reviewText:
Yikes, Pixar gets nicked by the double-edged sword. Pixar has had such a wildly successful run of animated films, one wondered how long the streak could be sustained. I guess the uneasy murmurs first surfaced when CARS 2 was critically panned. And now here's BRAVE, and murmur, murmur, murmur. And I liked BRAVE, quite liked it. But we grade on a curve when it comes to Pixar products. And as much as I favor BRAVE, it doesn't hold up to WALL-E or UP or FINDING NEMO or the TOY STORY franchise. Any other animated studio, and odds are I would've cast a more generous eye. But Pixar's standards are so lofty... I rate BRAVE 3.5 out of 5 stars. Kids will adore this movie. The grown-ups should maybe temper expectations.

It doesn't flaunt the originality of the Pixar classics. If anything, BRAVE wanders into the more familiar territory of Pixar's corporate partner, Disney. Set in an ancient and more mystical version of Scotland, the story revolves around Merida (Kelly Macdonald), a teenaged princess who rebels against a time-honored custom. Her doting father, King Fergus (Billy Connolly), may've erred in presenting her with a bow and arrows when she was a wee lass. Today Merida is very much a tomboy and has no use for the fineries of her status. When not besieged by her mother's unending instructions on history and proper royal decorum, Merida prefers to roam the craggy landscape and practice her archery. So imagine her collosal pique when her mother informs her that, as per tradition, the time has come for her to choose from three suitors.

Maybe Pixar was going for irony when they released BRAVE only a week after Father's Day. The film's central conflict lies between Merida and her exacting mother, Queen Eleanor (Emma Thompson). After a hurtful argument with her mom, Merida flees into the dark woods and stumbles onto a sketchy cottage in the wilds. In the cottage she finds a woodcarving old hag (Julie Walters), except does a woodcarver's home routinely feature a surprisingly mobile broom and a creepy talking bird? Merida is desperate to change her fate. The "woodcarver" has got something for her.

Beware the deal with the devil, the wish granted by the genie of the lamp, and the witch's spell. These never come out right for us foolish mortals. Merida's bargain leaves dreadful repercussions, and it's a bit frustrating that Merida repeatedly refuses to acknowledge any blame. The plot twist, the fallout to Merida's waywardness, is pretty unexpected - unless you knew the film's original title (which I won't mention). But, ugh... I think what follows underscores some folks' big quibble, which is that the film fails somewhat to deliver on the storytelling. As mentioned, this wouldn't be as telling if BRAVE had come out from other studios. But Pixar pictures are celebrated for their cleverness and inventiveness and rich emotional beats. BRAVE, compared to its predecessors (excepting CARS 2), presents a relatively uninspired narrative.

I wonder what effect director Brenda Chapman's being replaced had on the film? Because, ultimately, not everything comes together for this film, and this so is unlike Pixar. There are darker, scarier moments in the film which are then offset by a brawny and obvious form of levity. Aside from Merida and Queen Eleanor's depiction, characterization for the cast is doled out in broad strokes. Not to say that I didn't like the cast. King Fergus and the triplet scamps are all endearing as hell, but they're there mostly for comic relief. But if you thought the plot thread with the three hapless suitors is going somewhere, no, it fizzles out. The visiting members of the various clans are stereotyped to the kilt. So brace up for a steady diet of spit takes, brawling, carousing, and mooning (yes, mooning). Billy Connolly, Robbie Coltrane, Kevin McKidd, and Craig Ferguson as the four contentious Scottish lairds are admittedly great fun. Again, I wish they'd been developed more.

I know I've bagged on it, but I do recommend BRAVE. The visuals are sublime, and I'm sure it's no coincidence that your eyes are immediately drawn to Merida's fiery, untamed hair. Merida's tresses are so meticulously animated that Rapunzel's hair is gnashing its teeth (to mangle a metaphor). The Scottish Highlands are rendered in grand and panoramic detail. I love the design of the characters, the animators having leaned toward a stylized approach rather than a realistic one. Merida has got this distinctive moon face. It separates her from the other Disney princesses. And then there's Kelly Macdonald's marvelously expressive Scottish brogue. I could listen to her talk all day.

Also setting Merida apart is her remarkable aptitude for archery. In recent months, we'd already eyeballed Katniss Everdeen and the Avengers' Hawkeye. Merida's marksmanship rivals that of those two. There's a gratifying scene in which she Robin Hoods her way thru an archery competition, but then gets chewed out by her mum for her trouble. Yeah, Merida sometimes comes across as a brat, but you never doubt that her heart is in the right place. You never doubt that this family loves each other to pieces. Were you concerned that Merida won't be able to reverse the calamitous spell before the second sunrise deadline? Me neither. Ah, but will she own up to her bad behavior? Um...

I don't recommend viewing this in the 3D version, by the way. You just can't see anything during the night sequences, and there are heaps of night sequences. Also, you're in for a treat with the captivating animated short LA LUNA, which precedes the feature film. In it, a little boy learns the secret family business, which is awesome.

Brave portrays the powerful story about the difficulties a young woman named Merida has between following tradition and family expectations versus following her heart. Merida is strongwilled like her mother and they come to a confrontation regarding her betrothal. Carving a path that both may agree to is the heart of Brave. Merida learns that actions have consequences and may require equally brave actions to mend the strong bond of family.
This movie contains stunning cinematography, perfect editing, quality acting, powerful music and a compelling story filled with adventure, surprise, mystique and laugh out loud humor however children less than 4 may find that the roaring bear is scary.
I would be very proud to be Scottish today! We absolutely loved this movie and highly recommend it!!

Conclusion.

Great animation. Not a Pixar quality.

The animation was gorgeous, the music was haunting, and the humor was fabulous. The problem was the story. I do realize we're talking about Disney here, but C'mon, this was primitive and primeval even for the Magic Kingdom.

I'll sum up the story (SPOILER ALERT):

A rebellious girl is being forced to succumb to an arranged marriage so that her clan can remain allies with the other clans. She doesn't like it and rebels. What happens to girls who refuse to be treated like chattel? Why, their mothers get turned into bears, of course. Fitting punishment, and an excellent message to send to your daughters. And who facilitates the transformation of the mother into a mean and horrible beast, by the way? A "witch" of course: an old woman living in the forest. The vapidity of that stereotype didn't stop Disney from once again using it shamelessly.

So, how can this rebel princess straighten up and save her mother? By sewing.

I am not kidding.

By mending with a needle and thread a split she made in a tapestry. You know, by finally acting like a PROPER girl.
Then her mother is transformed back into her old self, and the men who otherwise might have been GIVEN the girl as a prize, now have agreed to court her until she loves and picks one of them (a flippant and insincere nod to women's rights). I'm sure she'll also be occasionally allowed to continue riding her horse and loosing her arrows at prescribed targets...that is, until she finally agrees to do her duty and marries one of the losers from which she has to pick. Ah, all is well.

Gimme a break.

I had hoped that Disney would finally have come up with a REAL heroine for a story, but instead it's just another thinly-veiled lesson in Christian patriarchy and female obedience.

2 stars for the positive points (animation, music, humor, scenery, imagination), and I certainly won't keep my daughter from watching it, but we're going to have a talk first about forced marriage and reasonable gender roles, and whether or not being old and living alone actually means a woman is evil and dishonest.

A delightful, brilliant and charming film! Pixar has created an amazing story that grabs the attention of children immediately and keeps them entertained throughout. The characters are Stunning as they give a breathtaking performance and will have the young ones laughing out loud. Wonderful, unforgettable animation with a creative story as the film portrays the trials-and-tribulations of stepping into adulthood, not an easy task for most. A fun-filled adventure, enjoyable for the entire family. Highly Recommended!

MOVIE REVIEW #39: " Brave "

I never thought I would ever write a review about a Pixar film like this one. It probably works better on the small screen (Blu Ray/DVD) but Disney's/Pixar release of director Brenda Chapman's (The Prince of Egypt) film Brave was a little more than disappointing.  I can see why this took 5 years to make and was pushed back with its release date two times.

Beautifully looking and deeply rich in Celtic culture it really lacks the full spectrum of the movie by grabbing you in the beginning and holding you. It's a mother and daughter film definitely and the best scenes are really only with them together. It does have a lush score by Patrick Doyle (Hamlet, Thor) - but even that didn't carry the film for me. Again it was made for 3-D - which it didn't really need - I think the glasses took away from the detail and majesty of the colors, textures and all the scenery itself in the film. (Just another attempt to charge more ticket prices at the box office, in my opinion..)

The story to me was a little simple and took a long while to get to the real `heart' of the film. It's about Merida, (Voiced by Kelly Macdonald of Boardwalk Empire and No Country For Old Men) who is a skilled archer and impetuous daughter of King Fergus (Voiced by Billy Connolly of The Last Samurai and Lemony Snickets) and - the one she conflicts with most, her mother Queen Elinor (Voiced by Emma Thompson of Nanny McPhee and Love Actually).

 Determined to carve her own path in life, Merida defies an age-old custom sacred to the uproarious lords of the land - Betrothal: with - the overly massive Lord MacGuffin (Voiced by Kevin Mckidd of Trainspotting and Kingdom of Heaven), the hugely surly Lord Macintosh (Voiced by Craig Ferguson of How To Train Your Dragon and Winnie The Pooh)  and cantankerous Lord Dingwall (Voiced by Robbie Coltrane of Harry Potter and Goldeneye).

Merida's actions inadvertently unleash chaos and fury in the kingdom, - as well as creating a huge riff in her relationship with her mother - and when she mistakenly turns to an eccentric old Witch for help, (Voiced by Julie Walters of Harry Potter and Mama Mia!), she is granted a strange wish to `change' her mother. A wish she later learns to regret and make the entire kingdom threaten her mother in a very mortal way. The ensuing peril forces Merida to harness all of her skills and resources -- including her clever and mischievous triplet brothers -- to undo a beastly curse before it's too late. She does this by learning how and summoning up her own Bravery!

Those three brothers end up being a VERY minor comic relief for the film. They could have done so much more with them, but the few scenes they had were `slapsticky' and quick with wit and humor - but not much.

Sounds great to hear story-wise- but to me the execution of the script was slow and the dialogue a little garbled due to the thick Celtic dialects overlapping a lot of the time. The screenplay written by Marc Andrews (John Carter) , Steve Purcell (Cars), Brenda Chapman (Cars, Beauty and the Beast) and Irene Mecci (Annie, Hercules) and need more heart and continuity to me.

The best scenes were always between Merida and her mother. Whether happy, arguing or dealing with a `change' - they were spot on! An extremely tear jerking moment is when her mother, in another form, realizes what's important to both her and her daughter and has to communicate this `change' to her daughter in a most unconventional, funny and heartfelt way!

Definitely a good film for the younger audiences and a family film - but  I definitely got the reaction/impression that it is geared more toward the female crowd (with a little action and a little violence thrown in for the men) and as such suffered the continuity and balance for a general audience. I think it was trying to be the female version of Finding Nemo. But it won't hold a candle to that classic Pixar film!

I wanted to enjoy it more....but it didn't have the Pixar heart I am so used and was excited and hoping to see again in a Pixar film. I am sure when I get the Bu Ray/DVD - it will work better. Some films work better on the small screen - this one needed a lot of help on the big one for me.

This is one of the best haitian movies I've seen. Great acting, great editing, it flows from one scene to another. You can tell this was made by professionals not amatures. Subtitled in English and French. Plus Reginald Lubin...should I say more?

Great animation, but as far as the story goes, it fails on multiple levels. Nearly every character except for the mom and daughter is a one dimensional goofball who wants to fight, so the viewer loses interest pretty quickly. With everyone playing someone who shouldn't be taken seriously, there is nothing at stake, so any danger they might find themselves in is boring.

Are there original songs in the movie? Yes, but none of the characters sing them. They are just played in the background and are not very memorable.

Now on to the title, Brave. There is very little bravery shown in the film.

**** Spoiler Alert ****

Does the main character do a lot of brave things? No she doesn't. She turns her mom into a bear and then spends the entire movie hiding the bear from her dad. With a title like Brave and a feisty female protagonist, the movie had potential for the young woman to do something extraordinary and they wasted that plot on a tale of regret.

The only saving grace is that the animation is one of the best Pixar has ever produced. The detail is truly amazing. This is the era of Pixar when they were focused on hair and it shows.

In conclusion, watch the movie for the animation because you really won't find much value in the script.

But the Scottish setting was wonderful. The castle, the hills, the beautiful soundtrackseriously, you should get this for the soundtrack alone. The message was a good one too, about putting oneself aside and being less selfish, for both her and her mother. A fun movie.

I absolutely love this movie.  It is one of my favorite by Disney and Merida may very well be my favorite princess.  She a is a feisty young woman who makes a rash decision.  However, she learns from her mistake, corrects it and changes her kingdom (for the better, we think) in the end.  Many other characters are also memorable.  Her cute little brothers, her Dad, who loves her but clearly is not sure what to do with her and her mother, who loves her and is trying to do what she feels is best.  They have a typical teenage daughter/mother relationship that blossoms as this story unfolds.  I love the imagery of Merida's time and place.  Her flaming red hair is definitely a symbol of her personality and determination.

I love princess movies, but this had to be one of the worst, most boring ones I've seen. It couldn't hold my interest for ten minutes. I've never watched a princess movie that was that awful.
First of all, we've all seen a million movies about princesses who rebel because they want to marry / don't want to marry someone and their parents or the patriarchy doesn't approve. Yes, this time, it's about a girl and her mom, and this time she chooses not to marry at all, but honestly, that doesn't lessen the clicheness. The only ones who really care about the "novelty" in that it's about a girl and her mom, and that this time she chooses not to marry at all, are people who are watching it for political validation, not entertainment. Disney might not have released a movie about a girl who chooses not to marry before Brave, or a girl who defies her mom instead of the patriarchy, but we've all read these plots in stories a million times. Merida doesn't want to marry because she'd rather ride through the forest and shoot arrows. She beats all of her suitors (who happen to be knuckleheaded oafs down to the last) at archery to prove she's shooting for her own hand, gets into a fight with her mom, then rides off to get enchanted cakes from a sorceress so she can feed them to her mom to change her. Her mom eats them and gets sick, but Merida, though she can see how ill she's getting, trails her gleefully, focused only on whether or not she's changed her mind about the planned arranged marriage. When her mom turns into a bear, she shows no horror or remorse and very little concern for her mom, but is only worried about how much trouble she'll get into. The dad was a henpecked overgrown child, the kids were annoying, and I pretty much stopped paying any attention to the movie after a while up until the end, where she FINALLY starts sobbing over what she's done and her mom comes back to life just like that. I was like, "Is this it? This is all?" I hardly felt like I'd watched a movie at all. I can't think of a more pointless and stupid film. Its morals are incoherent and all over the place and it makes no sense.

This film shows how a mother and daughter relationship was tested by each other differences. Both had to learn to listen to each other to fully understand the other. Elinor, the queen, just wants what is best for Merida while Merida wants her mother to see that life is not filled with all these strict rules of how to be lady or a princess in that matter. Both learn that their differences, flaws, were all life lessons to learn from one another. Both Merida and Elinor take a journey to teach themselves how to communicate and listen to one another and acceptance of each other to improve a mother and daughter relationship.

Nope, I don't have kids, and I'm not some weirdo. I'm your standard issue professional woman at a Fortune 500 company, who dutifully does her taxes and updates her LinkedIn profile as needed. I'm a progressive sorta gal in her 50's who is sick of crime, gore, too much gratuitous sex, young love stories that make me miss my youthful body, sick of dark and creepy stuff and loathe all things with zombies or violence.  So I went out of the box and rented a kid's movie.  I'm of Scottish descent, so why not.  I loved it. Just loved it. It resonated with my current 'take your expectations of me and shove it' mood, and left me uplifted a bit. Get kettlecorn or wine, whatever. I highly recommend this departure from being a grown up to all my friends who don't have kids.

I love this movie!!!  Once upon a time I owned every Disney VHS there was, and then, well, VHS was a thing of the past (can you imagine!!!?) and my final ability to play my beloved movies broke for the umpteenth time and I just couldn't justify fixing it again. I tried converting them to DVD or digital media, but no go--I finally just gave them away and am in the process of rebuilding my collection. For any body who hasn't seen Brave (is there really anybody out there who hasn't?) this is a wonderful movie with a positive message that you will remember years down the road. But underneath it all, there is an endearing story that has earned this movie its' place in the "Classic" hall of fame.

Amazon Digital is wonderful--it's nice to have this movie there in my forever library so I can watch it whenever and wherever I wish. The process was simple--press buy and viola! It showed up in my library.

It's a wonderful CG film, about a rambunctious 'tomboy' redhead who is going to be a future
leader by birth and take's extreme measures to make sure this doesn't happen. Because spoiled or something?

As an adult, watching this CG story unfold, whether I wanted to or not, I found myself reflecting on actions I took
when I was a young adult. Even so, I also found myself going "Dangit, why are you such idiots!?" And that was directed
toward the main character and her mother. Her mother should have turned into a chicken as much a she "henpecked'.. I'm
surprised Pixar didn't do an alternate tale where that happened honestly.

All it would have taken, is for the mother to back up a bit, and quit being so overbearing, and the daughter to just cool
her jets and focus. Of course, we wouldn't have had such a adventurous tale wove then?

Long story short. This is by far one of my favorite Pixar works. It ranks up there with "How to train your dragon" in its ability to
stick with me.

This is such a fun family film. We enjoyed it immensely! My family consists of a 4 year old, 18 month old and two adults. Some scenes were intense for my older child, however not so much that we needed to stop watching. Specifically the scenes toward the end with the dramatic climax of the plot proved to be particularly frightening. The plot is excellent and engaging for adults and children of all ages. Merida is a heroin following her own path, the plot focused closely on her story and personal development, rather than leading into romance which was an excellent change of pace. The story of Merida should encourage everyone, a true feel good film.

This is my #2 all time favorite animated movie (How to train your dragon being #1). This movie is very well animated and the voice acting is great. It's not your everyday 'princess movie' where boy meets girl, they fall in love etc... I know that some parents don't want to expose young children to that sort of thing too early.

It has action, adventure and lessons in taking responsibility for your own actions and making it right. The comedic parts of the movie are great and it has moments of character revelations and a message of family togetherness and mutual respect. There is a scary bear in the story and some short fighting scenes but nothing that I would call graphic. For real young kids the parent should watch it first to see if they think it will cause nightmares.

Seems too much like a re-tread of Brother Bear, but give them a break, at least they did it right. The problem I have is one that keeps cropping up with the Disney princess movies: weird feminists ideas. I believe I've mentioned it before and may have even started a thread on it. Female roles are presented as limiting to women, but realistically, males roles are limiting just as well. Any road you take makes you miss the other roads at the fork. It's just a part of life and should not be seen as a 'bad' thing. Now, if you wanna make it an indictment against arranged marriages, fine. So be it. But who in Western Culture really has to deal with that? These movies don't need to deal with safe, bland ideas.

Also, if you wanna present injustice and limitations to freedom, why make the character a Princess, someone who will, no matter what, lead a privileged life? The Tale of Desperaux, as unpleasant as it was, at least bothered to show is that the true absence of liberty comes from poverty and other physical, emotional & mental limitations which are pretty much out of the control of the individual.

I'm not cracking on the film itself. The film is a fine, competent effort (outstanding, lovely, design and overt influences of Melville are apparent.)  But this film making by committee limits the revealing psychological aspects or any insights on Life of the final result.

I just saw A Taste of Tea again. Something like that particular individual artistic achievement could with much difficulty be produced by a Pixar-like committee: only when an individual vision is pursued do they achieve greatness. Paradoxically Tea deals with individual artists of varying talents, some of whom produce flawed, commercial or derivative work. For example, the animator produces a very non-personal, superhero Anime fight sequence, and yet addresses that the true joy is in the moments of artistic creation and not necessarily related to the quality of the work produced. ...Or check out the "Mountain" music video... Much of the same, and yet clearly not missing in joyfulness.

So, this is the modern fairy tale? The damsel in distress being rescued by Prince Charming formula is old school. Instead we have an independent, head strong female who doesn't want to be told what to do. She enlists the aid of a witch to get her own way. It turns out disastrously, but all is well that ends well.

I think it's a tale for millennials. "Deny your parents and authority, follow your own path, and you will find happiness." It's a 180 from the "wait to be rescued by a handsome man." Neither is a balanced message. Just look at all the unhappiness, loneliness, and selfishness in the world and you will see that this doesn't work either.

Anyway, as a cute movie for kids, it works. It is fresh and entertaining. Not sure if "Brave" is an appropriate title, but it's an okay movie.

You just have to be Brave enough to see it.  And maybe cast aside the spears and arrows of critics.  Why do people put this movie down as a "girls" story?  Or a Disney princess story?  Or say "While this isn't one of Pixar's finest.."  What malarkey!  It is one of Pixar's finest.  I wonder if the reviewers have fully grasped the horrible implications of goings-on in this film.  They are horrifying indeed.

This is hands-down Pixar's darkest film yet.  If it weren't for the comedy this would be a horror story or a story of 10th-century war.  Last night, I realized this is a Dark Comedy.  Very dark.  And not just in terms of theme -- it's visually dark, as well -- which only makes Merida stand out like a bright flame in a dark alley.  At the same time, this movie is laden with human touches.  But that dark side this movie has can show without notice.

Spoilers ahead.  Read at your own risk.

Why is it Pixar's darkest?

Consider this:

1. A 5-ish year old little girl sees a giant, cursed bear attack her and her family.  The outcome is grim, and she is implied to have seen it happen.
2. An entire kingdom is laid to ruin, with vivid, visible evidence.. everywhere.. that it was an epic massacre, war, perhaps.  Nothing subtle about it.
3. No-holds barred, often fiercely feral combat with hand to hand and with edged weapons, arrows and spears.
4. Choices made often carry severe consequences, for-keeps.  No backsies.  No reset button.

It is also possibly Pixar's most beautiful film yet.  It's not so much an animated cartoon, but an animated Rembrandt painting.  It has that glowing quality.  While it is dark most of the time - except for Merida's torch-like mane - it glistens with vividness.  Nature is rendered with such loving beauty it remains with the viewer long after the stinger at the end of the credits fades.

And the music.. oh my lord, the music on this movie.  It can, on its own, bring tears.  This film took an Academy Award for sound, and if the viewer has a proper home theater, the result is enough to pull you into the film, put you in the Highlands.

I would like to think as Time, the Ultimate Critic passes, Brave will stand among the Pixar movies people of today consider great.

Myself, I think it already does.

Pixar set a high standard with the Toy Storys, WALL*E, and Finding Nemo (among others). These are kid films adults can enjoy and that tightrope is one few films ever make across. Unfortunately, Pixar is in a funk since the late 2000s and Brave (definitely lesser Pixar) will not pull the company out of the doldrums. Yet, this reviewer keeps faith in a Pixar revival; they're too talented over there not to. Brave scores points for its sheer beauty as a moving picture with misty, medieval Scotland as the setting. Moss, stone, and skin looks very real. Brave also scores points for authenticity. The main voice actors are Scottish, so the accents are real. Alas, the plot is a thinly-veiled, copy-and-paste job of Beauty and the Beast and the heroine, Merida, comes off as quite spoiled, rather than strong-willed. In classic teenage tradition, Merida fails to honor her father and, especially, her mother. [Explaining how would unnecessarily reveal plot points] This failure brings on the last fatal error of Brave: lack of a villain. Pride, not evil, sets the conflict for the film and the conflict is mostly lightweight and weak in execution. If you're going to make a princess movie (more classic Disney than Pixar specialty) then a nasty villain (think Jafar) may of drove the film's moral point home more solidly. Final verdict: worthwhile and family friendly, but nothing special (unfortunately).

A couple years back, the calls began for Pixar to have a female lead in a movie, and I began to roll my eyes.  As the calls got louder over the last couple of years, I rolled them more.  But Pixar answered back with Brave, and movie that will appeal to both boys and girls.

Merida (voiced by Kelly MacDonald) has been trained all her life by her mother Elinor (Emma Thompson) to take her proper place.  See, Merida is a princess in one of the clans in middle ages Scotland, and she must act properly and take a husband at the proper time.

That time is now, and her father Fergus (Billy Connolly) has called a gathering of the other clans.  There is to be a contest, and the winner will become betrothed to Merida.  But Merida enjoys her freedom and being outdoors.  Can she find a way to change her fate?

Now if you are worried that the previews give away too much know that they dofrom the first act.  Everything I've seen in previews (and I think I've seen most of them) took place early on in the film, and when it really got going, it shot off in an unexpected direction.

That's not to say I couldn't figure out the big brushes of the project early on.  But I was still caught up in the story, even as I was a step or two ahead of the where the plot actually was.

Merida and Elinor are really the main characters here, and their journey is compelling because they are so well fleshed out.  I truly came to care for them.  The rest of the cast are the supporting players, and they do a great job of it.

I enjoyed the Scottish accents of the supporting cast.  I never had a hard time understanding them (well, except for one character, but that's the joke with him).  And everyone does a great job bringing their characters to life.

It goes without saying, but the animation is gorgeous.  While other studios make fun computer animated films, no one does it with the artistry that Pixar does.  The scenery is just gorgeous.

The film is rated PG, and parents should pay attention to that.  I'd definitely say it is for older kids and up.  There are a few scenes of humor revolving around what men do and don't wear under their kilts, including one of brief rear end nudity.  Frankly, I thought those scenes were pretty funny.  More worrisome for parents are several scary scenes involving bears.  I hear a couple little kids leaving the theater where I saw it talking about how scary it was.  You know your child best, so judge accordingly.

While this movie does star a princess and have some elements of magic to it, it is certainly a story that will entertain both boys and girls.  It has lots of action in the story, and Merida is quite the tomboy.

And definitely stay through the credits.  There is a fun final scene at the very end you'll appreciate.

For me, this is in the second tier of Pixar films, and it took me a while to put my finger on why.  I think it's the story.  Yes, predictable stories aren't necessarily deal killers, but I think I usually expect more from Pixar.  From any other studio, I would have loved this one, but Pixar has set the bar so high for themselves that this becomes a lesser entry.

But by all means go and see it.  Brave is a bit of a more serious movie from Pixar, but it is still enjoyable.  I think they have another hit on their hands.

This awesome film changed my life.  I love every element.  The animation is awesome.  The story is fantastic.  I was most attracted to the fact that Disney created such a strong woman figure.  NO ONE messes with Merida!  Her triplet brothers joyfully steal the show on several occasions.  It's delightful!

There is a special place in my heart for the witch.  She's awesome.  They did their research.  Wiccans never conjure where they carve!

And, the sub plot with the wisps, and how they guide the film through is genius.

The counterpoint with Mordu is an ever-present threat.  The plot point of him also being a family member, and the story that goes along with that is precious.

Patrick Doyle's Scottish inspired soundtrack fits perfectly.

Disney really does need to put their differences aside with Brenda Chapman, and let her back in the director's chair.  I'm not sure if we are going to see any film that is the epic likes of Brave again, anytime soon.

It's well worth the 1 hour and 42 minutes of your life.  Go see it!

Whats it about?

Determined to make her own path in life, Princess Merida defies a custom that brings chaos to her kingdom. Can she undo a beastly curse?

What did I think?

For a movie featuring archery, its ironic that Brave doesnt quite hit the mark. Its a little predictable and oddly two-dimensional  very strange for a PIXAR offering. The characters are rich, the scenery is stunning, but the story just lacks depth and any lasting connection.

Im not sure whether its because the movie has had so many problems with re-writes and re-workings or Disney interfered to make it a safe movie, but Brave is a solid movie without the usual PIXAR magic.
Love this story! We should all embody the courage of Merida.

Brave's message is a simple one--a parent's love for a child is unparalleled.  Despite her willfulness, Merida learns that her mother, regardless of Merida's attitude and actions, sustains a deep and abiding love for her. It's a hard lesson for Merida, but one that awakens and matures her.

A fitting fairy tale if I ever saw one. I think the title Brave sums up the entirety of the movie and the story. Not just about the young Viking princess. But of all of the Viking nation. And this movie gives us a good example of what Vikings upheld and how it might have been for some when the challenge was too great and for some when the challenge became legend. It also shows us an example of the place of highborn women in the Viking nation. There are those that did become warriors and for lowborns this was accepted, but in highborns it was not. And  that's where this movie begins. With a young princess, not fitting the mold her mother wants her to fit into, and the princess wanting to be something she is not born to be.... I'll let you watch the movie to see what happens and how these to come to an agreement that is acceptable for both of them and the journey that got them there. I highly recommend it to any age. Especially adults. They could learn a thing or two in this world of "Brave".

This is a cute story about Marida, daughter of King Fergus and Queen Eleanor, who has grown up being able to ride astride her horse, Angus, along with learning archery and exploring the surrounding countryside. When she's approached by her mother who tells her she needs to choose a husband, Marida is not happy with the prospect at all. While in the surrounding woods, she comes upon a witch; she asks the witch to help her "change my fate". What follows is a darling story about being careful what you wish for.  I thoroughly enjoyed the movie, which included numerous touches that added to my enjoyment and gave me many reasons for wanting to see it again and again.
It is a story for all ages with just a few semi scary scenes. I chose to purchase the DVD so I can see it again. I highly recommend it.

I think this movie is outstanding because it teaches a lesson rarely taught these days.  I saw that someone else had hailed this movie as good because it teaches that a woman doesn't have to get married and that we can take our fate into our own hands.  I disagree that that is the central message of the film.  In fact, I think that is extremely short-sighted and (dare I say) self-indulgent.  I think the movie is about exactly what the witch said.  MEND THE BOND TORN BY PRIDE.  How many times in the bible does Jesus warn against pride?  It is the root of all sin.  Even during Merida's big speech, she admitted that she had been selfish (another clue).  The mother bear would not turn back into Elinor until Merida humbled herself, admitted her fault and apologized.  What would this world be if all people would be quick to do that?  This movie teaches an important lesson about HUMILITY and the danger of pride.  It also teaches the importance of family and peacekeeping.  The marriage piece was irrelevant.  This was about a parent and a child making amends and correcting the damage caused by anger, pride and rebellion.  Bravo Brave!
Love it
GREAT  MOVIE..

I'm reviewing the substance of the movie, not the DVD quality, Amazon service, streaming speed, etc. Terrific movie, and here's why (without giving away too much):
1. Animation is great, down to every last detail.
2. Story is original, folks! Not like other Disney movies -- Snow White (Brothers Grimm), LIttle Mermaid (Hans Christian Andersen), Tangled (story of Rapunzel reprised), Cinderella (Brothers Grimm again), Frozen (Hans Christian Andersen again (The Snow Queen)), and on and on. What a creative, different, but entirely believable story, with both serious and funny moments, and a very good message.
3. Main characters (Merida and Queen Elinor) are thoughtfully developed. Unlike traditional damsel-in-distress Disney princesses, Merida is assertive and smart and courageous. So is Queen Elinor. And their disagreement represents the quintessential challenges and complexities of mother-daughter relationships. There is no clear right or wrong -- just different perspectives between two strong willed ladies.
All that being said, I agree that it can be scary and probably inappropriate for really little kids to watch. I would say 6 yo and older is fine. But it isn't any more violent than Bambi, Finding Nemo, Snow White, Tangled or Lion King. This is not your typical happy sing-along Disney musical movie like Frozen, but I think Brave's musical scores are inspiring, authentic, haunting and beautiful. I loved just about everything in this movie, except for maybe the title. I don't expect everyone to love it too, but at least give it a chance.

At first I was hesitant to see this film because I had felt that the quality of animated features were on a decline.  Brave changed that and gave me a new respect towards the computer-animated medium.  The beauty of the subtle details and vibrant colors used make the characters fit nicely with the historical-fantasy setting.  This is a modern story that uses the spirit of Scottish traditions to create a new Celtic Legend for the enjoyment of all ages.  The strong female lead shows that everyone has the ability to grow into their own life while still honoring the feelings of their loved ones.  It is definitely a film for those seeking a true adventure.

I cannot speak to the entire movie because we just couldn't watch the whole thing! After we survived the brawl scene when all the Scots were clobbering each other, we thought it might get better. But when she cursed her own mother (!), we had to turn it off, especially with our young children there watching. My mother was in the room and asked us, shocked, "Are you sure this movie is for kids?" I really had to say I wasn't sure. There was so much incredible violence, covered up with slapstick and silliness, but violence nonetheless. I know a lot of people love the theme of a strong, wild hearted, independent heroine, but I have a different view. Though I understand why Merida was standing her ground, and agreed with her point, being disrespectful, yelling at parents, going to a witch to curse one's own mother- these are not behaviors I want my children to emulate. They aren't even behaviors I wish to exhibit myself, as an adult.

The story gets nowhere. The girl is a gifted archer. Where does that get her in the story? Nowhere. Couldn't even kill the bear or defend her mom or anything. The plot is totally predictable, unimaginative, and unreasonable. The mother is demanding and absurd. The mother-daughter conflict never did get resolved. There is the problem of the mom becoming a bear, that had to be solved. But the mom's not approving the girl's being a tomboy, which is the whole point of the first half of the story? That's forgotten.  I can't believe Pixar came up with such a half baked plot.

Finging Nemo is about parent child conflict, but the conflict is explored and resolved. For Brave, the conflict is ignored because of the bear, and then forgotten!

But the graphics, O, the graphics! The Scottish scenery is to die for! But most importantly, the girl's curly hair bouncing around is the most amazing feat of animation I've ever seen! I watch this movie just to watch her hair bounce. I read somewhere that they wrote a special program to get her hair to bounce like that, some 300 hairs all bouncing simultaneously in individual ways. Amazing! I don't believe the art of animation will ever get better than this movie. EVER!!!

I am a steelbook collector and I have to admit that this steelbook of Brave is definitely my favourite. The surface is a high gloss and smooth finish with some embossing. The colours are vivid and lush. Both external and internal covers have high resolution prints depicting four scenes from the movie.

The finish, the presentation, the artistry and final product are brilliant. If you are a steelbook collector and like a high quality product then this dvd is for you.

The movie in itself is excellent as many other reviewers have attested in their reviews. I am also very impressed by a dvd package that includes five discs. Finally, this steelbook certainly gives the purchaser full value for the cost incurred.

BRAVE [2012] [3D Blu-ray + 2D Blu-ray + Bonus 2D Blu-ray] [UK Release] A Triumph of Animation!

PIXAR Animation Studios, the creator of Toy Story 3, whisks you away on an astonishing adventure to an ancient land full of mystery and tradition. Bursting with heart, unforgettable characters and PIXARs signature humour.

Take a heroic journey with Princess Merida, a skilled archer and headstrong daughter of King Fergus and Queen Elinor. Determined  to carve her own path in life, Princess Merida defies an age-old custom sacred to the unruly and uproarious lords of the land. When Princess Meridas actions inadvertently unleash chaos in the kingdom, she must harness all of her skills and resources, including her clever and mischievous triplet brothers, to undo a beastly curse before its too late, and discover the meaning of true bravery. Its legendary on a PIXAR/Disney Blu-ray with never-before-seen bonus features!

FILM FACT: Awards and Nominations: 2013 85th Academy Awards: Won: Best Animated Feature Film of the Year for Mark Andrews and Brenda Chapman. American Cinema Editors: Won: Best Edited Animated Feature Film for Nicholas C. Smith, A.C.E. BAFTA Awards: Won: Best Animated Film. Critics' Choice Awards: Nominated: Best Animated Feature. Nominated: Best Song for Mumford & Sons and Birdy for "Learn Me Right." Golden Globe Awards: Won: Best Animated Feature Film for Mark Andrews and Brenda Chapman. Grammy Awards: Nominated: Best Song Written for Visual Media for Mumford & Sons and Birdy for the song "Learn Me Right." International Film Music Critics Association Awards: Nominated: Best Original Score for an Animated Feature for Patrick Doyle.

Voice Cast: Kelly Macdonald, Billy Connolly, Emma Thompson, Julie Walters, Robbie Coltrane, Kevin McKidd, Craig Ferguson, Sally Kinghorn, Eilidh Fraser, Peigi Barker, Steven Cree, Steve Purcell, Callum O'Neill, Patrick Doyle and John Ratzenberger

Directors: Brenda Chapman, Mark Andrews and Steve Purcell (co-director)

Producers: Andrew Stanton, John Lasseter, Katherine Sarafian, Mary Alice Drumm and Pete Docter

Screenplay: Brenda Chapman (story), Irene Mecchi, Mark Andrews and Steve Purcell

Composer: Patrick Doyle

Video Resolution: 1080p

Aspect Ratio: 2.39:1

Audio: English: 7.1 Dolby TrueHD, English: 7.1 Dolby Digital Plus, English: 5.1 Dolby TrueHD, French: 5.1 Dolby Digital, English: 2.0 Dolby Digital, French: 2.0 Dolby Digital, Portuguese: 2.0 Dolby Digital, Russian: 2.0 Dolby Digital, Castilian Spanish: 2.0 Dolby Digital, Catalan Spanish: 2.0 Dolby Digital, Ukrainian: 2.0 Dolby Digital, Kazakh: 2.0 Dolby Digital, and English: Audio Described English

Subtitles: English, English SDH, French, Portuguese, Russian, Castilian, Spanish and Ukrainian

Running Time: 93 minutes

Region: All Regions

Number of discs: 3

Studio: PIXAR Animation Studios / Walt Disney Home Entertainment

Andrews Blu-ray Review: Chafing under the domination of her mother Queen Elinor [Emma Thompson], Princess Merida [Kelly Macdonald] isn't interested in being groomed for the throne and is definitely not ready to be betrothed to one of a trio of grisly young men from three other Scottish clans. So, she happens upon The Witch [Julie Walters] in the forest who offers her a spell-ridden cake for her mother which Princess Merida hopes will change her mothers point of view about her daughters future. But as is often the case with magic, what appears fool proof on the surface goes awry as one bite of the cake turns her mother into a bear. With the fearsome bear Mordu having bitten off her father King Ferguss [Billy Connolly] leg as a young man, Princess Merida knows bears aren't popular around the castle, so she hastens to get her mother away from the clans and hopes she can find the witch to reverse the spell. When that fails, Princess Merida and her mother find their bond becomes stronger in their common search for an answer to her dilemma, but time is running out to change her mother back as the spell becomes permanent after two days.

The story flows smoothly as we watch Princess Merida grow from a young girl to a young woman becoming a proficient archer along the way. Even with the setting of 13th century Scotland, much about the dynamics between the parents and children in the movie have a distinctly modern ring to them, and Princess Meridas recalcitrance at being forced into something shes not emotionally ready to undertake with no possibility of stating her own case will be easy to identify with for almost any audience, especially with Princess Meridas showdown with her three suitors in an archery tournament is one of the films high points. While the writers get a bit too cute with The Witchs personality in her two sequences, shes undeniably entertaining if a bit too modern to fit comfortably among these rustic warriors of old. The films production design, however, is simply jaw dropping as Scotland comes alive in these majestic, detailed CGI renderings, and the directors use their ravishing settings to stage a number of memorable sequences. The highlight of the film remains a bucolic sequence when Queen Elinor as Mum-bear learns to forage for food in a stream where gorgeous animation provides both tender moments and slapstick comedy in the best PIXAR tradition.

Kelly Macdonald is full of feisty sassiness and plenty of pluckiness for Princess Merida, and her Scottish brogue, as is the case with the other Scottish actors hired for the film, is never too thick to prevent understanding of what shes saying. Emma Thompson has a noble carriage and the gentle art of diplomacy as Queen Elinor while Billy  Connollys braying and clumsy King Fergus is always a real treat. The three Scottish clan leaders putting their sons up for selection are played in the expected extroverted manner by Robbie Coltrane, Kevin McKidd, and Craig Ferguson. Julie Walters has all kinds of fun with the eccentric witch who moonlights as a wood carver, and bears are a specialty.

The computer animation is, of course, spectacular, with meticulous attention paid to the smallest of details. The performances are fine, too, infused with enough enthusiasm and warmth to make the characters as dimensional as the images they populate. And after a couple of sequels and there's that Disney influence once again, and it's nice to see PIXAR return to an original story that transports us to a foreign setting and simpler time, and give young girls a spunky role model they can learn from and emulate.

At 93 minutes, 'BRAVE' is one of PIXAR's shortest films, but despite its efficient storytelling, it still possesses a fair amount of depth. Though the characters it depicts may reside on a rarefied plane, the issues they confront are universal and timeless, and the ultimate message emphasizing the strong bonds of family, however trite, is presented in a poignant and effective manner. 'BRAVE' may not be as bold as its title, but it is a good solid PIXAR effort, celebrating not just girl power, but the power of understanding and mutual respect.

Blu-ray Video Quality  The films theatrical widescreen aspect ratio of 2.39:1 is faithfully rendered in this awesome 1080p encoded image. Whether in 3D or 2D, the images are breathtakingly beautiful. The details in hair, clothes, a tapestry, especially where you can see individual strands, trees, moss, stone, and other objects just defy description. Colours are bold and deeply saturated with Meridas red, red hair coming close to but never quite blooming. Black levels are rich and deep, and the image is as perfect as one should expect. As with most PIXAR 3D films, outward projections are not of primary importance to the animators though there are arrow tips and hands that reach beyond the frame for split seconds. But the sense of depth in the image is often quite staggering, and the 3D version of the film is much more interesting visually with its complex placement of people, animals, and objects within their environments which 3D exploits to the maximum.

Blu-ray Audio Quality  The 7.1 Dolby TrueHD sound mix is a miracle of audio design with split sound effects occupying the fronts and rears at an almost constant pace. There are pans across and through the sound field, and the rear back channels are used to make smooth transitions for sounds at the rear of the field. Patrick Doyles music and the Gaelic ballads of Julie Fowlis get remarkably fluid renderings in the fronts and rears aiding immeasurably in establishing the time and place of the action. Dialogue has been beautifully recorded and has been placed in the centre channel.

Blu-ray Special Features and Extras:

Audio Commentary: Commentary with Director Mark Andrews, co-director Steve Purcell, Editor Nick Smith, and story supervisor Brian Larsen: All four sit down for a lively commentary that allows us to see inside the creative minds of the filmmakers. From an abandoned alternate opening and a homage to 'The Sound of Music' to character insights and scene analyses, the quartet shares a wealth of interesting information in an easy-going, accessible style. They talk about, among other things, adding fresh elements to stereotypical figures, such as princesses and witches, various concepts that never materialised, balancing comedy and dramatic intensity, managing the movie's pace, and the incredible amount of trial and error that go into making an animated film. Children may find the discussion a bit dull, but adults, especially animation fans like me, found this commentary a worthwhile time investment.

Special Feature: Pixar Short Film: La Luna [2011] [1080p] [7:00] A fable of a young boy who is coming of age in the most peculiar of circumstances. Tonight is the very first time his Papa and Grandpa are taking him to work. In an old wooden boat they row far out to sea, and with no land in sight, they stop and wait. A big surprise awaits the little boy as he discovers his family's most unusual line of work. Should he follow the example of his Papa, or his Grandpa? Will he be able to find his own way in the midst of their conflicting opinions and timeworn traditions? This exudes a subtle sense of wonder and is filled with beautiful imagery. La Luna was nominated at the 84th Academy Awards for Best Animated Short Film.

Special Feature: Behind-the-Scenes [1080p] [50:00] Eight behind-the-scenes documentaries are available on the feature film disc. "Brave Old World follows the PIXAR team on a research trip to Scotland. Merida and Elinor digs into the lead female characters with the voice cast, designers and animators. "Bears" should be even more self-explanatory to those who've seen the film. Brawl in the Hall looks at the development and animation of the comedic clash of the clans. Wonder Moss delves into the complex mathematical creation of the movie's background moss, something most people will take for granted. Magic dissects Brave's fairy tale roots and magical elements. Clan Pixar introduces the artists and animators, touching on their daunting task and intense efforts. And Once Upon a Scene offers a glimpse into various versions of Brave's opening, key scenes and story.

Special Feature: Fergus & Mordu: An Alternate Opening [1080p] [7:00] A cautionary fable about the pitfalls of jealousy, ambition, and forsaking one's family, this dark tale ties nicely into the plot and themes of 'BRAVE' as it charts the development of the film's scariest villain.

Special Feature Documentary: Fallen Warriors [1080p] [2:00] This montage of deleted shots and snippets celebrates the hard work that goes into even the tiniest sequences in an computer animated film.

Special Feature Documentary: Dirty Hairy People [1080p] [4:00] This piece shows how the animators stayed true to the film's time period with regard to personal hygiene and appearance. Rotted teeth, unkempt hair, and sullied clothing are a few of the challenges they faced in composing their subjects.

Special Feature Documentary: It is English . . . Sort of [1080p] [4:00] This documentary showcases the numerous Scottish actors who lent their voice talents to 'BRAVE,' and examines the various dialects they employ, as well as some of the foreign Scottish words and phrases sprinkled throughout the film.

Special Feature Documentary: Angus [1080p] [3:00] Animating a Clydesdale horse wasn't easy, and here we learn about the particulars of hair, movement, and body language and all vital components of Princess Merida's horse that needed to be subtly but accurately conveyed to the audience.

Special Feature Documentary: The Tapestry [1080p] [4:00] This piece shows us what went into animating this critical element of the 'BRAVE' story that symbolises family unity and structure. Achieving the proper texture and movement of this object required a surprising amount of research and various trials.

Special Feature Documentary: Promotional Pieces [1080p] [15:00] A collection of five fun promos and three trailers from the U.S.A, Japan, and Great Britain that comprise this section. Feast Your Eyes [4:00] is a clever, amusing, and visually dazzling sampler of 'Brave' characters and personalities; Relics [1:00] introduces us to the lovable, bumbling, comedic trio that comes to court; Clan Dun Broch [1:00] introduces us to Princess Merida's family via a vigorous swordfight with her dad; Launch [0:30] shows us Merida's archery skills and the mischievous nature of her brothers; and Flying Guts Theatre [1:00] gives us the backstory of the courtship of Queen Elinor and Fergus as acted out by their three boys.

Special Feature: Art Gallery [1080p] More than 470 images are spread across five galleries under the headings Characters [178 images]; Colour Keys [95 images]; Development Art [96 images]; Environments [65 images] and Graphics [37 images]. Different viewing methods and bookmarking capabilities allow you to somewhat tailor the viewing experience to your personal preference.

Sneak Previews: Wreck-It Ralf 3D [1080p], Monster University 3D [1080p] and Planes 3D [1080p].

Finally, PIXAR finally shows its feminine side at last with its first princess computer animated film, but 'BRAVE' is no shrinking violet. With as much muscle as its more masculine Pixar counterparts, this captivating portrait of wilful, free-thinking lass in 11th century Scotland combines action and mysticism with a relatable emotional core to produce a period piece that's refreshingly contemporary and utterly entertaining. And like all the Blu-rays in the PIXAR repertoire, this Blu-ray disc shows off the computer animated film in the best possible light. A drop-dead gorgeous video transfer, which is even more mesmerising in 3D, exceptional audio, and a wealth of supplements spread across two Blu-ray discs make 'Brave' a dazzling and memorable home theatre experience. Unlike Merida's archery skills, the film may not always hit the bulls-eye, but this 3 disc set sure does, and without question, it comes with very high praise and now it has gone pride of place in my ever increasing PIXAR Blu-ray Collection, especially the 3D versions. Highly Recommended!

Andrew C. Miller  Your Ultimate No. 1 Film Fan
Le Cinema Paradiso

This review is for the poor quality of the disc being sold at the reduced price. The one I received was a "Disc Made in Mexico" as stated on the outside cellophane wrap.  Most people wouldn't think twice about looking on the bottom back of the plastic wrap for this faded blue notation.  (These made in Mexico discs are everywhere, in most popular and standard shop-marts.)  If you ripped that plastic off, like all people do, you'd miss this fleeting information and be fooled to believe the "Printed in the U.S.A" on the back of the disc jacket pertains to the disc.  Maybe the disc jacket sheet was printed in the U.S. and the inside paper pamplets BUT NOT THE DISC.  As soon as the disc started to play in hazzy image, I knew then something was off and sure enough there on the cello-wrap was the "Disc Made in Mexico" stamp.  What a disappointment for the kids!

I have always had bad results with disc made in Mexico--(Two times is enough--this third, unbeknownst until I got it, was returned and I had to PAY the return postage--though Amazon said they'll refund about $4 while I paid the cheapest return postage of almost $6 for a defective product that wasn't my fault!  No cool Amazon!)  I posted in various "Comments" asking if anyone knew where this DVD was made but apparently no one paid attention.  There was a reason why the "Disc Made in Mexico" wasn't more prominently displayed on the disc jacket instead of the least paid attention to plastic wrap!

The Story IS GREAT--buy ones made in the U.S.A.--referring to the disc.  For this review the disc is the product and the product is of very poor quality for the "Disc Made in Mexico" price.

Incredibly disappointing. This could have been such a cute movie with an interesting princess with awesomely crazy hair who fights against the tradition of having no say in who she marries or when. It started out teasing us with the thought that she was going to prove to her parents that she was more than just a pretty face, but instead the plot descended into darkness with her paying a witch to cast a spell over her mother and turn her into a bear.  Seriously? They created this strong-willed character with mad archery skills who could have become a heroine and saved the kingdom from an invading army or something, but instead she simply cursed her mom and had to try to break the spell before it was permanent. Really? Does Disney always have to throw witchcraft into their movies?

It is the middle ages in the highlands of Scotland where King Fergus' daughter, Merida, has lived wild and free all her young life.  She learns that her parents have decided it's time for her to marry and settle down and she flatly refuses. She and her mother have a quarrel during which Merida ruins an ancient and very valuable wall tapestry. Merida then runs to the stable, saddles her horse and gallops off to the woods where the will'o'the wisps lead her to a witch's cottage. She begs the witch to create a spell that will help her mother understand her better - and there the fun begins. I had the great good fortune to live in Scotland in the 60's and in my opinion the Pixar folks did an AMAZING job capturing the look and feel of the place by using very real locations, like Dunottar Castle, as models for locations in the film. The intelligent, true-to-life script makes me laugh - and cry - and Emma Thompson, Kelly McDonald, Billy Connolly, Robby Coltrane and the rest of the cast do a WONDERFUL job creating the other characters. And finally, Patrick Doyle's very authentic score brings the perfect finishing touch to this incredibly beautiful film about staying true to yourself no matter what the consequences.(Listen for American voice artist June Foray in a cameo as the crazy woodcrafting witch).

With "Brave", Pixar finally made their entrance into a period and fairy tale setting. After the critical and financial failure of "Cars 2" (which is a film that I personally enjoyed and didn't deserve the massive hate), "Brave" was seen as Pixar's chance of redemption. However, some Pixar fans screamed foul and thought "Brave" was a result of the Disneyfication of Pixar. However, although "Brave" wasn't seen as the definite Pixar comeback, it still was better critically and commercially received as "Cars 2".

The feminist aspects were also surrounding "Brave". It was their first film with a female lead after more than a decade of films with male leads. "Brave" got also some buzz of the directorial change. It was Brenda Chapman's lovechild, but she got replaced because of creative differences. Although Chapman herself has stated that her original visions of the tale was fulfilled, the replacements are barely mentioned in the special features. She still got credited as the secondary director, although one can't help to wonder if there was a bigger conflict about this story or if this conflict was enhanced by the media.

Either way, although I've always been not so fond of Pixar, they can deliver a masterpiece now and then ("Toy Story", "Finding Nemo", "Up"). "Brave" does come across a one of Pixar's strongest works, but is also hampered by some flaws. And some quite obvious flaws too. Moviegoers has grown to expect more from Pixar and many of them found the film to be conventional. The marketing device also misguided the film, depicting it as a grand adventure, when it really is an intimate, character-driven story in the second half.

Where "Brave" really excel is with the animation and the music. The animation is stunningly gorgeous, as is the music, setting a haunting atmosphere and giving the movie a special quality. The wonderful score is by Patrick Doyle, the songs written by Alex Mandel and they work well.

"Brave" is a departure from Pixar's previous works, not only because of it's setting, but it's scope. It definitively feels more Disney than Pixar at times, but that's doesn't necessarily hurts the film. I see nothing wrong about Pixar trying to go in Disney's territory  and make a Princes movie long you do it with class and subtlety (damn me as much as you want to, Pixar fanboys). However, I still wished that Pixar would make more realistic-looking characters for once and expand their horizons in term of character designs.

Where "Brave" falls flat, it's in terms of it's story. It's quite conventional, as the matter of fact too conventional. The story is trite, cliched and really not particularly well structured. The film seems more of two separate stories incorporated into one. However, despite the  story problems, "Brave" shall have praise for having a mother-daughter-related story in a fairy tale setting and not having a prince charming to save the day.

Another noteworthy component about "Brave" is the choice of having an all Scottish cast into the movie. It's easy to give Pixar some good points about that, although the Medieval Scottish would probably be not understandable for todays audiences. However, most of the voices are fine. Billy Connolly (who previously was in "Pocahontas") brings the warmth and joviality to King Fergus. Emma Thompson (who was in "Treasure Planet") brings dignity and subtlety to Queen Ellinor. Less successful is Kelly McDonald as the protagonist Merida herself, making Merida more grating and whiny than she needs to be. Otherwise, Julie Walters makes a fine witch. Steve Purcell makes a fun crow. Kevin McKidd makes a good Lord MacGuffin/Young MacGuffin. Craig Ferguson delivers some spunk to Lord Macintosh.

BONUS FEATURES
The film is filled with good bonus features. First up is a audio commentary by director Mark Andrews, co-director Steve Purcell, editor Nick Smith and story supervisor Brian Larsen. The four of them delivers an excellent commentary, covering all the topics of the story and the technical aspects, although Andrew's voice can be a little grating at times. But still another excellent commentary from Pixar.

LEGEND OF MOR'DU; A short which enhances the full story about Mor'Du (according to rumors that were around the Internet, the short was supposed to be included in the actual movie). It's a fine short, giving more purpose and weight to the story of Mor'Du and it's nice to see that it's mainly hand-drawn.

LA LUNA: A short and sweet Pixar film.

BRAVE OLD WORLD: A featurette that talks about the crew's visit to Scotland and the Scottish influences on the film. Although is mostly praise about the land and culture, it's still interesting.

MERIDA & ELINOR: A featurette that covers the characters and personalities of Merida and Elinor and their relationship. Chapman herself dominates most of the featurette. A quite engaging topic.

BEARS: A short featurette that covers the designs and animation aspects of Mor'Du and Queen Elinor as a bear. Short, but still quite interesting.

WONDER MOSS: A topic about how they created the moss in the movie. It's a little too technical, but still interesting.

MAGIC: Magic tells us about the magical aspects of the film, like the wisps and the witch and the fairy tale aspect. Quite enjoyable

CLAN PIXAR: A featurette that covers the folks at Pixar. A little more jovial and happy talk than what it needs to be.

ONCE UPON A SCENE: A featurette that delivers the many deleted scenes (and also indicates "Brave's" troubled production). It's interesting that Pixar decided to have many of the deleted scenes in one featurette, instead of having the deleted scenes themselves. However, it's still interesting to watch.

Disc two is also filled with many featurettes. First up is an alternative opening (a few shots that made into one of the trailers). While it's not fully animated, it's still an engaging shot.

FALLING WARRIORS: A featurette about the fighting scenes in the movie and how they got choreographed. Short, but interesting.

DIRTY HAIRY PEOPLE: A featurette which talks about the hair in the movie. Also short, but interesting

IT'S ENGLISH... SORT OF: This featurette talks about the use of the Scottish actors, the Scottish words and phrases used in the movie. Quite fun

ANGUS: About Merida's black horse, Angus and how to create the character.

THE TAPESTRY: About the tapestry that Queen Elinor makes in the film and how the creative team managed to create it.

Overall, "Brave" is hampered by some flaws and might be to conventional at times, but still makes a good movie to watch. It's easily one of the best animated movies yet on this decade.

I own all the classic Disney animated features, and I have a preference for the lushness of the painting in the 2D movies....think of the woods in Bambi, it's a beautiful work of art. However, with the right story, CGI films can certainly hold their own. Finding Nemo and the Toy Story films are great examples of superlative CGI films. Well, with Brave, the CGI technique has reached a high level. The background scenery of the Scottish Highlands, combined with the Celtic music score, drew me right into the atmosphere of medieval Scotland. And that most difficult of items to depict in CGI, hair and fur, was done magnificently. Watch the mane on Merida's horse, Angus, as it moves & flows while the horse runs...gorgeous! There was exhilaration in the gallops Merida & Angus took when she had a day free of lessons, and the will o' the wisps had a shimmery, magical quality. The first half of the movie had me captivated, although I did find the male characters drawn too broadly....all buffoons....with none of the subtlety of the female characters, especially the Queen. However, once the plot veered off into the changes Merida wrought on her mother, the Queen, I found the story to be far less interesting. It seemed to strain both credulity and logic, and the resolution of an ancient legend seemed confusing and tangential to the mother/daughter conflict. At least, that was my reaction during a first viewing of the film in a theater. However, on a 2nd viewing at home, I thoroughly enjoyed both halves of the movie. It made more sense, and I no longer had unrealistic expectations of what the movie would be like. I found it exciting, that it captured my attention throughout, and the storyline made sense. It was a departure for Pixar to have a female lead, and I applaud them for finally breaking away from their previously male-centric movies. Also, the female leads were just the right degree between the helpless princess and the pseudo-male wannabes like Mulan. They possessed that elusive, and eminently attractive, quality of strength combined with femininity.

So I had just finished watching Brave. I thought it was a very good movie...it's not on the same level as the classics, but I really enjoyed the story alot more than Tangled. I couldn't stand Flynn Ryder or hearing his cheesy monologues... it made me gag. I would even say the characters, story, and the songs were far better than the ones in Tangled. I personally think that Brave should have gotten Tangled's hype. I think Merida is a pretty underrated character/princess. I like how the movie teaches how one's own selfishness can lead to regrettable consequences. It's a story that follows Merida putting a spell on her mother to turn her into a bear just so she could find her way out of being in a an arranged marriage. In the end, Merida realizes how much her mother really loves and cares for her. Her mother even risked her own life to fight off the Mordu bear. She almost lost her mother because she just wanted to escape from being in an arranged marriage and find her own destiny. I could never do a thing like that to cause any bodily harm to my own mother..no matter how many arguments or differences we may have. I have to admit that I really cringe when Merida tries to poison her own mother by giving her a blueberry tart. That was just pure evil and sick. In a way, Merida reminds me of Mulan. Wanting do what the big boys do, defies her elder's wishes, and have things her own way. I really love how the story focuses more on the mother/daughter relationship. I think this would make a great upcoming Mother's Day gift and for anyone that had realized how much we take our own mothers for granted and should settled out whatever differences may arise.

I wasn't sure what to expect for Brave when I saw it in the theaters with the GamerFamily. I'd seen the brilliant trailer with the archery competition and knew that I'd have to take my son and daughter to this one. A brave, headstrong female lead in a Pixar film? Shut up and take our money!

Yes, the action was solid, the animation beautiful, the humor hit on every note. But the real story about what it means to be family was the one that got me. From the legend of the four brothers, we saw what a broken family could wreak on the world. I saw my teenage daughter reflected in Meridah's actions and words. Understanding, acceptance of changes, redemption... got it.

I won't argue that this is a well-animated, vibrant film, but what I found bothersome was the bratty star and how, once again, the tired formula of the rebellious teen disobeying the parents manifests.  What I find frustrating is how the protagonist defies her parents and there aren't any real clear resolutions or severe consequences.  Just a convoluted plot with a bear transformation.  Why no stories about the rebellious child that, due to their disobedience, falls into a real, life-threatening situation (you know, like real life?)  All of these headstrong, independent female Disney protagonists of recent decades just seem like a long, drawn out apology from Disney for making the character 'Snow  White', but to be honest, I'd watch that film a million times over before  wasting time watching Brave again.  Another note:  because of the  scary sequences and nudity, I would NOT recommend this for  small children.

This is a great movie for any age!  The princess is a tomboy who loves riding and archery and she's darn good at both.  When her parents tell her it's time to put those things aside and prepare to be a queen, she horror-struck and determined to show-up the princes who try to win a contest for her hand, which she does - easily.  Mom is reasonably upset, they argue and daughter runs off to the woods where she meets a witch who gives her a spell to 'change' mom's mind.  Only problem is, it doesn't change mom's *mind* but rather turns her into a bear.  When the princess realizes what's she's done, it's a race to find the cure before the spell becomes permanent.  How the two manage to resolve their differences and restore mom is a wonderful tale for parents and kids.  Probably one of the best Disney movies I've seen in a long time.

Just as an aside - the music is absolutely gorgeous and totally fits the Celtic setting.

From 1995 to 2004 Pixar ran up an unbelievable string of critical successes with each animated film receiving at least 92% aggregate score on Rotten Tomatoes and 77 out of 100 on Metacritic. Then came Cars which was financially successful but was recognized by many, myself included, as the weakest Pixar movie thus far. Pixar regained its mojo and rattled off another 4 winners before Cars 2 stunk up theaters. The following film, Brave, was the lowest rated Pixar film not featuring Cars in the title. That's not to say it was bad and it did win the 2012 Oscar for Best Animated Feature but some measure of Pixar magic seemed to be lost. It's also possible that Cars 2 was sufficiently bad that it knocked the luster off of Pixar and reviewers were primed for revenge.

There are a lot of films I've seen that are greater than the sum of their parts but Brave is the rare film that seems less than the sum of its parts because I cannot point to anything in the film that's bad. The animation is spectacular and somewhat of a technological breakthrough that Pixar was crowing about prior to the film's release. The breathtaking Scottish Highlands were the first thing I noticed having such an amazing level of detail and organic feel. The only weakness I saw was that character movements are still somewhat jerky and mechanical. I didn't have any issues with the story or the music and I can't think of any individual scenes that weren't well done so why is it when the whole thing is put together it feels so Un-Pixar like?

I've done a lot of thinking about this and I believe one big factor in the failure to connect is due to the darkness of the film. I don't mean the darkness of the plot because quite frankly I think that Up, The Incredibles and WALL-E were darker. It's the physical darkness of the film particularly in the second half of the film. Most of the film takes place in a Scottish castle, at night, lit only by torches on the walls. From the moment Merida leaves the castle after getting in an argument with her mom until right near then end there are almost no well-lit scenes. This is not me saying that this makes the film bad. This is me saying why I believe it didn't connect with a lot of people. On the technical side it is a magnificently crafted film but it lacks the joy of many of the other Pixar films. I would compare it to Wreck-It-Ralph which also came out in 2012 and many might say should have won the Oscar. Wreck-It-Ralph was inventive, bright and full of energy.

I've actually discovered that with each additional viewing I enjoy the film more. It is a great film and Brenda Chapmen who wrote and co-directed the film should be proud. It made well over $500 million worldwide which although a bit light for a Pixar film is still a fantastic take. I'm not into the whole Disney Princess thing being an adult male and all but Merida is probably the best, most believable Princess ever to be produced by Disney/Pixar. She is tough and strong but Chapman didn't go overboard as often happens with writers overcompensating for the farer gender. I suspect it's because Chapman IS female that she didn't feel the need to make Merida tougher than any male (except in archery). Sadly Brenda Chapman left Pixar before the film was completed carrying some bitterness with her. It took me about three viewings to REALLY get into the spirit of the film but I now consider it a great addition to the Pixar filmography. I hope Brenda gets the chance to write and direct more theatrical releases.
