I made the mistake of listening to the mothers on here who seem to think this is a good movie for girls.  I should've listened to the other reviews that said this movie isn't that great. The message of the movie ultimately is- do your feminine duty.  (even if that duty entails you getting married to someone you don't want to marry).  Um- this is the same message you can find spoonfed to women through the centuries.  It would've been different if Rubella STAYED rebellious throughout the movie, but toward the end Rubella DOES decide to go ahead with the marriage for the sake of duty "it was selfish of me not to see that this is what I had to do" she says. Selfish because her marriage is what would end the fighting. And this was the 'lesson' she learned when she 'grew up' in the movie.  And we see her mother look at her in fondness when she does this as if to say 'my little girl has finally grown up.' ugh.

 So she "learned" that a girl needs to sacrifice her own independence and dreams for the good of others.  It was only because her mother changed her mind that it didn't actually happen and Rubella didn't go through with it.  So in the end Rubella learned to do her duty and was just lucky that her mother changed her mind about forcing rape on her in marriage.  Just dandy. The idea of the female having a duty to sacrifice herself for the needs/wants of the family and of others is further pointed to by the fact that her brothers in the movie are not expected to do anything similar themselves.  Not to mention that while Rubella is rebelling against being forced towards marriage she is deemed as "immature" and unlady-like... and then when the story progresses and she finally decides to succumb to marriage she does not want is when the character is implied to have 'grown up' in some way.  Ridiculous!

I don't see this as that great for girls at all.  There are other animated female characters that are much more independent and don't learn this as a "lesson."  All in all, I think the animation and accents were really cute, but the story wasn't that great. And not just because of this women needing to be sacrificial lambs for the sake of the family idea... but the story was lacking in other ways.  It never goes into why the witch was obsessed with Bears or what happened to the prince's family (the one that turned into a bear)..  There are many interesting characters, but we don't get to learn much about them like with other disney films...  The story itself however is completely forgettable and not a healthy lesson for girls.  For strong female leads that don't succumb to this sexist 'lesson' that they need to do their female duties while the men do as they please stick instead with movies Like Mulan and The Princess and the Frog and skip this one.

Ok so maybe I'm a sap but this movie truly made me cry. Having a pre-teen and seeing this movie with her just hit a chord with me and I realized that soon, she's going to not need me so much. I love the fact that Disney finally came out with a "princess" movie that isn't about a girl being a victim. Merida is very in control of her world except for that pesky must get married thing. She's strong, knows her own mind, is willing to stand up for herself and her entire generation against an unfair tradition. This is the kind of role model I want for my daughter, rather than a girl scared in the woods, forced to be a maid, shut up in a tower and/or awakened by a kiss.

Usually, I don't like Pixar films because I find them shallow and insipid.  HOWEVER, there are the exceptions, for example the charming spy action spoof The Incredibles.
In Brave we find perhaps what was the inevitable use of Pixar technology in creating a Fantasy CGI film in the age of the MMORPG.  Right from the get go, Brave feels charming and mature.  We are introduced to Merida, a fiesty young woman who has more on her mind than childish activities and yet does everything possible to avoid growing up.  This of course leads to a conflict with her family, which is obsessed with marrying her off as soon as possible.
What ensues is what feels like a RAN inspired tale of the dangers of ripping your family apart.  Instead of tragedy though, Brave takes you on a dangerous quest to mend the tapestry of family.. with awesome action sequences that tease you with the notion of Gummi Bears returning.
Brave is a great film, it's mature, it's silly and it's the first Pixar movie I've seen that has a sense of dark, tense danger.  Merida is also a great character, she's not weak, she's charming and strong willed.
HIghly Recommended!

To animated film students and CG geeks in general, the geniuses responsible for the Pixar classics we know and love have become something of celebrities themselves.  John Lasseter, Brad Bird, Pete Docter, Andrew Stanton, these are the cornerstones of the Pixar ideology so when you encounter a feature film boasting the Pixar name; it seems odd when such names are absent.  Yet such is the case with Brave, Pixar's 2012 big budget action film that spent 6-years in development at a cost of $185-mil.

Though it wasn't overly apparent at the time, looking back 2012's Brave finds itself smack dab in the middle of a Disney animated heroine resonance (2010 saw Rapunzel take center stage in Tangled and 2013's Frozen centers on Elsa, princess of Arendelle).  And, despite nearly a century's worth of Disney experience with leading ladies (think all the 2D princesses throughout the years), Brave actually represents Pixar's first attempt with the concept.  How did they do you ask? The answer depends heavily upon who you ask.

Critics weren't overly generous with the film during its theatrical run, many going as far as to say that it continued in the lackluster tradition of the Pixar piece that preceded it: Cars 2.  It doesn't take much to realize that a lot of such criticism stems from the simple fact that Pixar has managed to raise the bar so ridiculously high in the 17-years' worth of releases separating the first Toy Story from Brave.  Were such criticisms justified with Brave?  Not entirely but let's first take a look at the plot summary.

Set in 10th century Scotland, we follow along on the exploits of one princess Merida (Kelly Macdonald), a redhead tomboy whose regal lifestyle is forever jeopardized when she receives a bow as an early birthday gift.  With aspirations of becoming the best archer in the kingdom replacing those of becoming the best possible wife in a parentally arranged (and politically-driven) marriage, Queen Elinor (Emma Thompson) is forced to watch helplessly as her rebellious daughter mounts her steed and flees into the wilds.  Here the strangely underdeveloped will-o-the-wisps lead her to the cottage of a witch just itching to cast some spells.

Of course if there's one thing we can take away from all Disney films it's that witches should definitely be one's last resort when it comes to the concept of problem-solving and Brave isn't about to break this tradition.  In fact, rather than grant Merida's wish with w a spell that could change her mother's mind about the whole marriage situation, the spell in question actually changes the queen into a bear!  Strange as this sounds, Merida's lovable but brain-cell limited father King Fergus (Billy Connolly) just so happens to have lost his leg in bear attack in the prologue; and hence is not the world's biggest fan of the creatures accordingly.

The king (and much of the village) are bent on slaughtering the bear, unaware that it is in fact their wife and queen respectively.  What results from this point forth is a lot of slapstick as bear Elinor knocks haphazardly about in structures and rooms too small for her newfound girth and does her best to communicate while remorseful Merida endeavors to reverse the spell.

If this all sounds rather un-Pixar-like; that's probably because it is.  In action the film definitely feels more like something we've come to expect from DreamWorks; which is to say entertaining, humorous, solid, and pretty.  However, until now, Pixar has separated itself from the competition with unrivaled cleverness.  It has been their concepts of observing and capturing the nuances of adult life and spinning them around a kid-friendly prose:  In short, something for all ages.  Brave however is a bit more forthright with its delivery and underlying message.  The humor beats certainly harken back to How to Train your Dragon with the brawling, uncouth behavior of the Scottish clans-folk (particularly the overly proportioned King Fergus, who is eerily reminiscent of Dragons' Stoic).

The visuals however are stunning.  Just when you think computer generated imagery has reached its peak, Pixar goes and develops a brand new hair simulator program that required 1,500 individual curl strands to be strung through with a flexible core not unlike the string of a beaded necklace, that allows the scarlet coils to bounce and brush against one another without unwinding.  The misty and green Scottish landscapes are lush and unbelievably intricate with rendered textures and elemental effects that positively dazzle.  Factor in a Patrick Doyle score and Julie Fowlis' Gaelic soundtrack and the environment almost makes up for what the depth in story lack... almost.

All in all Brave remains an entertaining 93-minutes with enough gusto to keep the little ones glued to the screen while adults marvel at the near-photorealistic textures laced throughout.  Had this one come from any of the other animation studios in the world, it most certainly would have earned unanimous praise.  Perhaps Pajib's Agent Bedhead said it best in his June 22, 2012 review of the film: "Brave is a pretty good movie. In fact, for a Dreamworks or Sony movie, it's outstanding. However, relative to the Pixar brand, Brave is merely OK."

Hi Everyone,
I'm writing this review a year late. I also had problems with the Brave Blu-ray disk. I read that many people using an L:G Blu-ray player experienced the same prob;em I had. I have a Toshiba Blu-ray player and had the same exact problem. I returned the set to the Disney store I purchased it at and was given a new set to try. The new set was no better than the first. The store manager was very surprised and gave me another one to try. I was very disappointed and quite amazed that three out of three had the same problem. Although the DVD from each set I tried worked and played through the whole movie with no trouble at all.

I had a similar experience with Cars 2. The Blu-ray disk from the combo set had some type of a virus. No sooner than it began to play my virus detection software alerted me of a virus. I returned it to the store and tried another copy. Both copies of Cars 2 had the very same proble. I gave up, returned it to the store and bought the DVD and had no problems with it.

Since these experiences, I no longer purchase Disney Blu-ray disks or combo sets. The DVD's play just fine in my computer and Toshiba Ble-ray player. Furthermore, I have never notice much difference between Disney Blu-ray or DVD's and I have a 50 inch Panasonic Plasma Smart screen TV. Now I save my hard earned money by purchasing only Disney DVD's for my little princess. I recommend advice this to everyone reading my review!!!!

I entered this movie assuming it would be another story about a princess who is saved by Prince Charming and then she falls madly in love with him and feel obligated to love him because he saved her. I don't have anything against those stories, but they aren't the only stories in the world.

I actually was delighted when I found out this was a story not about falling in love, but about saving one's self. Merida didn't need someone to save her, she was stronger then all the men in the area. She didn't need a prince to swoop in at the last second and slay the beast, nor did she need a man to inspire her to save the day. Merida could save herself.

I felt like Merida was an inspiration to girls all over the world. She is proof that you don't need a prince charming, that they are just a perk to life and that no one, not even them, gets to choose who you love.

If you own an LG Blu-Ray player, then you will have to update your firmware after buying this disc otherwise it will freeze and shut off your player at the 5:12 min mark in the movie. This is another wonderfully made movie from Pixar/Disney. The animation is outstanding, the actors picked for voices are well known and do an outstanding job, but the story is so weak as to make the movie trivial. The plot centers around a tomboy princess who wants to have her own identity and follow her own desires and of course her own life. This is a good opening, but the story degenerates into a farce about a magic potion that turns her mother into a bear, and the resultant senseless chaos. The only forceful, believable characters in the story are the protagonist (Merida, the Princess) and her mother,(Elinor the Queen). Every single man in the story is portrayed as a buffoon and/or vulgar slob, including her father. Who was Merida ever going to marry? None of the men in the entire kingdom are worthy of even a first glance. The craziness of her mother being bewitched goes on too long, and the moviegoer feels only relief when Elinor finally is returned to her own form. Masterfully done by the best animation house in the world, but could have been a much better movie with a stronger plot and a more profound story.

It's a cute story and good to see strong female roles.  However, I never appreciate stories that make men look foolish in contrast to the strong women. Brave is a 2012 Disney DVD of the critically-acclaimed PIXAR animated adventure and introduces to the world the newest addition of the Disney Princesses, Merida! Kelly MacDonald provides the voice of Merida in this tale of courage as Merida is being planned by her mother, Queen Elinor(Emma Thompson)to be married, but Merida believes she should get betrothed on her own terms. Feeling bothered by her mother's choices of suitors, Merida seek advice from a old witch, but what she did not know that the witch had turned Elinor into a bear trough a curse, and Merida now must get her mom, and her little triplet brothers back to normal. The special features includes two PIXAR short films, The Legend Of Mordu and La Luna, as well as sneak peeks of other Disney DVD favorites like Sofia The First and Finding Nemo 3D. Brave is the perfect addition to any Disney DVD collection and the great way for everyone to get to know Merida, the first Disney/PIXAR Princess!

I was excited about this movie because the animation seemed brilliant and cutting-edge & Scottish culture is very colorful & interesting-- so I bought it in HD for $20.  The visuals & computer graphics did not disappoint-- Walt Disney would be awestruck and ecstatic if he could see what the industry can do these days--No doubt. But I believe he would have had the writers work on the storyline a bit more before releasing this to the public.  It was a nice idea -- I'm sure that every mother & daughter would be able to recognize themselves in this tale of Merida and her queen mom-with-nagging-high-expectations.  And, yes, when rifts and disagreements occur as a result of youthful pride and stubborn ego a mother figure can become, at least in the eyes of her daughter, a scary giant bear--who can be threatening & monstrous towards her girl --as well as more protective of her baby than any other natural force in the living world--- I completely get the metaphor and it had so much potential to resonate more with people than it actually did.  But somehow, the metaphor in its beginning is strained and carries little momentum.  There seem to be few apparent parallels between the Queen and her enchanted persona.  Perhaps this could have been fixed by making her more "bear-like" before the transformation-but it would be difficult to do this and still have her be likable.  So as it stands for most of the film, there is very little to make us believe that the Queen is really inside of this bear-and it's somewhat horrifying to think that her husband is getting ready to slay his wife b/c of mistaken identity.  The story is redeemed in the one scene when Merida believes that she has failed to break the spell that holds her mother captive.  She waits for the bear to transform back to her mother -and she is crushed when it does not occur as she had hoped.  She is humbled and can only hopelessly cling to her mother's side -wishing her back to who she once was.  This scene was masterfully done and rightfully brings the audience to tears.  Almost as fulfilling as the classic scene from "Dumbo" where his mother reaches thru the bars of the carnival cage with her trunk to be with him as much as she is able to.  C'mon Disney-Pixar -- don't be distracted/overwhelmed by your own visuals-- make sure the story is refined and fleshed out as much as possible before takeoff.

It's not that this movie is bad, I just find it too questionable. What exactly was Pixar trying to get across in this film? The characters say something about changing their fates, but no one knows what their fate will be. We can only change our fates when we know them, or at least sometime we can. The accents...don't exactly help. And the story is just a little dissapointing. I was hoping this would be a "Mulan" kind of story where Merida goes into a war, or she could go on a quest, but instead we get...turning her mother into a bear. Yeah, bears are not exactly that interesting, and they let Pixar throw away a great opportunity for a film set in medieval Scotland. Also, the villain is yet another ferocious animal, with no actual evil plot. Yeah, villains who are downplayed like this just don't fascinate me very well. I mean there are some good things about this film, particularly the triplet brothers. They may not speak, but their comical actions speak loud enough. Also, I guess it is rare to see a strained relationship with a mother. It's usually the father whom the main characters argue with. Was this movie meant to teach a lesson to mothers and daughters? Eh, possibly. Merida's design is not that beautiful and I feel as though she's the black sheep of the Disney Princesses. SHe just doesn't do anything that remarkable. I am DREADING a bunch of complaints from my sister when she figures THAT out. I'd say the only time I felt annoyed at this film was when it won the Academy Award for Best ANimated Film instead of "Wreck-It Ralph" which I thought told a better story and should have been a Pixar film. I guess this film is okay for what is is, but I would still like to see something a little stronger.

Disney should definitely be applauded for trying to break the mould and make a movie centered around a girl. Unfortunately, it quickly degenerates into a moral story of how parents and children should behave with each other and what happens when the latter don't!

The movie starts promisingly, with the protagonist, depicted to be a free spirit. Unfortunately, within no time, she behaves like an idiot (surprising considering she is shown behaving very adult-like a few minutes ago) and ends up turning her mother into a bear.

From this point onwards, the movie degenerates into a mother-daughter bonding tale and the mother gets more focus than the daughter.

While watching this movie, I continued to sense that something was missing...towards the end, I realized that inspite of its title, the movie lacked real bravery of any sort...

The story takes special care to set up the mother as a monster, and then they turn her into one.  As far as the term `brave' being applied to a girl who is simply fighting for respect and acknowledgement of her own merits against the tyrannical ravings of an overbearing mother who clearly rules the kingdom instead of the permissive caring father/king.......  I'm not certain what I watched was a demonstration of bravery as opposed to squirming out of a mess of her own making.  Merida is a girl who wants to go her own way and when given two grand opportunities to escape, she does just the opposite.  Instead of fleeing for her life, she resorts to trickery to get her mother to see things her way.  She finds a means of finally making her mother shut up and listen, only to have precious little to say to the woman/bear other than they need to find a means of getting out of the trouble she caused.  The fact that the mother/queen has a belated epiphany where her daughter is concerned might have more to do with the desperation to return to her normal form and not angering the only person who might be able to do just that.

This movie is loaded with mixed messages.  They barely skirted around the issue of servitude through an arranged marriage to a total stranger.  And what about blind obedience that only serves the person making all the orders/demands?  The same person who charges, "we can't run away from who we are."  Who we are, or what someone else wants us to be?  As for celebrating Pixar's first strong female character, I found it incredibly odd that there was a curious lack of female characters in the first place, strong or otherwise.  There was just the domineering mother, the less than dutiful daughter, a wacky witch, and for comic relief a nanny of sorts.  Why?  In this fantasy, were women supposed to be barely seen and never heard?  Evidently, this was a matriarchal society, run by an iron-willed woman, why weren't more women involved in the story?

Not my favorite Pixar movie by a long shot.  But.  All the characters save one were fantastic, the art work was spectacular (but fared better on the theater screen than a small screen TV), loads of good humor, some excitement, it's a keeper but not a movie I will watch all that often.

As for the viewing problems noted above, I have an older LG Blu-ray player and both the DVD and the Blu-ray disks played just fine in it.

For those of you who don't know, Stephen Colbert is a hilarious fellow who runs his own political/comedy show, called "The Colbert Report" on Comedy Central. Among Colbert's more humorous quirks is an all-consuming, quite irrational fear of bears. He seems to believe they are out to get him at every opportunity, and that they may very well be bent on conquering the world itself. As such, he would probably soil his shorts by watching "Brave", as this movie is chock-full of bears... most of which are adorable, but some of which are quite scary.

If you share Colbert's weird fear of bears, steer clear of "Brave", for it will undoubtedly give you night terrors for a solid fortnight. Personally, I think bears are awesome, and Pixar's rendering of them in this beautifully animated movie is nothing short of breathtaking. The other elements of animation are likewise up to the studio's industry-leading standards, and this movie is just as visually impressive as anything else in their formidable stable. These guys can create vibrant, immersing worlds like nobody else.

The story, while somewhat simplistic, is also great. At first, I was a bit hesitant as the plot began to unfurl, as I feel that the "angst-ridden teenager whom nobody understands" theme has been ridden to death, and I couldn't believe that Pixar would go down that road. However, I was happy to see that the movie soon took on unexpected twists and turns, and delivers an exciting, heart warming tale that even Stephen Colbert would enjoy (should he be able to look past the scary bears). "Brave" is highly recommended for viewers of all ages, and makes for a great movie for parents to share with their lil' ones.
What little girl wouldn't want to be her? Great story with a bit of a stretch on the mother bear.

Typical mother/daughter coming of age angst.
Nice to have a mother AND a father in a loving relationship.
The animation is great, storyline easy to follow.
Great price for all these discs and the movie itself is phenomnal.  I'm glad they thought out of the box for this one.

I admittedly had high expectations for this film, as I love all things with a Celtic flavor, and the story of a spirited little girl appealed to me.  It starts out nice, setting up the theme of changing one's fate and Merida's attempts to do so are fun to watch.

But the story I think gets a bit off-center once the witch enters the picture.  It struck me as undermining the whole message that she needed magic to essentially change the rules and get herself out of her current situation, rather than finding a clever way to do so on her own.  Is she really changing her fate in that case, or is some mystical force doing so that we couldn't possibly call on in real life?  What sort of message does that send?

I was also expecting the antagonist of the film to take more of a center-stage in things... possibly even being a love-interest, ala Beauty and the Beast.  That is one time where magic would have been acceptable - to counteract previous magic.  But this doesn't pan out, either.

What we get here is a perhaps-touching film about family values when we really could of had a strong leading female changing her fate through the sheer force of her will.  While the film as it is is certainly enjoyable in its own right, the latter would have perhaps made a more powerful, poignant film.  I can still recommend it, but not as strongly as I might have.
This is a great product, exactly what the description states. I am satisfied with my purchase. I would highly recommend it.
I love the disney and animation movies and am very happy to have added this movie to my collection.  I hope to share this with my daughter and granddaughter some day.

I just wish Disney had made more strong female characters when I was young. The story was well done and the animation was great. The characters were so good. All age groups will like this.

"If you had a chance to change your fate, would you?"

Pixar is one of the very few reliable film companies out there. And by reliable, I mean that you know exactly what you've signed up for, what to expect and it is always delivered. Walking into a Pixar is like going to an amusement park. You've been on the rides before, you've learned the layout pretty easily and what there is to see, but 20 years later you still have a blast.

Brave is a little different from other Pixar films in the sense that not everybody can relate to the characters and plot. The theme of the film is deeply grounded in a study of free agency and the power that individuals have to make up their own lives and futures, but at the surface it's simply the story of a girl and her mother trying to see eye-to-eye. This is very well done but no matter what experiences I have in my life, I will never understand what it is to have a mother/daughter relationship. The emotion is there, the humor and desire for conciliation as well, but being a man...well, all I can do when coming out of the theater is smile and say "That was nice."

Despite this major element of the plot, there are many other things that can be learned and appreciated from this film. As mentioned above, free agency is a big part of the story along with its friends, the great theories on nature vs. nurture. To top it off, throw in a dash of unconditional love, then contemplate the effects of hasty or impulse decision-making and blend it all with both the fear of the unknown and the courage - or bravery - to take it on. Serve while warm and you've got yourself a pretty successful dish. Say one thing for PG films, say that they've got a message to share.

Where Brave is lacking compared to its compatriots - Up, Wall-E, Monsters Inc and others - is in scope. The setting was small, taking place inside a castle and its surrounding the entire time. Characters never seemed to travel more than an hour away from this central location. The turn-around of main events was also very short, most plot points being resolved within minutes. The bulk of the film must have taken place in about 3 days timeline. It just seems to me that the types of challenges that were being faced by the characters might have taken more effort to resolve. I wish there had been more time and vision spent on actually getting the characters to interact with each other.

The film was a bit clich at times, but what do you expect from a kids film? They thrive on clich, so no real complaints there. Graphically speaking, Pixar technology basically leads the industry and Brave is pretty much visually stunning. From the feathers on the ends of arrows, to the curls in Merida's hair, to the flow of water in streams, the vision they are able to convey onto the screen in nothing short of jaw-dropping. Solid - though not outstanding - soundtrack and great vocal performances. I found myself easily slipping into this world, almost to the point of forgetting it was CGI. Not quite, but almost and I know the day is almost here.

I need to mention one more thing that I truly appreciated about this film and that was being shown a child and parent willing to fight for each other to the very end and no matter what. In a world as crazy as our own, it is easy to forget that we have people on our side and who are willing to do whatever it takes to protect and maintain us. Equally, it is easy to forget that those same people are not invincible and could use no less from us than what they are giving. Brave wove this into the tapestry of the film beautifully and - whether or not it was intentional - I found myself deeply moved by this aspect of the film.

Brave is not the best of the lot - it's no Up - but on a scale from lame to amazing it's quite good. I was overall pleased with my experience and would definitely recommend it to anybody looking for simple and clean family fun. There are a few moments were the humor was pushed close to the limit of appropriate for your five-year old, but these were pretty sparse.  Take it all in with a grain of salt and you'll be sure to walk away from those ending credits feeling warm and fuzzy inside.

P.S. The Pixar Short that runs before the film, La Luna, is a masterpiece that deserves awards. Absolutely fabulous, I could write a whole review on those five minutes alone. Go see Brave just for this short film if you must, it would be worth it.
I just love a good Hero's journey tale.  And Pixar really knows how to stimulate the eye when it comes to scenery and digital animation style.  What a deal!

With a Scottish setting, stunning visuals and a stirring soundtrack this movie promises much and things get off to a splendid start... but then the writers bring in that ridiculous spell which turns Merida's mother into a... bear?!?! This is where the movie starts losing the plot. I couldn't believe my eyes. From this point on I would sit there shaking my head - what on earth were the writers thinking??

Merida's mother was a strong character who exuded regal charisma. What possessed the writers to turn her into a bear?? Her bear mannerisms and Merida's interaction with her... good grief. It was such a waste of a pivotal character. If that wasn't enough Merida's three little brothers turn into bears as well!

Merida's character came across as a little bratty at times but not to the extent, in my opinion, that other reviewers have made it out to be. I personally liked her character a lot: spirited, strong, independent, yet with plenty of heart. In saying that however some of her dialogue towards her mother was over the top and totally uncalled for (eg 'You're a beast. I'd rather die than be like you!'). Gotta love that big mane of red hair though.

'Brave' certainly does have plenty of strong scenes (my absolute favorite being the one accompanied by the song 'Touch The Sky' - this scene gives me goosebumps every time I re-watch it) but the whole 'bear spell' storyline was just plain stupid.

I was hoping that 'Brave' was going to be more grounded in some sense of reality and history, as to opposed the over-worn hocus pocus themes that seem to permeate animations. And how Merida's use of a spell to change her mother is to be considered brave is beyond me. I do re-watch the movie to purely enjoy the Scottish setting - however very rarely will I watch beyond the bear transformation scene (about 38 minutes into the story) - the movie seriously loses the plot from that moment on and is painful to watch, especially when up to that point it's terrific viewing.

All in all this movie was well made, however it easily had the potential to have been so much more, had it not been for the ridiculous 'bear spell' storyline. I just hope the writers are brave enough to admit that they dropped the ball here with that idea and will seek to make amends for any sequels.
This Blu-Ray/DVD combo was the greatest and at the perfect price.  We all enjoyed it and it played perfectly and the box was in great conditon exactly as described.

I highly recommend this if you want light-hearted, well meaning characters who are maybe just slightly mis-led in their thinking (sounds like Craig himself, God love him!!!), there's a funny, awkward, could go really bad-sort of conflict. and then a happy resolution, with several sub-plots.....I GOT A KICK OUT OF IT!!  It is delightful, funny, and did I say light hearted?
You understand this is probably a "chic flick" and fits into the " whimsical" category. But it's fun!

If you're a snob, or like Craig says, "the troll that lives under the bridge" don't get it. It might make you laugh, and you might
not want to do that!!!!!!

If you need a good laugh, you like Celtic things, and you're looking for something to entertain you, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND
IT.
Disclaimer:  You might not like it if you are a Scottish male, and you're REALLY impressed with yourself, and believe all of
your own "press" releases about yourself!!!! LOL!!!!

I watch Disney with my grand-children. twenty years ago, I watched Disney with my children.  Thirty years ago, I watched Disney with kids I baby sat.  Before that and in between, I watched for myself.  I love the Disney Pixar, they just keep getting better and better.  This is my kind of princess.

I like most Pixar movies and this is one of them.  Great acting and wonderful graphics.  My wife and her friend don't like it as much as I do.  I like the story and get caught up in the drama each time.  The two extra small features are great too, especially the "La Luna", really love that one.  I like the commentaries, but wish that commentaries would actually follow the feature film scene by scene instead getting caught up in rambling stories.  The commentators gave some really good insights to the backstory but they too got caught up in the going on too long while the film was unfolding. I was expecting the standard Disney princess film with this film. I was pleasantly surprised to see that they used this film to illustrate the mother/daughter bond. I ws so glad that this Movie won best animation last year, and it deserved it,

The whole thing takes place in Scotland years ago.

I can't begin to say how pleasantly surprised I was by Disney/Pixar's newest feature. The mess of Cars 2 significantly brought down the mean quality of their films, so going into Brave I expected something equally lumpy.

What I found, however, was an extraordinary and very original post-modern fairy tale. It is a solid balance of humor with the emotional weight Pixar has recently become notorious for (cough Up and Toy Story 3). Furthermore, by placing the setting in a semi-historical context, the story gains a much heavier sense of importance and meaning.

Pixar's recent foray into more mature work also makes the stakes much higher for each new film. Their marketing team did a solid job of not revealing many plot details (the commercials just hit the tip of the iceberg), so the plot details are genuinely surprising. The main plot has not even been addressed in any of the advertisements I've seen.

I had my doubts going into it, but Brave turned out to be a very different and far superior movie than I was expecting. Don't fight it just because it looks like Mulan or other girl-power fare. Brave is its own film that can stand proudly in the already-solid Pixar canon.
This movie was alright, but it was not the best movie I have ever watched maybe not worth the full rental price.

I really was not expecting much from this movie, but it turned out to be a great story that not only held the interest of my 3 year old twins, it held my interest as well. Again, another movie I bought as a digital download from Amazon, so no more scratched DVD's or Blu Rays!

The movie was received new as advertised. The shipping time was also as advertised but did take the entire 7 days to receive. It made me nervous because it was a gift and was shipped directly to the recipient while visiting a third party. I was worried the movie would arrive after my daughter had left to go back to her home but it got there on the last day.

Great movie, nice 3D effects lovely full HD details and the sound it is so realistic, nice packaging, fully recommended
For lover's of the fabulous animation being done these days, this movie is on top of that world. AND, the storyline is pretty good, too, although you must have a great sense of fantacy in you.

Sure you could probably like the dad if you don't mind that he is a mindless buffoon. And some might find the sons funny, however, I just saw them as a waste of space and I think they actually confused my daughter. There is almost something redeeming about the mother/daughter relationship off and on. It gets pretty muddy and the resolution is a none event.

It is hard to fault Pixar and their work since they have set the standard for the industry. The story, however, takes the prize as a super story for young girls to enjoy and see themselves in the story line. Merida is a great character since she portrays more real-life situations and reactions than a whole host of other stories that attempt to address the same scope of emotions. We all enjoyed it!

Disney/Pixar really hit the mark on this one. The main character shares a lot more true-to-life qualities with growing up that many past princess characters; she's rebellious to the point of not only going against her mother's wishes, but trying to subvert them completely. But she loves her family dearly all the same, and the bond runs deep through all that happens. Seeing a child's deep love and caring towards a parent whose rules they also so desperately wish to escape from is a very different motif for a Disney princess story. I found it heartwarming on so many different levels. The fear, the bravery, the sacrifices, and the strengthening of their loving bond through their tribulations are all wonderful and relatable parts of the story for any parent and their growing (or grown!) child. The lesson of mutual respect between a parent and child is a wonderful reminder of this constant challenge to both real-life counterparts as they watch this movie, as well.

As others have stated, this movie does have some fairly scary scenes involving animals. Many people use the term "intense," which they are, but to be perfectly blunt - they're scary. As a small child, I would have had bad dreams involving them, but I also clung to imagery in movies very tightly and had an overactive imagination. If in doubt, watch the movie by yourself first, or search online for a synopsis or video of just the scary scenes if you don't want to spoil getting to watch the whole movie together for the first time with your child. It's not "Nightmare on Elm Street" or anything - it's just good to be aware of the scenes if you have a child you know gets frightened easily.

As for the physical disc itself, the presentation is very nice. I like the lenticular slip cover that goes over the disc case, though it is prone to the corners getting a little bent after removing and reinserting the blu-ray case a few times, as it's a pretty tight fit. I do appreciate that unlike a lot of multi-disc sets, the discs aren't stacked on top of each other in this package. Each one is one its own little spindle so you can get to whichever disc you want without having to remove a bunch of others first. The bonus features are also really enjoyable, and this movie looks great in 3D! A wonderful package to buy if you'd like to get the complete set of viewing options (we used the 3D blu-ray as a special "movie night" treat, the standard blu-ray for normal "let's pop in a movie" type viewing, and the DVD for playing in the car during road trips).

Brave(2012) is a solid, well-made Disney-Pixar movie. It's packed with side-splitting gags and a convincing, colorful 16 year old heroine. Kelly MacDonald is the voice of the red headed, blue eyed Princess Merida. Merida has to repair the damage after her mother is turned into a bear by a witch's spell! The story takes place in a mythical Scotland. Brave took Pixar 4-5 years to make. This CG animated film is packed with crisp, visually stunning images. There's action and a little drama and pathos. There's funny moments such as a horse slapping Merida's face with its tail. Brave is worth owning on Blu Ray and DVD.

Didn't mess with the heroine's looks as they planned to do! An online petition made sure that Merida would be faithful to the author's depiction of her princess. It is a great story and one that shows that girls and women can, in today's society, depend on themselves to solve their problems if they so wish.

I highly recommend this movie.
This is a wonderful mother/daughter story. It's also a story about how the choices we make affect others and things don't always turn out as we think they will.

Pixar has a good reputation for a reason, they make good stuff.  This time around they tackle the whole Mother vs Daughter relationship that always seems to happen.  The characters are fun a pacing is quick enough to keep the kids entertained but it lags at a few parts to add to all those story bits that the grownups that are watching it with the kiddos will enjoy as well.  Note I didn't save have to watch as it is a good movie on its own merits and I don't have any little ones to watch it with.  I am not sure if I would put this on for background noise as quick as I might any of the Toy Stories or the Incredibles, but a good movie for sure.
Just another wonderful movie for kids and adults. They all have a wonderful story. I don't remember how many times we have watched it.
My wife and my 6 year old daughter both though it was great. So I plan to watch it too.
This is a really cute movie.  Great graphics and very entertaining.  All ages will enjoy this movie.  It was good having a young woman as the hero.

This is an addition to my original review (below).

After viewing this film for a third time, I finally determined where the real fault lies in the story.  Merida (the princess) wants to change tradition (i.e., her marriage to the winner of a contest).  But the problem is, she does absolutely nothing to earn the RIGHT to challenge the tradition.  That is, Merida does not place her own personal safety at stake, nor does she redeem anyone by taking her position (e.g., by personally saving the soul of the ghost-bear prince).  If she had placed her own interests at risk, or accomplished something grand or noble by taking her position, then she would have earned the right to challenge tradition.  But ... she did nothing.  Rather, it was her mother (Elinor) who changed.  In short, the ostensible heroine of the story (i.e., Merida) did nothing meritorious - she was only "brave" in being a defiant child.  And what lesson does that teach?

My original review:

With over 2000 reviews written thus far, it's unlikely that anyone will read my review.  Notwithstanding, here I go.

First of all, let me say that the animation is superb - what Pixar has done in the way of animating hair and water is simply amazing.  The forest scenes in the early part of the film are works of art.

Now, to my major problems with the film.  Yes, I understand that the "moral" of the story is about being brave in choosing and pursuing your own destiny.  What I simply don't get is why the mother (Elinor) underwent such a radical change in personality (going over to accept her daughter's views) merely as a result of her transformation to a bear.  There was simply nothing in the mother's experience as a bear which would explain this transformation of personality.  Yes, there is the whole "fish" scene, and the "rescue from the evil bear" scene, but I just don't see why either experience should convince the mother that she was wrong in her views, and that her daughter (Merida) was right.  Plus, it does not seem that any lesson was learned by Merida, the ostensible heroine of the story (a major shortfall in story telling).  In fact, it seems to me that the story is more about the mother (Elinor), and what she learned as a result of her experiences.  But, as said, the story falls short to that end.  Plus, there is the whole confusing thread of "legends are lessons" - what lesson was learned by whom and as a result of the story told?  Merida did not save her mother - it was the mother who saved herself from the "evil bear".  So, in my opinion, not good story telling.

John Lassiter (the father of Pixar) is on record as being a great admirer of the films of Hayao Miyazaki (as am I).  In Brave Lassiter attempts to create a "young heroine" story line, perhaps along the lines of Miyazaki's Spirited Away, or Nausica of the Valley of the Wind.  But Lassiter falls short in Brave.  That is, the ostensible heroine of Brave (i.e., Merida) does not place her own life at risk in order to save those whom she loves (or for a greater ideal).  In Brave, Merida's greatest contribution to the salvation of her mother is merely placing the stitched-together tapestry over her mother.  It was not Merida who saved the day, but rather her mother, Elinor.  So what lesson is to be learned from this film?  Nothing, so far as I can discern.  Merida (the daughter) did not "save the day", and Elinor (the mother) underwent a transformation in personality with no satisfactory explanation as to why that occurred.  In the end, a confusing story line as to what was learned by who, and why.
I loved it.  Great adventure, and per the name of the movie, she is Brave.  Would watch again and again.

First off, the animation quality in this movie is absolutely beautiful.  Just watching how Merida's (the main female character) long curly red hair moves in a wonder in and of itself.  Animation is just getting better and better.

As are the plots for many animation movies.  I didn't see this movie in the theatre, a decision which I now regret.  But I sat down to watch it based on the idea of a main female protagonist and with a love of all things Scottish.  I was not disappointed.  The humor was great, if crude at times, and the Scots characters covered a spectrum as displayed by the different virtues and vices of each clan.

Merida is a princess and is expected to wed one of the three sons of the other three clans.  Her own father is head of the fourth clan, and she discovers a clause so that she can "fight" for her own hand and takes part in the contests.  Of course, she is a wild girl who can ride, hunt, and shoot with the best and resents her much more dignified and formal mother's attempts to make a real "lady" out of her.  She resists what she sees as her Fate and so discovers that the question about Princess vs Rebel was never so far apart as she first thought.

This is a real mother-daughter picture, one that brings the two together as they fight to overcome the results of a badly-chosen spell.  In-between the funny scenes, we see how they each learn to really see each other, rather than their expectations of each other.

The movie has many elements (especially how people speak) woven into the (somewhat) more historical ones, so it will appeal to a modern audience.  Fortunately, it isn't too distracting.  There is enough action that most kids won't get too bored, but I would recommend this movie more for 8 year olds and up than any younger ones.  Highly recommended for young teen girls, the reasons for which will be obvious if you watch the movie.

As Pixar's first fairy tale and its first "princess" movie, I was very curious to see what they'd come up with. Would Brave's Merida be a traditional princess in the Disney mold, or a more modern girl?

Well, it's the latter, thankfully. Merida is a great character and role model for girls (and boys, really) who are struggling between respecting their parents and growing into their own person.

This isn't at all a story about a girl who a) needs rescuing, or b) falls helplessly in love. If anything, it's a love story about the complicated relationship between mothers and daughters. It's also about duty versus personal freedom.

Merida is the kind of girl who doesn't wait around to be rescued. When the situation warrants, she rescues herself. Good for Pixar. A great movie!

Arguably no institution has greater power to shape and mold public opinion than mass media organizations like Disney.  They claim to simply respond to public tastes, but they usually twist and turn those tastes to suit their own objectives.  Their influence is hard to see, since they start early, shaping our minds when we are yet youngsters.  Pixar's Brave is a case in point.

Promoted as a hip, feminist fairy tale, Brave tells the story of Merida, a Scottish princess required to marry a prince from a rival clan in order to quell the potential for war.  Merida sports the most violently blow-dried mop of red hair since Nicole Kidman's Aussie youth.  The princes vying for Merida's hand - like all male characters in the film - are portrayed as oafish losers.  Merida seems justified when claiming the right as a first-born noble to "champion herself."  In Zena-like fashion, she is quite the waifish warrior, capable of outmatching the males at all martial arts.

Most of the film deals with Merida's conflict with her mother; she defies the Queen's wishes to submit to an arranged marriage.  A magical spell causes Merida's mother to transform into a beast.  The girl must reconcile with her mother before the change becomes permanent.

The subtext of the story involves how females suffer from the burdens of obligations they bear due to men.  Like many popular entertainments, Brave characterizes females as almost a separate species from males, possessing insight and sensitivity that the barely-sentient masculine sex lacks.  The last time we saw a wave of similarly-themed entertainment was during the feminist revolution of the early Seventies.  In both cases, the true conflict was not between the sexes but between employers and workers.  In the 2000's the public is saturated with stories about female empowerment, but really it is a justification for an employer's power to hire cheaper female workers, firing men en masse.  Brave is an attempt to reconcile children to this social norm, even before they develop the power to decide for themselves what those norms should be.  In the end, Brave is a sinister agent for a brave new world.

Has a way of not doing the expected. Young Merida is the headstrong daughter of the feisty Scottish King Fergus and the equally strong but more quiet Queen Elinor, and loves both with all her heart, but as a princess, finds her duties to be a royal pain in the tush. Elinor is grooming her to royal duties, but Merida sees the inequality of her life as she has three smaller brothers who can almost get away with anything and are not facing the duties she must. In what little time she has to herself. she can be found outside the castle walls, riding her horse and practicing her archery, her favorite hobby. It is when she discovers she has been, literally put up for betrothal to the winner in a contest between three clans that the war with her mother actually begins as she has no desire to be married at all unless she can choose for herself, and none of the three clans offer much hope for a good match. Merida then takes matters into her own hands when she enters the contest to win her own hand sparking a raging argument with her mother which sees her flying off alone in tears. Willo the wisps enter the picture to lead her to an old witch's cottage where she pays the witch to cast a spell to change her fate. It changes more than that. It turns her mother into a bear and binds both her and her mother to an older fate when she finds she must not only seek a way to change her mother back, but protect her from her father who is seeking to kill what he believes is a legendary monster. Worse, both must contend with the monster, who is not only legendary, but alive. Merida must fight her father while Elinor takes on the powerful creature to save her daughter. How does it end? You'll have to see. I love this because it doesn't fall into the usual fairytale rule of Prince marrying the princess and living happily ever after. This is a tale of a headstrong powerful girl changing her fate and herself, seeking more from life than to be a prize for a contest and the dutiful quiet wife of a winner she doesn't even know. She is seeking the freedom to choose for herself what she wants and must be brave to not only find what she wants, but to correct her mistakes and protect her family as well as she might. This is an odd tale, but a great one!

Who doesn't love a good princess movie?  I mean, if you have children, or more specifically if you have daughters, then princess movies circulate your DVD player on an almost constant, and so you really do hope and pray and a good one comes along.  There are so many of them.  Pixar, the same studio behind great animated films like `Up' and `Toy Story' has never ventured into princess territory, and so when `Brave' was announced the internet (and every attentive parent) got their hopes up for this to actually be something special.

In parts, this really is, but in other parts it is kind of the same.

I think where `Brave' differs from almost every single other princess movie is that the protagonist is actually fighting AGAINST the idea of finding a prince charming.  It may have a lot to do with what she is offered (laughable at best) but the idea that she is more of a tomboy seeking her right to be herself and express herself freely, and without tradition barking in her ear, is a nice touch.  It's not like that same sentiment hasn't been expressed before.  Disney films like `Pocahontas' and `Mulan' display similarly strong-willed women fighting against the traditions of their people, but `Brave' takes it a step further by eliminating the desire to find Mr. Right.  Sadly, the overall construction of `Brave' doesn't steer too far from the set course.  It follows a similar story outline and so, by the time the film has ended, it does feel like an exercise in the same.

The visuals are lush, and the moral of communication and compromise are nice assets to the films progression.  Folklore is such a fun and spirited way of telling a story, although I will say that many of the films plot points felt a tad lazy in construction.  Really, another witch?  Another potion?  Can't we do better than that?  The film is heartwarming and presents a meaningful message, especially for families since it stresses the importance of realty listening to one another.

At the end of the day, my daughters love this (obviously) but I'm not entirely sold on the finished product.  Maybe it's because I expected more from the same studio that found such inspired ways to address so many mature themes (growing up via `Toy Story 3', mourning and loss via `Up', parenthood and balance via `Finding Nemo').  I wanted this to be something special, something amazing.  It was good, but lacked greatness.

This was disappointing. It might be the dumbest story I've seen in a long time. Nothing heroic, nothing inspiring, nothing adventurous, & outside of the first 5-10 minutes... nothing entertaining. Also not sure what the title "BRAVE" had to do with anything with the story line or main character. The lead character didn't do anything "BRAVE" once the story started. As for the settings & locations (in which an animated feature could transport you anywhere your imagination takes you)... yet the entire movie actually took place in about 2 locations; the modest castle & a small section of the forest. Once again there was no imagination.

Even the supporting characters were lacking. The witch (who was pivotal to the story twist) was dumb, one dimensional, the character was not fleshed out, had no originality & outside of 5 minutes the witch had no further involvement in the entire movie. The main villain of the whole story line had very little background ... we didn't know anything about "him" even during the conclusion. The whole plot revolved around turning the mother into a Bear?? The only thing more absurd, was how "the Bear" interacted with the daughter. It was clumsy, and a head shaker. The moment that happened & I realized that dynamic is what the whole plot revolved around... they lost me. The first 5-10 minutes of BRAVE (when the main character was a child) were promising, after that, there was no point to making this movie... even less of a point to watch it. The best way to describe BRAVE, is that the entire movie merely scratched the surface of what they could have done. In a word... disappointing.
Great movie! We bought this movie for our four year old son. He loves it. :) !!! !!! !!! !!!

I have seen disneys recent movies and this one is definitely the best one in the recent two years. It was very well made and funny. It tells a tale about a daughter who is a free spirit who's mother always tries and make her more princess and lady like. She stumbles on a witches house and asked to make her mother to change. She was turned into a black bear and now they must find a way to change her back. A definite addition to any Disney collection.

Brave shines as the most compelling Disney princess film ever made.  As appealing as the other Disney princesses are, Merida brings a healthy dose of real-life teen rebellion, a desire for independence, unique talent, and the ability to think on her own two feet to the concept of princess as a model young woman.  Additionally, this is the only Disney princess film I can think of in which the mother of the princess is still living.  The evolution of the relationship between Merida and the Queen has an extraordinary arc that will leave you in tears--it makes me cry every time.  There are some pretty scary parts that might not be appropriate for some children, and I would have loved for the songs to be on the lips of the princess and her queen mother, but Brave has nevertheless become my very favorite animated film and I'd recommend it to any parent.
We've enjoyed this dvd and hope that PIXAR will continue to deliver fun family entertainment.  Only gave it four stars because there are other PIXAR films which hold the 5-star spot for us.

I love this movie. It's strong and has a good message. Yes, there are 2 small scenes with bare butts, but they're not randomly placed and they add to the movie as it 1) explains how the men got there and 2) wouldn't make sense if they had clothes at that point.  That and it breaks up a more serious movie with a bit of humor.  There's even an extra scene after the credits that's good and fits in with the story.

And that leads me to my only complaint.  WHY was it necessary to list the marketing team, theme parks, and even the babies?  The credits are way too long. Who in the movie theater actually sat through them to see the little clip at the end?  Really?  Okay. Rant over. :)

Quite contrary to the traditional thinking of being brave that one would define. Whether you were expecting for a shiny hero to save the weak, you were mistaken. Brave is the courageous to confront your mom, yourself, to break free, and to fight for what you believe in responsibly. Being brave is not just an act, it is a process enchained with one's growing up. You want freedom, but are you willing to pay the price? And should one's freedom be merely as an act of selfishness be about one's life? Watch brave to find your own answer. Brave is a thrilling story and a must for the holiday.

I've never written a review on amazon before, but after watching Brave for the first time only a few days ago, I really feel like I should speak out my opinion.

 ( CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR THOSE WHO HAVENT SEEN THE MOVIE DONT READ )

 The first time I saw the trailer for Brave I thought OH WOW THIS ACTUALLY LOOKS GOOD lol! Most family movies that come out these days just seem to be more for the little kids then the entire family.(I grew up on the movies from renaissance Disney) So when I found out about Merida, The fresh new warrior princess defying tradition.. I guess I over hyped it for myself.
 The beginning looked great! Everything looked so real I thought I was watching live action. The music is very beautiful and melodic. Our female protagonist is princess Merida. A flame haired tomboy who is a skilled archer  and loves riding her horse Angus. She spends most of her time at home fussing with her mother the queen Elinors strict commands on how to be a proper princess. I didn't have a problem with this, Elinor is just trying to be a good mother and teach her daughter how to do things the right way for her own good and wellbeing. Of course Merida isn't ok with these rules of being a princess. So Merida and Elinor spend most of there time arguing with each other.

  This all really doesn't bother me because when I was going through my earlier years of puberty I was a bit of a brat too. But since then ive been having the best relationship with my mom. Mostly because she never gave in to my tantrums and stood her ground. Something sadly most parents don't do and just give in. Creating spoiled adult brats the rest of society have to deal with. I don't like to say best friends with my mom because im only 17 and shes in her 50s, but I do talk to my mom about EVERYTHING. She is the first person I go to for advice about anything. My mom is like my queen and Im her princess, shes the loving mentor I could ever want and NEED.

  But this isn't the case through Meridas eyes. Elinor informs her that she is to be betrothed to one of her father's allied clans sons. Merida doesn't like this idea of getting married to anybody and at her young age. So she throws the biggest fits from here on out. (Through out the rest of the whole film.) If I was going to be put through arranged marriage at my age, I would have a fit too. But Merida is a princess of the 10th century Scotland world. Her marriage is only for the sake of peace for her country. She could still shoot her arrows after shes married.. or maybe not. Things get even more sour when Merida yells off at her mom screaming '' I would rather die then be like you!'' and runs away for an hour. Everything is easily fixed with magic, so she goes to a witch to try and change her fate. Well this is were I get a little confused and even sick to the stomach. She basically asks the witch for a spell to CHANGE HER MOM. I thought '' woahhh what now?'' is this suppose to be the bravery we are about to see? So instead of just maybe wishing for a different fate, she specifically asks that her mother be changed. Not even Ariel from the little mermaid asked that lol.( She had the bravery to actually switch out her tailfin not change her dads opinions of the forbidden human world.) Am I really the ONLY daughter in the whole wide world who got sick at this? Merida gives her mom a CURSED CAKE and watches her mom get SICK, and all Merida says is ' YOU CHANGE YOUR MIND YET MOMMY''?! Elinor gets ill and sick from the cursed cake while her heartless daughter practically gets high hopes off of this. Elinor then turns into a bear and the rest of the movie is about how cool Merida is trying to own up to her lil mistake. And everybody is ok with that. Merida doesn't really do or change or mature into anyone. Its mostly her mother that does the changing. Well she changes her opinion on her daughter getting married and lets her off the leash. Which would have been nice... if she wasn't practically cursed in the process to learn her lesson on how to be a better mom. Merida and Elinor grow a closer bond with each other while Elinor being a bear and all, Merida even teaches her mom how to catch fish. The ending of the movie is just '' you gotta be brave enough to change your fate-destiny-mom' or something like that. At least Mulan was able to find a way to honor her family and find her true self. Pocahontas chose her people over running off with John smith. Merida... continues riding her horse and now has a great relationship with her mom. They even make a new tapestry together with Elinor being the bear...(couldnt be her in human form)

  It would have been slightly better if the movie explained how being a housewife isn't the most horrible thing that can happen to a woman, but that not all girls should be that way either.  And that whenever we have a problem with our mothers we should fix our moms. That doesn't come off as an independent brave princess to me. Sure Ariel runs away from home to go on land, but at least she didn't complain as much and just did what she wanted to do.

  I grew up watching all the princess movies. Not just the fighter princess ones like Mulan and Pocahontas but also The little Mermaid , Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty and all the rest. I love and adore all kinds of girls and women. From the lovesick girly girl Princesses, to the fighter princesses taking action into her own hands.

 Today at 17 I don't feel the great need to get married to soon before the age of 25, and I don't need rescuing either. My mother is my hero. This movie kind of sends off a wrong message that your mom is the one who needs to change if you have a problem with her. Yes a parent can learn new things from their children, but the way it was done in this film.. It just doesn't sit well with me at all. If you want your daughter to feel loved and independent.. why not show her movies that does good for all us girls. Like The Little Princess and The Secret Garden from Warner Bros. Forget about those? Sure there not mother daughter flicks. But they have tons of girl power :)

How is this character a role model? Merida is born into the most privileged position in her society but rejects the accompanying obligations. Merida's mother clearly loves her but when Merida meets a strange witch she immediately purchases a spell that puts her mother's life in danger just to selfishly avoid her royal obligations. It is a mistake to judge the obligations of a historical social organization by what exists today. Other than skill at archery I saw nothing in Merida that was good. Merida's selfishness and lack of concern for society as a whole seem to epitomize what is wrong with people today. She is the bratty child of privilege like Paris Hilton. Did she do the right thing for her royal realm? No, she almost kills her mother to avoid doing the right thing. So if you want your children to disregard what is best for family and country and turn to witches and spells to break the rules this is the movie to teach that. How did this movie win an Oscar? I suspect many people who actually got to vote just read the positive press for the movie and never actually saw it. To actually watch all the Oscar contenders is an obligation a Merida would skip so maybe the Oscar voters see a kindred spirit. Wreck It Ralph should have won.

Well, what can I say?  I'm old, and I'm a parent of a 13 year old girl and a 15 year old boy.  I loved Disney cartoons back in the day.  I also had my kids watch them as they got old enough to (whatever the parent feels, but I waited a bit).  I understand that kids focus on the slap stick and the gags and such.  However, there is absolutely no doubt that the amount of smack talk, brattiness, smack talk, disrespectful attitude, etc, is rampant in the "new" films of today.  Fine, I understand that people say Bugs Bunny/Looney Tunes were some of the most violent cartoons ever, agreed, but it is STILL different!  SO, I guess kids can get some fun off of these, but I would wait until they were older as the negative outweighs the positive messages of the film.  Hey, this is just because I care man.  cheers.

I'm a bit worried about Pixar of late... they seem to be having a hard time finding their way since UP, which was followed by the overestimated TOY STORY 3, and the "let's never mention this again" CARS 2 ... BRAVE seemed like a shot at returning to form with a new original story.

And there is much to admire here.  The animation is, of course, outstanding - reportedly a new software upgrade was required for handling the heroine's fiery red hair, and it shows.  Pixar has yet to falter in the graphics department, and BRAVE is a stunning and beautiful film to behold!  The voice acting is typically top shelf as well, with the likes of Emma Thompson, Kelly McDonald, and Bill Connoly leading the cast.  And the underlying theme of learning how to swallow your pride and admit mistakes is a very good one to share with the youngsters.

With a strong foundation such as this, it is a shame that the movie ends up feeling so ... bland.  The problem here is that there really isn't anything new to sink your teeth into.  Perhaps we hold Pixar to too high of a standard now after one major innovative story after another.  I have long bragged over Pixar's ability to avoid the commonalities of Disney and other animated features - but here things are about as rudimentary as they come.

So how many over-worn story elements you can find here:

We have a young princess (check) who has a problem with her parents authority (check) who decides to follow her own path (check) which leads her to making a deal with a witch (check) that ends up backfiring and hurting those she loves (check), requiring her to mature in order to solve the problem (check) - but in doing so, she still ultimately kind of gets what she originally wanted (check and check).

Supposedly there was originally an intention to make this more of an adventure story of the "good vs. evil" kind, and you can see in the build up of the heroine how this might have been.  She is an expert archer in the medieval days of Scotland - a setting rife with possibilities for adventure.  But, midway through you can sense the script being wrested out of one pair of hands and into another as the story takes a right turn into fable territory... one wonders how this setup might have functioned as more of an adventure.

But as I said, the theme overall is a good one, and the relationship that builds between Merida and her mother is a very touching and positive one.  There is certainly a strong pro-family message here, which is always nice.

However, there are also the typical ongoing tropes that are, sadly, rampant in Disney's films of late - adult responsibility is not as important as personal freedom, men are immature idiots while woman must take up their slack, etc...

And most annoying of all, nearly every shot of the movie has to have someone bumping into something, or being hit by something, or screaming, or falling, or laughing uproariously.  It's as if the filmmakers are afraid of losing the kids' interest for a split second, so they had to dress up every shot with some overly kinetic movement.  Add to this the over-animation of the characters.  Merida cannot simply bob her head as she utters a line - she has to sweep her hair up, or fall onto a bed and then roll off, or bulge her eyes, or something... these are the elements that are common among Disney films, but have not plagued the Pixar movies of the past.

Overall, BRAVE is a passable piece of entertainment - but it quickly leaves you once you've walked away.  Enjoyable? Sure... but BEST ANIMATED FEATURE?  Hardly!  The handful of children I know of who have seen it have expressed no interest in seeing it again.  That's your target audience, Pixar - I hope you're paying attention!

I'm  not excited about Pixar continuing this year with the "franchise development" mentality in delivering a MONSTERS, INC prequel ... I really want to see them getting back to groundbreaking and innovative storytelling - and keeping away from the commonalities of children's animation - here's hoping the best animation studio in the business will remember it's roots!!

At the time I subitted mt request the fees were automatically deducted from my bank account as expected.  However, afetr several attempts (days later) to track this DVD movie I was unable to do so.  I sent in a not to the seller informing them I was unable to track the movie at since I usually receive my movies within a week I was concerned on whether or not it was lost.  The seller responded within a couple of days that he would track it for me and get back with me.  On 3/19/13 (the deadline for when the movie should arrive) I still had not received the movie so I contacted the seller again this time I received no response as of today 3/29/13, nor did I receive a refund.  So I paid for a movie I never received.  This experience has truly been a bitter one.  I will never trust nor purchase anything from this seller again.  Since this I went on to purchase the movie at a store when I know I will get what I pay for.

*WARNING THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS* I just finished previewing BRAVE because I had heard good things and was considering buying it for my 8 year old niece and 6 year old nephew. I really wanted to love this film. I'm glad I watched it first. I would not consider buying this video for anyone under 12 and even then, I'm not sure it has much redeeming value at any age. Why? Several reasons.

1) MOST IMPORTANTLY, THIS FILM IS VERY VIOLENT. I can forgive lame story lines etc but there are too many violent scenes. The most upsetting violence makes up most of the second half of the movie in which a bear (the mother, under a spell) is being hunted by a mob of nobles with flames, ropes, arrows etc -- and the audience knows the bear is the child's mother. The daughter is trying frantically to save her mother.  Horrifying.  Any child watching this is going to be frightened by this and fearful that the girl's mother will be killed! Also there are a lot of scenes of rowdy Scottish clans who erupt into fighting each other when they get bored. This is almost all the father does in the film, besides hunt the bear.

2) ALSO IMPORTANT, THE HEROINE ISN'T VERY LIKEABLE OR A GOOD ROLE MODEL beyond her horsemanship, skills at archery, and of course her hair (which is beautifully animated and for most of the movie looks like a living thing -- a lovely sea anemone drifting in the current). Selfishly, she seeks a spell to transform her mother (granted, she doesn't know what the transformation will be) who is trying to get her to do something she doesn't want to do - get married (BTW, it's 2013 and women are outpacing men of the same age in education and earning power - are we still railing against marriage (even if it is arranged) as the great oppressor of women? yawn.) Why didn't she seek the spell for herself instead of her mother? When the spell goes horribly wrong, she simply does what she should do in order to save her mother's life. This doesn't seem to me to be particularly 'brave' -- just decent. She doesn't even apologize to her mother for turning her into a bear until almost the end of the movie! She spends much of the first part of the film flouncing around, running away on her horse (also beautifully animated!) and rolling her eyes at her mother and her good-natured but absent and slightly stupid father. I suspect this is to establish her 'independence' but it doesn't. She just looks like a prideful brat. That's not independence nor did she learn any.

3) OTHER BOTHERSOME BUT NON-FATAL ISSUES INCLUDE that the plot doesn't live up to the billing and is REALLY THIN. The father is a non-existent influence, the brothers are also non-persons (both disappointing because I thought this might have something more for a little boy). This girl changed her 'fate' (maybe) by nearly destroying others (her mother and her brothers who are inadvertently caught in the spell). Was there another way to get her mother to listen to her and to avoid getting married? Probably. Even if she had run away and faced some trials (maybe killed the other bear that took off her father's leg years past) that would have been better -- SHE would have suffered and grown and when she returned home it would have been believable that she had found some independence and her own path. I don't see the growth in this plot.

Also, the theme of a young princess who doesn't want to be in an arranged marriage is unlikely to be grasped by a younger child or to get their attention. The character is too young for this to be a believable storyline. She looks like she is @ 10 years old. An older princess character might have made this story line more believable. In short, I am very disappointed in this film and won't be buying it or recommending it, but if some hairstylist can figure out how to replicate that hair - then that would be something.

Very disappointed with this film, especially from Pixar which has put out some gems. There was no clear moral, a sketchy plot, and minimal resolution.

The movie tries to make some vague points about changing your fate, except you can't really change your fate, only sometimes you can. It's very vague has no real purpose.

There's also this whole mother/daughter relationship dynamic which could have been done beautifully, and in fact has some good moments, but again: vague and no real purpose.

Spoiler alert! After the main character and her mother get in a fight, tearing a tapestry, the daughter finds a witch and asks for her mother to be "changed". The mother is cursed into becoming a bear. The given solution to the curse is to "mend the bond" that was broken. You'd think: "well clearly it's a metaphor, and the mother/daughter relationship needs mending." Wrong. For some reason the writers decide to take this extremely literally and she has to physically sew the tapestry that was broken.

Overall, the film really stretches to find some depth and meaning which at the end of the day just isn't there. Pixar films used to be a "must see" for me, but "brave" has me doubting that mentality.
