I have heard good things about Brave, and I thought the animation was lovely, I just found the heroine to be a bit of a brat. To me she seemed quite spoiled, she was given a lot of love and attention and seemed quite privileged. She accepts all but none of the responsibility.  When it comes to being responsible, she runs away, never owning up to her actions. She wasn't compassionate, she wasn't considerate of others, and aside from shooting a bow, she didn't have a lot of talent at much of anything. I didn't find her that brave. I think this could've been written differently, so the heroine's rebellion would seem a bit more justified, and less the actions a form of tantrum. Yes, I agree, being forced to marry someone against your will is a bad custom. But so is hereditary leadership, royalty, an privilege. I didn't notice that she was all that upset about her privileged life in the castle. In fact, her and her brothers seem to take advantage of their good fortune quite often, plaguing the servants, and wrecking the kitchen. To me, she seemed quite spoiled. Rebellion against custom can be brave- but it is more brave to rebel against something that you personally benefit from. Getting upset because you are forced to marry a prince against your will, while enjoying your privileged life and more personal freedom than most people of your time.. I found it tough to sympathize with really.

Disney (Pixar division) has done it again!  On the heels of Tangled, Disney had released yet another princess to the cheers of all.  Disney has played with the princess myth/story in many ways over the years.  In Brave the princesses get their payback.  Brave is nothing like Snow White and she doesn't intend to be, despite her mother's wishes elsewise.  So many great themes are explored and woven into the main story.  3D adds to the fun, but in this case it truly is icing as Brave delights in any version.  Still, the 3D is well done!

Brave is a story about a mother and daughter coming to terms with one another in a teen angst coming of age movie.  The film takes common teen cliches and parent of teen cliches and explores them in a magical way.  There's nothing new here.  The cliches have been around a while.  I would have rather liked to see the movie more about the killer bear and his back story.  For me, this is almost the weakest Pixar movie.  I still think the Cars franchise is weaker, but this one is a close second.

Brave is a beautiful movie with great music and voice actors, but the story and characters just aren't there.

The theme of a bonding mother and daughter is a refreshing change, but the whole movie is based around this idea of self sacrifice for the greater good and a comparison between the protagonist and a mythical prince that led the country to ruin through strong feelings of entitlement, but she never changes, she's no more willing to sacrifice than she was at the beginning. The only difference is she is closer to her mother and manages to squirm out of the consequences for choosing her own happiness over duty as the story became less about the conflict of her arranged marriage and instead is about changing her mother who is turned into a bear back to a human, which she might have also tried to ignore if it wasn't for the fact that her mother would have died in the end if she had.

In Brother Bear, which was not only made first by Disney and would have made this movie redundant if they'd called it Mother Bear. The protagonist actually sacrifices his human life to make amends for the pain he caused another. If you are familiar with that movie then consider what the moral would have been if instead of changing himself, he pushed the bear cub he unknowingly wronged to change into a human instead to fix the problem and you'll understand what I took from this movie. I didn't see Brother Bear win any Oscars, but to be fair it did lose to "Finding Nemo".

But in this movie the protagonist doesn't change. By the end she finally listens and somewhat understands what could have been the result of her stubbornness, but she never has to make any sacrifices because the world bends to her wishes and she gets her way.

Perhaps I'm too focused on this point but it seems to be a common concept these days that a stubborn and free-willed character is a strong character. It isn't, she isn't. I found her to be unbearably annoying at times. In example, she has just given her mother magical food poisoning and even while her mother is huddling in pain, she continues to ask if she has changed her mind about the wedding. Then her mother crawls to her room and collapses and we don't see any concern or guilt we get. "So I'll go ahead and tell them the wedding is off shall I?"

Yes, the mother and daughter had some emotional bonding. Why? Because the daughter fed her mother with a magic danish that ends up turning her into a bear and is then forced into hiding so her oblivious husband doesn't kill her from his blind vendetta against bears.

Why did the daughter ignorantly poison her mother?  Because she was being forced to marry one of three suitors, which of course all had to be baboons in some way or another to try and force the audience to pity her, instead of finding her motives selfish as they would have if the suitors had been decent people. (In fact I can't think of a single male character in this movie that wasn't a muscle-head or to put frankly, a dork.)

The mother even explains how selfish she's being and how her stubbornness could destroy their kingdom/clan. Her response from what I remember has the undertones of "so what." I had no problem with all of this until the end. After all, a character is supposed to work through their problems as the story goes on, but as I've made clear this doesn't happen. I was more interested in the magic and the mythical fallen kingdom than anything to do with the protagonist.

I agree we need more pro-feminist movies in a genre filled with Damsels and Prince Charmings, but this is not how you go about it. So three stars for the great soundtrack and incredible graphics and setting, but little more beyond that.

Forgive the title but in my opinion, Little Vanellope from Wreck-It-Ralph was braver and more likable than Merida and I feel Disney was pushed under the rug simply because it was Pixar that made this movie or perhaps the Video Game subject matter of Wreck-It-Ralph wasn't as refined or mature as they wanted, but from personal opinion I felt the general choice had nothing to do with the actual movies.

I want to say that just as most other reviewers the story has its troublesome spots, while it tries to embrace the idea of a girl coming of age, it also teaches rebelliousness against parents, a big no-no, it also makes the kids seem to be smart and their parents stupid and out of touch with reality. Listen most of you at Pixar, do you have kids? I mean try to be more sensitve about such things and make parents as wise as they are, to allow the children to see that their parents are not the enemy and that peer pressure and all the dangerous stuff in the world is, like drugs, sex, violence, rebellion (when not warranted). This also goes for all the other animation companies, also the jokes were alittle over the top, tone it down please, you want to go all out make an adult movie, leave our kids out of that stuff until they are out of the house and make their own decisions, you know what i mean?
  Now as for the good, the animation is just eye popping, i mean you are reaching a higher and higher level of visual excellence that is stunningly gorgeous, well done also the bear is the most beautifully rendered and terrifying bear probably in animation history only the bear in over the hedge comes to mind but this one takes the crown. The excitement is very intense, well don, but it will scare some of the children even the 8 year olds maybe. THe lighting, the surround sound all top notch as is to be expected from Pixar.
  Please continue to give us great films of this calibur but do be mindful of the above comments and please include a moral to the story that can carry on for years to come, positive and worth their weight in gold. Wall-e did give a good message about being green and its consequences which i hope we will all find ways to avoid. Corporate Greed is lazy it doesn't care how it gets what it wants, its irresponsible will not accept being held accountable for anything.
  We need companies made up of responsibly minded scientist, developers CEO's etc., to force other less responsible companies into the beat of the drum or off the side of the ship. Use texting to spread the news about being economically and environmentally responsible consumers, purchase only productst that are safe and don't damage the environment, everyone wants this, while including a perfect blend of being sensitive to the communitie, its needs, its workers, job proctection etc., and that will donate to the starving children, save the forest and endangered animals while helping the populace nearby and spreading awareness, educating as you move forward. It begins with children movies as well, set the right tone and you never have to look back or there won't be a future to look forward to or even worse, that the future our children will inherit will be a disgrace and the shame of our generation. Dont just read this and forget it, read it and make a stand, make a change, do something everyday to help us change this thing around and make the world a better place, a peaceful place because it can all be so beautiful.

The movie, Brave, was very well made.  What was lacking is story line.  I watched it with my grown daughter
and we both liked it.  But we agreed that the story line, while an important one, was much misplaced in this
movie. Lovely movie but cartoon-ish in story line.  Too bad. The good thing, we agreed, is that we didn't spend the
going rate of approximately $15.00 each to see it in the theater.  We really wanted to love this movie, but the
best we can say is that, all told, it's okay.  We will save it for it's visual beauty for her baby to watch when he
gets older and the story line, while it could have been told better, is still a valuable one.

This is a good movie, one that I watched on DVD. My kids are too old to watch Disney movies now, but I'm not. My wife watched it with me, and we were captivated by the story, the brave, bold young woman who makes a foolish choice, then pays for it, makes amends, and well I won't ruin the story. It was well done, with a strong story line, good, believable characters, an adventure that will keep you watching, a struggle between good and evil, both internal and external.

There are lots of sly jokes for the adults, which were truly funny. All the males in the film are treated like bumbling simpletons, which is a pernicious but officially sanctioned form of sexism today. I was willing to overlook it here, because the story was such a good one. The true story of the making of this film is a cautionary tale, because Brenda Chapman, the person who conceived this story based on her relationship with her daughter, started as the director of the film, but was shut out from the final product. Doesn't seem fair, but that is the way they do business in the movies. The final product is a good one, no matter how many bodies lie beneath the parking lot at the studio.

*slight spoiler*

There's no handsome prince (though Merida's suitors are presented like a comedically-horrible round of first dates), and I thought I would miss the romance aspect. But by the middle of the movie I was like "Eh, ain't nobody got time for that-- we've got to fight Mordu and change our fates!!"

In short: it's a wonderful adventure, and one that I know I'll be watching over and over again.

Merida (Kelly MacDonald) is a princess that just wants adventure and excitement. Her mother the Queen however, is forcing Merida to marry whoever wins the competition for her heart. Which makes Merida mad enough to get a magic pastry from a witch in the forrest that she feeds to her mom to change her fate. The Queen is turned into a bear and the two bond when Merida protects her mom from her bear killing father.
  Brave is a Disney film that has a Princess that doesn't care about love which hasn't been done by them before. But that doesn't mean it deserved an Oscar due to that. I think Tangled was a better animated comedy by Disney and that wasn't even nominated. Looking at the trailer for Brave, I expected a stronger film from Pixar that we just didn't get. The film is funny and has a touching ending but compared to Wall-E, Up, Finding Nemo, the Incredibles and Toy Story, Brave is one of Pixar's weaker movies.

It has it's typical Disney theme were the main character learns a very important lesson by the end of the movie, which Merida does.  But aside from the life lesson she learns the real reason I love this movie is that the main character is a woman and that she is not some helpless princess like some of them are in the Disney movies.  She writes her own fate.  She is Katniss Everdean in the world of Disney animation.  And if that is something that you want to teach your kids then you must own this movie.  It is incredible.

I just wasn't sure if it was for a audience that is DEFINETELY not a fan of princesses. But my mind was changed one day. I was walking through Walmart in crestview and was about to see if they had Brave. It was nowhere to be seen! I asked the assisstant of electronics and he told me that it was the most requested item in the USA. And after looking at Amazon reviews ( 5 STARS!! ) I figured I shoul see it. I don't know that I can say anything more than what so many others have already said about this movie except, it made me cry.  It's a touching and heartwarming tale about a tomboy Scottish princess who refuses to become the lady her mother, the queen, requires her to be.  In an attempt to change her mother, with the aid of a woodcarving witch, her mother is changed into a bear.  The rest of the movie is a journey of discovery as mother and daughter grow closer, trying to undo the spell before it's made permanent.  It's funny, it's moving, overall its a good time.  Kids will enjoy it, parents will love it.  The animation is top notch, the music is wonderful and compliments the story beyond words.

Overall, it was definitely a film worth watching.  I believe I would recommend it to adults with some reservations.  Small children might not even blink at that ursine metamorphosis.

My daughter received this UCE as a 2012 Xmas present, but we just got around to watching it over last weekend. That's probably because she's turning 16 in March, and she's right on the cusp of outgrowing the appeal of most Disney heroine films (I remember her wanting to see this movie when it was released in theaters in June, 2012, but she never did see it in the theater, and seemed none the worse for it.) In the world of the high school sophomore, last year's priorities can become this year's "meh" overnight!

It turns out that the movie has a level of maturity to it that worked very well for my soon-to-be-sweet-sixteen daughter. From a parenting perspective, I had no problem with the few "adult" bits that were tossed in, as they were sufficiently humorous and sufficiently brief as to not be off-putting. This is pretty tame stuff by any measure.

Overall, I enjoyed the film as well, though the story isn't very inventive as stories go. Within the first 15 minutes one can begin predicting what will occur later in the story line. I was happy to see that Disney avoided adding too many contemporary references or characters to the film (Merida's mom tells her to "stop doodling" in one scene), as such playing to the gallery can become dated in short order (think "The Emperor's New Groove," or Robin Williams' Genie in "Aladdin," whose ad naseum references to circa 1980s pop culture are lost on audiences 20 years later). I can see "Brave" becoming a family evergreen, watched each year around St Patrick's Day, along with "Darby O'Gill & The Little People" and "The Quiet Man," even though "Brave" is set in Scotland, not Ireland.

The animation is just spectacular - "Brave" just won the 2013 Oscar for animation, in fact. The only complaint I have is the complaint I have about most of Disney's recent animated films: things sometimes move too fast, no doubt a sop to pacing their films to a contemporary tempo that will compete with the explosion-laden video games that are so popular these days.

Another Academy Award-winning film from Disney/Pixar, though not - I suspect - the kind of film that will garner the repeat viewings the more-traditional Disney fare seems to enjoy, let alone earning a place in posterity in the form of a theme ride at one of Disney's Amusement Parks.

Four stars.

I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoy this movie. I read new software was used to make Merida's hair more life like and it worked. Her hair is what made me fall in love with her right from the beginning. The story itself is not what I expected. Without spoiling the story, this movie is not simply a teenager rebelling against her parents. It may start that way but stick with it and I think both sides can learn something from the story, especially parents (and I am an adult saying this). And of course there is fun mixed in with a serious message. The triplets are hysterical, I just want to hug them as I shake my head at them. They are like a puppy - so cute you can't stay mad at them. I haven't watched the blu-ray version yet but the dvd picture is crisp and clear. This is a top notch movie from head to tail. Something you can enjoy with the entire family, even if you have to tie down the teenagers I think they will enjoy it. Merida has a spunky spirit that I think many teenage daughters can relate to. I think I would if I was a teenager again.

Not a movie I will willingly watch over and over. I bought it as a Christmas present for my 4 year old granddaughter who also received Tangled and Cinderella. I know out of those 3 it would be my 3rd choice to watch.

The whole family watches this movie and we love that we have it on the road as well as at home.  It is fabulous.

Visually, "Brave" is stunning, with the usual excellent soundtrack and voices expected of such movies these days.  But what's it about?  Damned if I know.

The heroine is a willful, capable young woman who can outride, outshoot and outthink nearly everyone she comes in contact with.  Her mother annoys her, however, so what does she do?  She seeks out a witch, who transforms her mother into a non-speaking bear.  Then what happens?  A bunch of stuff that doesn't really amount to a hill of beans.

Maybe I just didn't get "Brave", because I'm not a kid.  But I've loved nearly every other CGI animated movie of this type, and this one left me cold.  If you're looking for a saga of a young woman using her heroic gifts and achieving great things, I believe you'll be disappointed.  I frankly think "Tangled" is a better movie involving billowing hair.

Brave didn't get the best reviews, but I really liked the strong story line with a moral about pride and selfishness. The portrayal of the mother in both her incarnations was excellently done visually. I loved the princesses hair.

While the animation is striking, it is kind of dark material and the accents the characters have can make it hard to understand to a child.  I am not saying the movie was bad, but I think the animators focused to much on how everyone's hair looked and moved and not enough on the content.  I have said this before, but this movie couldn't hold a candlestick next to movies like Paranorman, which is a little dark, but you kind of know that by the title.  Brave is a nice little movie, but it is forgettable.

This movie does not herald virtue. It promotes vice. In one moment, it says that pride is the problem that causes all the turmoil in her family. Then, it says that "I must choose MY own fate", thus promoting pride! The only person who changes is the mom, but not the child. Long-standing family and cultural traditions, as well as the wisdom of elders is mocked in this movie, in exchange for doing "what I want" and "following my heart". Where's the chivalry in that?

Moms, if you want your daughters to learn how to talk back to you and become more selfish, have them watch this movie.

Dads, if you want your children to see you as nothing more than a buffoon with no real authority, have them watch this movie.

I'm disappointed with Pixar. They had set a standard for classy movies, but this felt more like Shrek to me. Want your kids to see images of bare backsides and cleavage? It's all in this "family" movie. Tasteless humor, and promoting selfishness with no lasting consequences.

We laughed, We cried, We thoroughly enjoyed BRAVE.  There isn't a mother or daughter that cannot relate to the movie!  I am so sorry we listened to poor reviews and didn't see it on the theater big screen! It was my favorite Christmas present from my daughter who bought it for me to remind me of the turbulent teenage years. It's our special favorite Disney movie now.

All in all, it is a thoroughly enjoyable movie, even for a 79-year-old man.  My only complaint was that some of the dialogue in the Scottish brogue was very difficulty to understand.  I would recommend checking to see if subtitles are available on the DVD.

We have been mostly appalled by the Disney Princess phenomenon and all the entitled little mean girls it has engendered over the last twenty years.  (Anyone who thinks Ariel is a model for how young women should behave needs their head examined.)  So it was refreshing to find a Disney movie in which the lead female DOESN'T think that sacrificing all to chase after marriage to a handsome man is the best thing ever.  Merida is passionate, talented, opinionated, bold (and, yes, "brave"), and absolutely willing to stand up for her right to determine her own fate and not have it dictated by tradition.  She's the Disney princess that doesn't want to marry anyone yet.  It's one of the few recent Disney movies we don't mind letting our daughters watch.

What a wonderful movie!  I wonder if Merida will become one of the new "Disney Princesses"?  We shall see.. she is a great role model for young women today- take their fate in their own hands!

I do not understand the negative reviews of this movie at all. Personally, I think it's Pixar's best movie to date! I think the message is great for children and parents alike. Both of the main characters change and that's the point. Merida learns that her selfishness leads to nothing but destruction and Elanor learns that she isn't always in the right. The graphics are beautifully fantastic and even though there are some dark moments, there are also some funny ones to even it out.

As for the marriage issue, I like where the story leads. In most Disney movies, the princess is always seeking to be married and for the man to save her. Merida isn't ready and wants to grow up a little before she gets married, as do the suitors. It seems appropriate for this day and age, when everyone is trying to hook up as quickly as possible.

Overall, this is a wonderful movie and I highly recommend it.

I was very unsure about this movie after having heard and read some reviews. I wasn't sure if it was appropriate content for my 4 year old daughter. So, we rented it and enjoyed it enough to buy this 3 pack.

1. This is NOT a typical Disney princess movie. My husband LOVED this the first time we watched it. There is a lot of boy humor in it which my daughter now enjoys. There is no boy she falls in love with and she does not get married in the end. The story is about her and her mother. It's a beautiful story.

2. The bear scenes are not as scary as I thought they would be. Despite Merida turning her mother into a bear, her mother still acts like her mother - mannerisms and all. It's very funny and entertaining. There is another bear that is scary and those scenes are a bit sketchy but I would compare them to the wolf scenes in Beauty & the Beast. There is some witchcraft involved (as in most Disney movies) but it wasn't enough to bother me (unlike The Princess and the Frog which I think was horrible).

3. The animation is fantastic and Merida is beautiful, especially her hair!

4. The musical score is one of the best I've heard in a Disney movie. I would buy the CD in a heartbeat.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie for 4 and up. I think it may be too scary for kids younger than that and some of the boy humor may not be appropriate. The more I watch it, the more I love it. It's really a great movie!
Great movie and super 3D effects. Great way to experience our new 3D set. i highly recommend for adults and kids.

I watched "Brave" with my three and a half year-old when she had the flu last week. It was a bit too violent for her age, even with the kooky sound effects meant to lighten the mood, and I'm fairly sure the symbolism of the bond that needed mending went straight over her head despite my explanation. The characters are appealing and the animation top notch. "Brave" is no "Beauty and the Beast," and certainly doesn't have the adult appeal of "Aladdin," but I liked seeing a girl making her own decisions and an adolescent struggling to balance her desire for independence against responsibility to her family and community.

I expected a movie with a very broad and sweeping cinematic scope to it. And also some fierce troll or ogre battling coming of age tale. Instead two of the main characters are piggy-backing one another throughout the whole film. They do not take a journey to a far off land to find the crystal sword that will push the protagonist to discover some profound meaning to life and become protector of her land. Instead the main scenes mostly take place in the castle and the nearby wood. Then again it is a PIXAR film which means by proxy it is a family oriented production company, so far, so I should have known what I was getting into when purchasing this film. It has it's moments...
It's nice to do 3d for special occasions, blue ray just for fun, or have the regular DVD in the car.

King Fergus: [shrilly voice] I don't want to get married, I want to stay single and let my hair flow in the wind as I ride through the glen firing arrows into the sunset.

Brave takes CG animation to a new level and is a visual feast, however, the story line is weak and the movie loses steam and focus just when it should crescendo.  The title is a misnomer.  The heroine isn't as brave as she is a self-centered narcissist, but that will appeal to the teenage and 20 something set for whom this mindset is normative.  But perhaps mother-daughter conflicts are just not as appealing to me as other plot devices. I was expecting something along the lines of  "How to Train Your Dragon", but it falls way short.

Usually I enjoy Disney/Pixar works.  That being said, this has got to be the poorest attempt at a decent story line I've seen in a while.  The characters are enjoyable and the overblown cultural stereotypes will bring out laughs.  After the movie is over, however, you'll probably be left wondering exactly what you just experienced.  The moral component of this story is humility over pride and love over control.  Some of the ideas were really good and the graphics were incredible, but the story is so disjointed and incomplete that it brings the movie down - way down. Some of the bear scenes as well as the witch scene will probably be a little too much for younger kids.
Very pleased with my purchase of this movie - I found the resolution great and I liked the fact that I had it to view for 48 hours.

We were searching for a relatively recent kids film to watch with our 10 year-old and she recommended Brave from the TV commercials she had seen last year. Well, what a disappointment!  The message re mother-daughter relatins got completely obscured by the ludicrous fighting scenes (apparently they were supposed to be funny?).  The worst was the scene where the bear/mother was tied and trapped in preparation for slaughter.  A children's film?  Did anyone really enjoy this film?

I couldn't believe how horrible this was.

The movie is only about Princess Merida and her Mother, the other characters are minor. Neither Merida nor her mom knew how to listen to anyone, each always expected to get her own way.

Merida is a Princess, a member of the Royal Family.  She sees that as something to escape from.  Royalty are the richest, most connected and most powerful people in her country, and she hates it.

Beyond that the movie shows marriage as something to fight against - something to fear and oppose.  It backs up the presumption by having Merida's suitors be physically weak and mentally inadequate - in other words, beneath her.  Beyond that Merida herself chooses the means by which they were supposed to show their worth, and she deliberately chose a means in which she could out do all of them.

After that she flees into the forest - runs away from home.

Merida meats a Witch in woods and buys a spell.  She wants to curse her own mom.  The curse was on a cake, which turns her mom into a bear.  Afterwards Merida just leaves the cake laying around, she leaves a cursed cake behind.  Which her brothers eventually find and eat.

Merida's reaction to the transformation was blame the Witch, she just kept saying " It's not my fault"  She'd bought the spell, and gave it to her mom, but refused to show responsibility for her actions.

Merida then learns that her 3 younger brothers also ate the cake, turning them into bear cubs.  She'd just found out she'd cursed her brothers as well as her mom.  Her reaction was disgusting. she wasn't hurt or afraid or even shocked -  she was angry, at them!  She felt no guilt over what had happened to them.

Her dad finds her mom's cloths shredded and her room destroyed, by a bear.  He sets out to avenge his wife.  That should be a great and honorable intent, but the movie's content make it look stupid.  This shows her dad trying to kill his wife, Magic curses or not - that is horrible.  Merida arrives in time to save her mom - Saying "I won't let you kill my Mother".  She had to fight her dad, that's beyond horrible.

At the end Merida broke the curse by, finally, admitting that it had been her fault.  So her suitors were sent away. She cursed most of her family, and nearly got her mom killed - so for that she gets what she'd wanted.  She's rewarded and considered a heroine for just undoing the catastrophe she caused.

It's hard to believe children are even allowed to watch this, much less encouraged to.
You will love this. It is a fantastic change from the typical princess role. My son just loves the bears and the hourses, it is a great movie.

It's always refreshing to see a strong female character.  My 3 year old son loves this movie (even though parts a bit scary to him) and I appreciate him seeing a strong female character.  Watching it is a wonderful excuse to snuggle up with the family, but it's not my favorite movie- strange storyline- loud rambunctious scenes which seem to go on forever.  But it is beautiful to watch (especially the bears gathering salmon out of the river- wow!).  It's definitely worth a watch, but not my favorite.
for Disney to be involved in anything where the female doesn't need a male hero. Priceless! Pixar, thank you! 5 Stars!

Finally, a beautiful story about a young girl that isn't all about falling in love and getting a man! I mean, really, we need to stop teaching our daughters this! And Brave begins with this independent sassy girl who hates being prim and proper, would much rather be a tomboy and shoot arrows and ride her horse. She's still a girl and just not ready to grow up. She reminds me so much of my  daughter, Ella.

Spoilers Alert Ahead, scroll to bottom to avoid!

So when her parents announce she will be married off to keep the peace between the Kingdoms, she is beyond unhappy. Merida doesn't want to be a PRINCESS, let alone a WIFE. Her mother just won't listen, and her mother, the Queen, thinks Merida just won't listen, either, as peace is at stake if she doesn't comply. Neither understands the other.

When the suitors arrive, her parents announce only the firstborn from each royal family may shoot for Merida's hand in marriage, which gives Merida a great idea. Being the excellent marksman, or girl, that she is, she announces after everyone has gone, and shot poorly, that she will be shooting for her own hand.

This is one of my favorite scenes as she really defies her mother here, publicly, while rejecting all her suitors and standing up for herself and what she wants. Of course, her and mom get into a major fight, in which the Queen tosses Merida's precious bow into the fireplace, breaking her daughter's heart and sending Merida running from her home on horseback in tears.

Soon, she discovers a witch, whom she begs for the power just to change her mother. Merida hopes this will change her mind about the whole marriage and be done with, things can go back to normal. The witch gives her a tart to feed the Queen, promising her mom will change.

What Merida doesn't expect is that her mom changes into a bear, the very animal her father hates the most for taking his leg. The witch promised her a change, but her mom changes physically, not internally, like Merida expected. Fearing the King won't understand or believe his wife is a bear and may try to kill her, Merida and her mother flee the kingdom.

They of course return to the witches Hut to no avail, she simply left a message about fixing what has come undone by the next day or permanently becoming a bear, but the witch herself is gone.

Frustrated, guilty and sad, Merida tries to care for her mother and apologizes as they make do I'm the wild. It is entertaining to watch as the prim and proper queen turned bear tries to keep her manners about her while in her new form.  She makes eating utensils from branches, just to have them fling about. She tries to slowly eat fish at first, making Merida cook it, before impatience kicks in and it isn't long before she is ravishing fish cold and alive with get bear claws.

The two begin to share and form a new bond as her mother lives as a bear in the wild with Merida, doing things and learning things from her daughter.  Merida, in contrast learns more about the different Kingdoms and their fall as they stumble upon another bear, this one once human also, cursed like her mother,a part of what she thought was just a fairytale proved to be true. Merida finally sees the importance of all the Kingdoms uniting, and her role in it, when she realizes how they came apart; with this one brother, power hungry to control them all, became a beast. This bear who took her fathers leg.

Thinking they must return home to repair a tapestry, they sneak back into their castle, where they find everyone growing more restless. Merida decides to announce her decision, but her mother, posing as a bear statue at the back of the room, redirects her otherwise. Finally understanding one another, through time spent and a bond deeper than any ocean, this mother and daughter love each other so much.

By the end of this movie, I had shed more than a few tears and was glad just me and my daughter were watching it together the first time. She came and sat on my lap in the theatre, she's six and doesn't often do that, so I think it affected her greatly, too. When it came out I managed to get it on Black Friday and put it up for her for xmas, along with a few other Brave goodies. We quite enjoyed Brave. The art was gorgeous! Although perhaps it wasn't as "deep" or manipulative-of-the-audience's-emotions as most Pixar films of late, as a Disney Princess movie it was absolutely fantastic! I haven't liked any of the "Disney Princess"es since Belle, not enough that I'd want any of my nieces around them. Merida is a spunky young lady, as strong-headedly independent and moody as any teenage girl. She runs away, finds a witch, hijinks ensue, and we have a fun story about finding the value in one's family that they've forgotten. It's got a moral to it without being preachy, which I really quite enjoyed. Mom was flawed, but it was a flaw of love, and there wasn't even really any "bad guy" in my opinion. It was about personal growth, and one's journey.

I really quite enjoyed it. It wasn't a deep intellectual film; it's just a story about a young lass coming of age. But it was a satisfying story, well-told, with nice art and music. Planning on purchasing a copy. Do see it!

This "You can do any thing" women empowerment thing is getting old. How about setting a more realistic fantasy. I have seen women of this programming closed fist strike a guy 200 lbs heavier than them, not fat, and not understand why the open hand strike they received back was so powerful. Never would I encourage the striking of a woman, but movies like this are the reasons scenarios like that happen. every human being is limited, women, far beyond most men in multi-tasking, are not physically built like men. Other than having a cliche plot, with a bunch of bumbling cowardly men, and a downgraded demonized stay at home mom, this movie really failed to impress me with Pixars real capabilities, like what we see in Finding Nemo and How to Train a Dragon.

As usual, Pixar never fails to disappoints people with their films. Brave is a fantastic film people of all ages. The most noticeable aspect about this film (like other Pixar movies) is the animation. I was blown by the High Definition resolution. There was a part in the film in which it appeared to be like it was live-action. While watching the film, the audience may find the Merida's hair to appear just like real human hair. The vivid colors with keep your eyes glued to the television. Also, the story is pretty interesting. Since this is a family movie, people might believe it has the same traditional plot as other films. Brave delivers an interesting synopsis and keeps the audience engaged. The film has a pretty decent score as well. The music is not as great as other Disney films, but still good. Also, the special features include two magnificent Pixar shorts. Pixar shorts are amazing as all the previous ones before: stunning resolution! After watching the film, I would recommend watching the short "The Legend Of Mordu" (in the bonus content). It is an interesting and relates to the film. If you have enjoyed previous Pixar films, there is no doubt you will love this one as well. Disney and Pixar continues to make films with stunning animation and characters the audience can easily understand.

All you haters at the 1's and 2's. This was in the way of a classic folk yarn with simple story and simple values. It was a fun, cute movie and well worth watching. You had me going there, now I am only sad I waited so long to watch it believing you all this time.

I went into Brave with very high expectations, its hard not to think that Pixar will continuously produce brilliant film after brilliant film. I was sorely disappointed by Brave. The animation is gorgeous, yes- but the story telling is just not there. It feels uninspired and predictable and has none of that signature Pixar wit. In the end, its a good film- just not Pixar good.

I was really excited for this film to come out. I love Pixar films and the animation was so beautiful. The idea of an independent Scottish princess was also very attractive to me since I like strong female characters and the Celtic cultures. However, the film just lacked plot. The concept is similar to Brother Bear, but not nearly as moving. Merida is independent and rebellious, but not really in an inspiring way like Pocahontas or Mulan were. She's actually a bit of a brat. I understand not wanting to marry when you're not in love and I think that's a worthy cause, but she's outright awful to her mother. It's not just back-talking, either. She carelessly gives her mother an enchanted tart that a witch said would "change her fate," without having any thought into what the consequences might be. So then the consequences are bad and the rest of the movie is focused on fixing her mistake while also rekindling ties with her mother. In the end it's cute and happy, but not as satisfying as most Pixar films.

Overall, the film is okay. I just expected a more interesting plot from Pixar, but instead it seemed like a bad copy of another film. It was a shame to waste such gorgeous animation. Merida's hair was awesome.

My grandsons (5,8) learned not only about their Scottish heritage  (we are  also MacDonalds) from this film but got a lesson in how smart women think and behave, and were not bored as males usually are when stories center around women.  They were engrossed and happy to view the movie several times and will surely watch it again.

I love the movie Brave. So much that I decided to purchase the DVD in December. However, attempting to stream through Amazon Instant Video and a Roku player produced Audio and Video that were out of synch. Worse, I contacted Amazon the day we purchased the stream (in November) and it has taken the "support team" TWO MONTHS to attempt to "fix" the issue. I have received three form emails telling me that the technical support team is still working on this issue. I guarantee that a company like Amazon should not be struggling to fix a technical synch issue. So far, there has been no refund of my $5 to purchase the jobby stream or any attempt to give a coupon or discount for a future stream. I'm an Amazon Prime member, since the start of the program, and LOVE Amazon. BUT... I will not purchase an Instant Streaming Video ever again.

Great story and animation.  My entire family of six enjoyed the movie.  It is one of those movies that we will enjoy seeing again.

This movie is clever, funny, exciting, and of a quality rarely seen overall, let alone in animated releases marketed with youths in mind.  The only reason I put 4 stars is because this movie was made by Pixar, and this isn't a 5 star Pixar movie. In any other context, yes, 5 stars, no problem.  But this movie fails to reach the (extremely high) standards set by Pixar's greatest.

Should you see this movie? Yes. It's brilliantly paced, extremely funny, and has two shining examples of strong female protagonists with both Merida and her mother. Will it make you cry like Up did? Probabally not.  Does it take risks with the format of storytelling like Wall-E did? Nope; in fact, the plot is fairly predictable for an adult, though children might be taken by some of the twists. Still, while this isn't Pixar's greatest film, it's likely better than most of the other movies you'll see from 2012, and one of the best animated ones. If you're like me, this came and went at the theaters without catching it. Now's your chance--it really is worth the rental or purchase.

I love the Scottish accents, the characters, and quality of animation!  But the storyline was the typical boring storyline....Princess is forced to find a mate, doesn't want to get married, but forced by parents, finds true love!  Boring!  Been done for decades!
We used this for the Christmas movie at school, the kids loved it.  It's fun to listen to them laugh and giggle.

I originally bought this because my son loves Shrek and I had seen all the movies way too many times (sorry big green guy).  I was hoping that maybe it was the accent that he liked and this would add some variety to our viewing.  Turns out it was the accent that he liked and the the three "princes" entertain him greatly.  It also turns out that I learned this is one of the most beautiful stories ever put in a movie (let alone animated).  There is something for everyone.  What I truly love is the optimistic outlook the movie ends on and the beautiful scenery throughout.

GOOD PRICE FOR A POPULAR MOVIE. ALTHOUGH  I DO WISH THAT DISNEY WOULD MAKE A BUNDLE WITH JUST A REGULAR DVD AND BLURAY IN IT. ITS NOT NECESSARY TO HAVE ALL 5 DVDS, BUT IS THE ONLY WAY TO GET A BLURAY ONE.

I love that Disney now has a princess that does not need a prince to be complete or to rule her kingdom. Yes!!!!!!

The Pixar formula is just a bit too omnipresent here. The jokes, the characters, the story beats, all so familiar and predictable that it's hard not to feel a little disappointed. The first trailers and images of this film really gave me the impression that Pixar was trying to push their story telling boundaries a little harder, but not so. It's an enjoyable film, beautiful designs and color work, great animation as always... but nothing out of the ordinary for Pixar. They took no chances at all I'm afraid. And let's be honest, they can afford to take a few chances.

Mulan was the closest perhaps.  But think about it, in must female lead animated movies, even the heroine gets rescued or saved by a man.  Why not give the girls a real role model.  Merida (spelling?) comes really really close.  Not the best Pixar effort, but the subject content is good, and our girls Love it.  That along make it worth it.

I have fallen off being a big Disney fan, of late. I think the superior movie making skills of Dream Works has spoiled me. That said, Brave has gone a long way in redeeming Disney in my eyes. I rented it mostly because it features three of my favorite actors with Emma Thompson doing a lovely job as Queen Elinore and Billy Connelly as King Fergus and Julie Walters as the Witch. Kelly MacDonald is spot on as Merida and Craig Ferguson and Robbie Coltrane are wonderful, as always. It's visually stunning and the celtic music is wonderful. The story is as unbelievable as...well, Sherik, but hey it is a cartoon, ( I mean "animated feature")~eye roll~. I thoroughly enjoyed this charming movie and intend to buy the 3D version.

Her hair is incredible, the mystical feel of everything in a time when myth and magic were part of common life, all of it lends itself beautifully to this amazing movie. Thanks again, Pixar!

So, I'm not sure what they were collectively smoking when they chose to make the Scottish Disney Princess film into a bear movie (pretty sure Disney already did this concept in Brother Bear), but that's what Brave is.

It is beautiful to look at.  The story is cute.  The personality of the princess is adorable.  Her hair is the star of the film...and it is wonderful.  She doesn't run off with a prince she's known for 3 days at the end of the movie to live happily ever after.

That's the good stuff.  Now, for the bad:

The film is a rehash of Brother Bear with a girl instead of a boy and with a parent relationship rather than a sibling.  There is no discernible moral in the story, really, except a horribly written attempt at admonishing mothers to "just listen" to their recalcitrant adolescent daughters.  Stupid moral.

It's worth watching.  Kids will love it.  It's gorgeous.  The brothers in the story are funny.  But...it's not going to be one of the Disney greats.
They just keep pumping them out, enjoyed the fiesty girl but she did learn a lesson. I'll watch it again.

This is not a typical pixar film. It's like Beauty and the Beast + the Little Mermaid + some other new age hippie film I can't think of. I actually regretted watching this which I have never said about any Pixar film.

Saw the previews of this on TV and thought that we would check it out. It's better than the previews, and a good addition
to our collection.
The animation looks amazing! The plot was cheesy/ warm and fuzzy, but good message. It managedd to sneek in a little grown up humor too.
Very entertaining. Lovable characters and a lot of action and story. Never got bored, was very entertaining. Would recommend this movie to others.

A very family friendly film with lots of laughs and beautiful animation.  What was unexpected was usually these movies have a love story, good vs evil story line, however this movie was more about family dynamics, specifically the relationship between mother and daughter.  So in that regards not at all what I expected, but it was an enjoyable movie.  Awesome?  No, great, yes.

Great movie and again a wonderful Short from Pixar. Great for all the family. Lots of extras on DVDs and Digital Copy great to have for kids to watch on long car journeys.

Great movie, story line and strong heroine.  My daughter loves this movie.

I love the fact that Pixar has Finally made a Princess movie! I have always loved pixar(I remember when Toy Story caom out) And was very excited to learn about this one!

I love the fact that is about a young lady standing up for herself, and doing what she thinks is right. Also, it veers away from the typical princess movie in the way that it does not involve any kind of romance for the heroine. It is different, and that is what I love about it!

My little girl really wanted to see this movie and my husband thought it looked good so the whole family went to see this one in theatres. Now I really didn't want to go sit through yet another animated movie AT the movies so I dreaded it. The movie was over before I realized it because it was just so good. This is one animated movie that is easy to get lost in because the story is so different from all the other princess stories out there. I loved it and so did the whole family. In fact my youngest daughter has declared her next birthday party to be a "Brave" party and the whole family is super excited about it. We really, really liked this movie! This is definitely one to buy because you'll want to see it more than once.

saw it over the summer and my kids said to me when it was over - mommy we need to buy it when it comes out on DVD.

My wife and I were skeptical at first that it would appeal to adults who were staying in on the weekend, but there's tons of entertainment in there for all ages. And, it's a beautiful story.

Definitely recommend whether you're a kid or adult and are looking for a good movie for the weekend!

Wanted to watch Monsters Inc on amazon instant play but it was temporarily unavailable, probably due to the fact that its currently in theaters. So my boyfriend and I settled on this since the comedian Craig Ferguson was one of the voice actors in it, so we expected it to be funny. If you're a 20 year old couple, I don't recommend it. There were some funny moments but it was very slow moving and not what we were looking for. If you want a Disney Pixar movie that's also entertaining, watch Ratatouille!

Brave is really great.  It's not the pinnacle of Pixar's catalogue, by far, but it's a solid film with memorable characters and a lot to say about family, community, tradition, and individuality.  Well worth your time.

I have not seen this movie yet only of the trailer..looks so cute and I bought one for my 30 year old daughter actually...she has auburn hair, and loves cute movies and has her first house so I thought it'd be cute to buy this in addition to some other type movies so that she can build a library of movies in her new home of all kinds....it looked so cute in the trailer I watched on amazon that I ended up ordering one for our family as well....I cant wait to watch it with the kids soon.  Shipping was timely as well as good packaging thank you:)
Good story and excellent animation. I watched ii twice. A different twist on an old fairy tale. I found it to be most entertaining.

I was looking forward to this movie as a father of two girls, because there are not enough children's movies with female leads especially non-princess female leads, and until now Pixar has always made excellent and touching movies (or at least enjoyable when in the case of Cars 2). I thought Pixar could make a movie about a female lead where the plot doesn't revolve around whether or not she gets married but apparently not. There are decisions that women face throughout their lives other than whether or not to marry. I also assumed that they could give a female character the lead while having respectable male supporting characters but they couldn't. Every single male character in this movie is a physically deformed half-wit mutant. The only halfway like able male characters are Merida's father and brothers and they're still portrayed as immature morons. The brothers are barely portrayed as humans. They never speak and spend the entire movie stealing food and never show any emotional reaction to any of the bizarre events that freak out everyone else.  At one point they get turned into bears but nothing about them changes except for they grow fur. The previews made it look like an epic adventure but most of the movie takes place in the castle and most of the action is comedic misunderstandings and deceptions. What I thought was going to be an epic adventure starring a female lead turned out to be a cliched 90's girl power comedy of errors.

If the movie had only been disappointing then I would have given it 3 stars but there was far to much nudity in it for me to consider it appropriate for small children. In one scene we several men's butts for several seconds and in another we see Merida's brothers butts. My children did not think this was shocking. They actually thought it was funny which is a problem in my opinion. It is very difficult to explain context to children. They see nudity in a cartoon as comedy their going to think that nudity in other situations is comedy too and I doubt very many people consider a man exposing his butt to children as comedy. Most people would consider him a pervert and he could go to prison and be registered as a sex offender for the rest of his life. My wife and I already have a hard enough time trying to convince our daughters that exposing their butts to us is inappropriate without Disney and Pixar telling them it's comedy. Luckily our girls haven't  exposed themselves at school to get a laugh but as more cartoons show nudity as comedy more kids will expose themselves in public thinking that makes them funny.

Brave isn't the only children's cartoon to do this either. Why is it every children's cartoon that shows someone's butt for comedy shows a man's or boy's butt. Brave seemed to try very hard to come up with situations to show every male character naked and to cover up the female character the one time she would have been naked. Why is male nudity comedy gold while female nudity is inappropriate?
My daughter and I have been watching Disney together since she was a baby (almost). She is 19 now and we still enjoy our time with a good disney movie.

It was fun and enjoyable. Good humor and likeable characters. It was a good children's story with a good lesson. I thought the bear animation was especially well done. The bears moved like real bears.

Great movie and very entertaining.  The family really liked the colors, and the story was clear and entertaining.  we've watched it maybe 3 times, we'll watch it again in about 6 months.

My wife and I were really disappointed with Brave.  We have loved all of the Pixar movies (except the Cars series).  What we love the most about Pixar is how intelligent, heartfelt, and truly funny their movies are.  They never stoop down to potty humor for easy laughs.  Well, Brave is not the Pixar we know and love.  It is Disney's Pixar:  more generic, more lowbrow, more mass-market.  I was actually a little bored watching it.  There's potty humor and naked butts, too.  Definitely not the Pixar that created the masterpieces Up, Monsters Inc., and Finding Nemo.  I hope their next movie is a winner.  I would say that Brave, Cars, and Cars II are all sub-Pixar standards.
All I can say is that it is an animated movie that can be watched by both a grandfather and his grand daughter and both will enjoy it equally.

The animated movie, "BRAVE", is an excellent family adventure for all the proud wee Scots (and those who WISH they were!).

I very highly recommend this show for an evening of family fun.
I love this movie and it was for a fair price, so if you are a Brave fan but don't want to pay for all the extras other dvds bring, then you should buy this.

My grand daughter was thrilled to receive this movie for Christmas.  I was not able to watch it with her, but was told by my son that it was a great movie. Would tell anyone that my granddaughter loved it.
Our 2 year old daughter loves this movie.  She runs around yelling for "Merda" (her version of Merida).  We like that Brave has strong women characters for our daughter to look up to.

I was so happy with everything! The delivery was quick, Brave Blu-ray DVD arrived in perfect condition, the little girl I gave it to was extremely happy to receive it, I watched the movie from start to finish and it was a perfect DVD - no skipping or scratches or sound problems, it was perfect!
Thank you so much!

Have you ever considered how rare a mother is in a Disney animated film? Usually there is no mother or she is killed off quickly. This story might explain why because the teen's wish is that her mother would change so she could be free to become the woman she desires. She gets her wish by placing her mother in danger. This movie gets so much about teens right, including the normal self-absorption, lack of responsibility and wild pendulum swings between child and woman. The story encourages parents to nurture their daughter's strengths, not just their traditions. The girl's hair is practically a character in its own right so much time is spent on its rendering, just as it is in most teen girl's lives.

If you're of Celtic background this will be a particular delight. There are stereotypes of Celtic behavior, but how do you ground a cultural story without them?

Enjoy.
enjoyed this in the theater and at home, beautifuly animated and a great soundtrack too.  one of my favorite amimated movies of the year
Cute movie, with a cute red head and storyline about her relationship with her mother. Very sweet movie, kids and adults like it.
Good movie for the kids and adults. I would recommend this movie. It was not that long,but it kept the kids attention the whole movie.
This movie is so cute. I loved it and so did the kids. I totally recommend this as a family movie night
lots of action and humor.  I liked the story of a rebelious teenage girl- alot of kids can relate to that.  the twins we adorable
Bought this item for my daughter for Christmas - she is still a kid at heart and will enjoy this movie with her boys.

This movie was so amazing I would like to watch it 100more times in a row, and I would probably cry every time. Merida was so  brave (obviously), but when her mother got turned into a bear and wouldn't go back to human form when Merida put the blanket on her, my entire family started crying! Great movie.

I knew next to nothing about the plot of this film besides it being about a headstrong girl that with a mop of red hair. I was pleasantly surprised by the touching story. While I found myself identifying with the girl, my wife felt the girl was more to blame instead of the mom like I concluded. Regardless, the movie was funny, charming, very colorful and vibrant and nicely animated. I would have given it 5 stars but my wife insisted on 4 because the two songs that were sung, the artists had no accent while singing and she felt it did not match the thick accents of the cast very well. Overall, as an adult, I felt this was a very good movie that was fun and entertaining that also had a point to make while not being heavy handed.
This movie was interesting graphically, but the plot, the characters, and the annoyingly adolescent mayhem of the star were unappealing. The worst Pixar movie we've seen.
Good story line, good moral to the story, and good animation.  If you are Scottish, the movie is an added delight since it is based in Scotland.  What's not to like?

I bought this movie for my daughter for Christmas to add to our Disney collection. She is a red headed, green eyed girl who thought Meridia was amazing. Very cute movie for the entire family to watch.
It's a great Disney movie - both for adults and children - and really speaks to those of us Scot ladies who know that the spirit of Scotland is alive in women as well as men!
This item was shipped fast and was of great quality enjoyed watching this again and again with my daughter we love Disney movies

I watched this movie because my son enjoyed it. I thought the storyline would have been more about saving her clan, village, etc other the relationship between her and her mother. That being said the movie itself was entertaining but not a major hit.
It was a good movie, but definitely not my favorite Disney or Pixar movie by a long shot. The story is good, the art is good, there's just something missing that I can't name.
My family loves this movie and it is a lot of fun to watch. We still watch it at least once a week.
Among the better Pixaresque animated films. Definitely fun for the Family. Don't want to give anything away just watch it.

Great movie!  I loved it.  Was a little intense for my kiddos at times, but they are little (5 and 3.5).  We all loved the humor and the story, just some of the bear scenes are really scary for them.  Personally, I thought it was hilarious and exciting and wonderful.  I love Billy Connolly, and he was fantastic in this movie.  The story is excellent, it's funny and heart-warming, and the picture and music are excellent.  Overall, right up my alley.

I watched the movie Brave with my family and we all really enjoyed it.  Be sure to grab a box of tissues beforehand as there are some tear jerking scenes.  The story is about a queen who is training her daughter into becoming a princess and according to tradition, a prince is selected to marry the princess upon proving himself through competitions.  The princess wants her own freedom to choose and fights with her mother on this.  She symbolically tears her mother out of the family by cutting a tapestry with the family in it and seeks a witch to help her mother change.  Her mother does change, but not her heart, rather she becomes a bear.  The story is a lesson of choosing freedom over tradition.  It is also about a love shared between family members that is unbreakable since Merida instantly regrets what she did to her mother and will go to any lengths to bring her back.  The movie is action packed.  Unlike many of the Disney princess movie, this one lacks on the romantic side, however this only adds to the movies uniqueness.  It is more family based than romantic based.  Very good movie to watch with the family.

I just love this story and the quality of the animation.  We are starting to slow down on how many dvds we get so, we are getting pickier about which ones we buy.  This is such a good movie.  My 10 year old son also loves the movie.
Yes you can watch this movie and enjoy it. Best of all is not too violent, the kids really liked it

This is a great story.  The colors and animation is unbelievable.  Everyone should watch this movie.  I believed that there would be some killing in the cartoon, but I was glad to be disappointed.  Great movie...you must watch.
I would give this an A+ rating.  My daughter, grandson and I saw it at the theater and we were glad that it came out on DVD before Christmas.  I would recommend purchase of this to anyone.
This is the best princess movie in my opinion. It has a great moral. I wish more films were like this one.
Amazing quality. Great watch for the entire family. Glad the rental time is up to 48 hours. Nice place to watch new movies not available on Netflix.
This is a really good movie. It was a little too long for the 5 year old, but perfect for the 8 year old.
It was really great to see a Disney fantasy fairy tale-ish movie where the heroine DIDN'T go ga-ga over a prince. The animation is lovely as always and the voices are a perfect fit.

I saw this movie in theaters and loved it.  It's not just a kids' movie.  It's a movie that I enjoy watching.  The Blu-ray quality is impeccable and it really gives Pixar's amazing animation the showcase it deserves.
The 3D is this movie is fantastic. Since installing a 3D home theater in our basement, I have been collecting 3D titles. This one is near the top, along with Avatar, the Avengers and the Lorax.

good movie the grandkids really love it

kept the kids attention glued to the tv

would recommend this movie to anyone with kids

Not a very clever storyline, basically the movie Brother Bear (Disney) without the funny moose.

Pixar junkies give me a hard time about describing it like that, but they all say the same thing: "Yeah, but Pixar wasn't working on the story, they were working on HAIR in this movie!"

Well, she does have hair. Big hair. But I thought they did hair pretty well in Monsters Inc. And if you're really worried about getting good hair, don't pick a huge mass of red curls (that's going to look animated just because it's outrageously red), pick slightly curled brown hair that reacts the the moisture in the air by frizzing halfway through the day.

Not much storywise, not a compelling plot, very predictable. Maybe good for kids? I don't know, probably a little scary. A lot of angry bears.

What you seen in the trailer is basically the first several minutes of the movie. I thought the movie would be about a strong independent woman like the movie Tangled but it's not. The final battle is not even between the main character and the bad guy. Also the movie was very scary for my 5  year old
Well, this is just delightful! I love the Scottish accents and the story was fun! I would recommend this  DVD

another great Pixar movie that while it is a lovely female themed lesson its value is for both sexes --- a fun movie with great voice acting by major hollywood actors.  typical flawless Pixar animation and a nice story with a genuinely good lesson for kids and adults.  entertaining and funny as well. The extras are fun but not really that much  but you do have a physical DVD so there you go.

My son wanted to watch and so I'd the rest of the family so we watched and loved it glad we own it and it is in my library on line. We can watch any time anywhere with wifi. Or down load it to my iPad  great.

I got this for my kids  for Christmas, tis is one of the funniest movies I've seen in a while. Disney made another great movie.
I can watch it over and over.

I gave this to my granddaughter for Christmas.  She said she had seen it in the movie theater and did not mention anything untoward about it.  I however found the bears quite unsettling for one so young.  She is 3 &3/4 years.  She climbed up in my lap when the bears were fighting. I was able to reassure her, by telling her the bear, which was her mother after a spell was put on her, was fighting to protect her little girl.  She saw the fight in a different light after that.  A little scary for the timid child.

No matter how trite the representation is (she's breaking free from the constraints of traditional roles, literally, bursting out of her ladylike outfit as she looses arrows) people will make excuses for this ham-fisted feminism because they're determined to play counter to traditional Disney princesses. The problem is this movie has zero of the charm of movies like Snow White, none of the fun characters, ridiculous 'According to Jim'-like portrayals of the majority of males, and an incredible lack of a real powerful villain such as we saw in past movies like Little Mermaid. It's too bad as it wastes Pixar's best visual effort, full of sprawling landscapes and great rendering on the main character's wild hair. After the mess of Cars 2 (and Cars 1 for that matter) it's unfortunate that Pixar is going in the wrong direction, but hey at least now people can stop whining that they haven't had a female lead in any of their movies.
This s a really great movie. Watched it with the grand kids & they loved it! Now, one of our favorites.

Very nice!  Love the animation, music, characters and accents!  Extremely well developed or it couldn't bring tears! A great family TV / movie nite show for all ages.  VERY WORTH A VIEWING!

If you haven't seen this movie, but just heard the hype so far, you will not be disappointed.  That was me last year until I saw it for the first time after a friend loaned me hers.  My daughters are 3 and 1, my step daughter is almost 18, and my husband is almost 38, and we all love it!  My 3 year old has discovered the princess world and I was not overly excited about the negative stereotypes surrounding Disney 'beauty' and the role of a girl as a princess.  Disney impressed me with this movie and not just because of the graphics and soundtrack (we have downloaded several MP3's, the music is absolutely beautiful) but because they finally created a strong female character that denounces marriage to choose her own path and the family dynamics are quality and heartfelt.  As a mom, I cried.  It's a story mainly about a mother and a daughter and it's amazing.  We laugh every time because the humor is funny and age appropriate but still makes us adults laugh as well.  I never object when they request this move (we have one in the car and the other in the house DVD player) because I enjoy it just as much.  This particular one was a great price and it comes with both a regular DVD and a blu-ray disc.  Definitely recommend this :)
Disney movies always seem to be good. I do think they're running out of ideas. This movie is good with some very funny parts, but not as good as I'd hoped for. It's worth watching atleast once.

This is such an adorable movie.  My kids love to watch it.  Please keep in mind parents that television should always be monitored and she be used in moderation.  With that being said, Brave is an adorable movie

I ordered this collector's edition for my daughter for Christmas.  The DVD plays well and we love the movie (we saw it in the theater last summer).  However, the blue-ray disc ("regular", not the 3-D version) has a spot in it where the movie gets "stuck".  I thought it was just a glitch with the blu-ray disc, so I returned the entire collection for another one (which arrived quickly - kudos to Amazon!).  I was disgusted when the "new" blu-ray had the exact same problem.  Apparently the companies who manufacture these products don't care about the quality.  I will be contacting Disney/Pixar directly to complain about the fact that they mass-produced an inferior product.  I still gave the collection 3 stars since the DVD and the "extras" all play well and we truly love the movie - and Amazon's shipping was fantastic!
We love this movie, adults enjoyed it as well as our 6 yo boy and 4 yo girl. The scary parts were not too much and the story was fun with a strong message.

I didn't feel like this was the best movie ever put out by Pixar but considering their track record, is still a compliment.  I was a bit surprised by the naked butts in one scene.  It seemed more like humor one would find in a Dreamworks production.  The tale of a teenage daughter becoming more independent and the complex relationship it causes with her mother, is a tale as old as time.
Family safe, and entertaining in many respects. The story was compelling and seemingly original to me, with plenty of small funny asides.
I love Brave!  The movie was cute, funny, scary in some parts and it teaches you a lesson.  I will watch it over & over.

Great movie. It's so great to see a disney movie that is not about romantics. Instead it's a very unique and sweet story about a mother and daughter. The detail and graphics were excellent and the cast really drew me into the story. I really enjoyed watching this over and over again with my four year old niece who like to act like the little bear brothers, while I personally and secretly wish that I had Merida's archery skill, (and her beautiful Shire horse.:)) Definitely full of giggles, thrills, suspense and even a touching tear jerker moment.

I'm a huge Disney buff. I am 24 and have no children of my own but I collect anything "Disney Princess" and so of course I was very excited to hear we were getting a new princess. My son was resistant to watching it at first, but now he requests it as much as his sister - they love it. Very stunning visual presentation. Disc wouldn't play on my cheapo player without freezing up right at the beginning every time, so I can only play it on my regular, name-brand player.

OK, so what is not to like?  Pixar focuses it's remarkable talents on a tale of a young princess (natch) growing up in medieval Scotland.  Since it is Disney, you know that there will be an attempt at a heart-warming message.  The plot itself is rather linear - girl is special, girl rebels, girl causes problem, girl fixes problem.  The positive message is one of taking action to control ones existence, but understanding the effect of your actions on others.  Merida is another strong willed Disney heroine.

What is great is the comic undertone of the entire movie, the supporting characters, other than the serious mother, are uniformly hilarious.  Most scenes display a humorous whimsey that wins you over, from the clan chieftans to Merida's little brothers (always after baked goods).  The animation is great, with wonderful landscapes, animals, and, of course, Merida's fire red hair.

We bought the movie without having seen it before.  Overall my family liked the movie.  I missed the music and singing that usually happen in a Disney princess movie.  My 4-year-old daughter was a little scared at parts.  Not as well developed as other Disney princess movies.
Brave is a very cute family movie with incredible graphics. If you can, try to watch in HD on a big screen.
This was a birthday present for my little cousins, they hadn't seen it yet, so they were super excited to open this and loved it!

Like other reviewers, our copy of Brave would not play past a few minutes, the audio cut out, and the frames skipped. We were, however, able to resolve this problem.
If this is happening with your copy, try this: After selecting 'play movie', switch your audio to 'Channel 2'. This completely resolved all issues we were having. We were so excited!! I thought we were going to have to return our copy, believing it to be defective, but that is not the case.  There seems to be an issue with Disney and their True HD audio (which is the default 'channel 1' selection for the movie).
Hope this works for others--just thought I'd share.
love disney anyway but this was a great movie I took granddaughter to and they each got the dvd for christmas and wached it x-mas day love it.

- sorry to say, but the story line was weak, and I am not a girl having (teenage) issues with my mother to be able to relate to this one. Regardless who was the target audience, is this really made so that there's a first major female character done by Pixar? What about pre-teen kids? It felt as if too many categories and groups of people were supposed to be covered (somehow) and it did not work out, as it always does with trying to be commercial and appropriate....
Finally, a Disney princess with both parents intact! We need more movies to help teach that the world will fall apart if families don't stick together

My wife wanted to see it and I watched it with her.  It had a good story and I enjoyed the music and cinamatography of the animation.  It was funny and enjoyable and had a good message.

We received this DVD on time and in perfect condition.  We've all thoroughly enjoyed watching it. Being from Ireland, we love the scenery of Scotland and their accents...hard to believe it's animated!!  I would recommend this DVD to our friends. Thank you!
Great movie! Its very entertaining for kids and adults as well. There are some parts of the movie that are a little scary for my 3 years old girl, but she still loves to watch it with me.

Weak tea. Don't bother. The storyline is insipid and uninspired and entirely predictable. The characters are pretty standard cliches with little (if any) development during the course of the movie. The music is cloying and generic Lilith Fair derivatives. And it really has very little to do with bravery. Disney hit it out of the park this time - there is nothing better than a strong heroine, and Merida shows that the girl doesn't always need a prince to help her win the day.  Perfect movie for my girls - it is not as musical as most Disney shows are these days, which is not necessarily a plus for us, as we love the music, but the plot is very strong and teaches a valuable lesson to little girls (and boys!).....

This movie was very entertaining . The take away is that you can't be selfish and you must think of how you actions can hurt others.

Growing up a hardcore tomboy, I was the little girl that defied the sterotype and honestly never did dream of being a princess. If Brave had come out when I was kid though...it would have been a different story.

Great story. Awesome characters. The most fantastically wild red hair *ever*! A refreshing dose of realizm about what being a princess was really like. A happy ending *without* a Prince Charming. I'm one of those Pixar fans that is willing to put money down on any film Pixar produces -- before I even know what it is.  I have such faith in the company that I know I'll enjoy the film regardless of what it's about.

While I very much enjoyed Brave, I have to admit that it is possibly the worst Pixar film yet.  In terms of technical quality, it rocks!  Fantastic animation, color grading, effects, and sound.  Brilliant!!  The story, however, is a bit tired and predictable -- and that's where my only disappointment comes in.  There isn't much new under the sun... but Pixar has found ways, in previous films, to bring something new to the screen in every scene.  So, even if you know "the good guy is going to win and get the girl in the end" they still find ways to make the whole ride a 'new' experience.  But I didn't get that experience with this film.  In fact, I could almost see every scene coming before it arrived on the screen -- it was that predictable.  There were some original moments in the film, but just not enough to keep me interested.

Ultimately, I was a happy customer watching this film... but for the first time with a Pixar film I can honestly say that I don't need to watch it a second time (keep in mind that I have not seen Cars 2 yet -- which my wife says she doesn't care to watch a second time -- so maybe there will be two Pixar films that I don't find "above average").

Rebellious Scottish princes Merida, a teenager pressured to choose a future husband so her parents can arrange the marriage, instead argues with her mother and runs away to prove her independence (it's really nice, in a Pixar/Disney film, to see a princess not waiting around for a man to marry or rescue her!).  In the forest, mystical will-o-the-wisps (who Merida has been brought up believing can lead one to his or her destiny) lead the princess to the modest home of a wacky witch, who provides Merida with a spell that will change her mother, the queen, into seeing her side.  The spell changes the queen all right, but goes horribly wrong, and from her on the story is one about mothers and daughters, bravery and loyalty, and a message about finding one's own destiny within.  Beautifully done, beautiful to watch, and another winner from Pixar.
