This film was generally well-received by critics and audiences alike, so I went in expecting what most Disney films deliver: family-friendly content that normally doesn't require any serious emotional or intellectual investment.  I actually laughed out loud at a few parts, which surprised me.  When I saw the trailer, I thought the humor was going to be obnoxious crap in a desperate attempt to appeal to the younger audience, but I was pleased with the way it was done.

The storyline is a bit strange.  Because the main character, Merida, wants to be free, she has a witch perform a spell to "change" her mother.  This "change" involved her turning into a horse.  The rest of the film consists of Merida trying to break the spell and bring her mother back into human form.  Okay, I can try to accept the odd storyline.  It is a kid's movie, after all.  But here's where I have a problem: The witch tells Merida to remember a phrase.  I don't remember it because everyone in the film has Scottish accents, so it was hard enough trying to comprehend what they were saying.  This phrase is supposed to be so important that the witch repeats it.  After this, we never hear the phrase again.  What was the point of spending that much screen time on something that won't be brought up again?  More organization in the script could've made this a better film.

There was one thing I really liked about this film: the climax.  There is an awesome scene where we get to see two bears fight.  For a Disney film, it was actually really intense, which is an unusual but welcome feeling to experience in a film of this caliber.  This film was also funny, specifically when Merida is trying to sneak her bear mother past a group of townspeople.  Also, who doesn't enjoy seeing a bear dive down a big-breasted woman's blouse to get a key?  I give two thumbs up for the comedy in this film; the timing was spot-on and targeted several different age groups.

To wrap things up, Brave is a colorful and funny film that lacks a solid script.  I really want to check out more Disney films in the future so I can keep in check my thoughts about the studio.  Disney usually does a good job of making great family films, but not always.  I liked Brave and I like the direction Disney is heading in.  If they continue to make films as enjoyable as this one, you can expect more Disney reviews from me.

Brave was an outstanding movie. The quality of the animation done by PIXAR gets better and better every year. This movie was not short on quality. The sound and pictures were simply amazing. There were times during the movie I wanted to say, "Wow... isn't the scenery beautiful?"

The plot of the movie was good, and it was nice to have a heroine take the lead role. In addition, the movie was hilarious! There were so many funny parts. Although a Disney movie, there were quite a few scary parts that young children would find frightening.

The major downside (and the reason it's only 4 stars) to this 3-disc Blu-ray set was the special features. I was very interested in the Scottish accents and the actors that did the voices (they were all native Scotts), but the special feature on them was only a few minutes long. The rest of the special features were not much better. With a separate blu-ray disk dedicated to the features, I was expecting a lot more.

In all, I was quite pleased with it, and definitely recommend it.

This is just a spectacular animated story.  Merida is the Princess daughter of King Fegus and the beautiful Queen Elinor.  Her mother wants her to be a perfect princess and a lady but Merida is a tom boy at heart with a passion for challenges and archery and she is really fearless.  When it comes time to match her up with a suitable suitor for a husband from the sons of the clan tribe leaders, Merida has her own ideas. She wants to be able to make her own decisions about how she will live her life....

This is a very cute story and the CGI graphics were outstanding. This is a five star movie and it is an excellent film for children and adults alike.  The graphics design and animation of the film were some of the best that I have seen and the story line for the film was dramatic but well thought through.  The accents and the voices selected for the characters was just as well selected and performed.

My wife and I thought the film had a good premise and it was great to see how the movie flowed and it never left the plot line, sticking to the final goal until the impeccable and exciting ending.  Disney and Pixar have another hit on their hands.  The film also had an excellent song track with some good music and songs and it really is a full package when it comes to an entertaining CGI adventure film.

And indeed , it is, even if we never quite see Merida's strength.  We can see her bravery, because bravery is not always about adventurousness, but sing the courage to admit you are wrong and to try and change to become a better person.  That is real courage, because it can be more difficult that courage in the face of physical danger.

I saw this film with my granddaughter, who is nine. She was entranced, I was pleased. Disney and Pixar has given us an unusual twist to the Princess, gruff King, loving queen mother story.

The Princess is Merida with the voice of the wonderful Scottish actress Kelly Macdonald. Merida is an a red haired Scottish tomboy whose life is changed by an early birthday gift of a bow, which quickly inspires her to become the best archer in the kingdom. Then we move to Merida as a young lady of marriageable age, who is angered by a request from Queen Elinor voice-over by Emma Thompson, to choose among three possible husbands chosen by her clan. Merida wants none of them and escapes to the forest after winning the archery contest. One event after another occur and the queen becomes a bear after a magic spell is cast. The search for god and evil occurs, and in the process new love and devotion come to the fore. All is right with the world after battles and barriers are broken down.

This is not one of the ground breaking Pixar films, but good enough. The Scottish countryside seems almost real, beautifully crafted characters and background.

The story seems to have been built around the idea that admitting ones mistakes requires bravery. I would wholeheartedly agree with this. However, the main characters actions are not what I would consider a clear example to the under 13 crowd of bravely admitting your mistakes. Instead, it seemed to me most of the movie is about the young lady trying to prevent the truth from coming to light and helping her mother cope with the results of her actions. The large reliance on magic for plot advancement doesn't win points with me either. I would have preferred a message that conveyed the importance of admitting mistakes promptly and that asking for help if it is needed in addressing the consequences. The later requires an equal amount of bravery in my mind. Probably my biggest issue with the movie-and a completely subjective one- is simply that I expected something very different. I thought it was going to be about a young lady taking charge of her destiny in a man dominated world and instead, this is where the movie ends.

If you have little bears at home this movie will be well received. Second to How to Train Your Dragon for the kids' favorite movie. Great quality streaming from Amazon Instant Video, too. No skipping even on poor internet connection.

This movie shows girls that there is nothing wrong with being strong in theirselves and we could definitely use more of that.

Edit: Scottish, not Irish.
Expectation: Feel-good story about a courageous girl with great graphics.

Reality: Great graphics provide real life detail for content that is not for young children. I wish I had read the Amazon paid reviewer who stated that the move wasn't suitable "for those under 10 years" prior to purchasing the movie. Lesson learned.  The content included a lot of violence and some animated nudity (I'm unsure why animated nudity is different than actual nudity anymore because there is such a high level of detail).  Are animated sex scenes ok since they are `just' animated?  Anyway, back to the review. In terms of content the movie is a poorly written chop job. The writers worked hard to negatively stereotype the Scottish as apparently moronic idiots who can't keep their pants up while forgoing such trivialities as a plot. There were a few small laughs scattered throughout the movie.

Plot (spoilers):  The story begins with a bear named Mor'dur attacking a family randomly picnicking in the woods.  I'll leave the explanations for the bear's existence to internet research, but suffice to say it is an angry ancestor. The young girl, not wanting to be married to one of the local Irish dolts her mother wishes, has a witch cast a spell on her mother.  As a result of the spell the mother is turned into a bear. Long story short - they run through the castle, there are multiple kilt-raisings, and the mother bear ends up killing the angry ancestor Mor'dur.

Summary: I would not purchase the movie again.  I enjoy watching movies with my daughter in which she can observe strong female lead characters portray positive role models while telling an entertaining story.  With Brave, Disney obscured a good tomboy princess idea with bear chicanery and idiotic, imbecilic behavior by every male character in the movie.  The resulting product is neither entertaining nor positive.

I'm an adult and got talked into watching this movie.  The animations are beautiful  and it is a well done movie, but I found the story to have a somewhat forced moral at the end, definitely a kids focused movie but entertaining enough for anyone to sit through.

The Scottish stereotypes are as demeaning as you'd expect, but like stereotypes satisfyingly familiar (I say this as a Scot).  It's sort of like you feel like you've arrived if Disney or whoever is depicting you, even if they're bludgeoning you at the same moment.  Ah well.

Best part?  The utterly feminist workings of the plot where (spoiler alert) she doesn't have to marry anyone in the end, and doesn't have to masculinize herself (okay, a tiny bit at first--but she quickly realizes her mistake there and backtracks) in order to avoid becoming a wife.

Of course it does have that weird thing happening to women these days in film where they're made sexy by being given a bow and being ultimately proficient with it, a la Diana (the Goddess, not the demised Princess).  To a certain extent, you become hotter by being a female with a bow and a male with a bristling gun of some sort.  Oye.  But her empowerment here is only accentuated by the prowess with the bow.  It was there in her refusal to be objectified first.  Who gave her that and how it go there is up for further critique.

quickly become a Disney favorite- we went to Disney a week after purchasing this and there was already reference to Princess Merida in the park (especially Frontier's land)

Princess Merida is a firey red-head who does not want to be promised as a bride to another Irish clan- she fights with her mother and then runs away from the castle only to find a witch in a wooded cave. Merida makes a deal with this witch who casts a spell on Merida's mother (who wants her to marry another clan's son and unite two Irish tribes). Merida's mother becomes a bear- if they can't reverse the spell in enough time the spell will become permanent.

I am an adult Disney fan and I found parts of this movie VERY scary and inappropriate for young children. The bad character (Merdu the bear) was terrifying- very scary- and the fight scenese with said bear were equally uncomfortable.

There are a few Irish songs in this movie but nothing very catchy that left you wanting to replay them with children or do a sing-a-long.

What I did find interesting of this movie is: there is no love interest. Merida is the heroine - and there is no male lead to come in and help her save the day. There is no prince for this princess - and she is just A OK (more so) with that. I thought this was very 21st century of Disney and feel they are very Brave for putting out a movie/story such as this.

Overall, this will be another Disney classic but does not meet the ranks of some of the other Disney hits (such as Nemo or Tangled).

I felt this movie was closer to what Pixar wants to do and less of a 'Disney' movie.

The first time I saw Brave, I didn't think it had quite as much pizzazz as the other Pixar films before it; After a second watching, I realized that this film is just as great, but in different ways. The film features voice actors not as well known as other Pixar films, but the cinematography alone will blow your mind for an animated film. Yes, the characters look cartoonish, but everything else (the sets, costumes, atmosphere, even the weather) look SO real and beautiful that this film is worth owning on that point alone. This film was probably the darkest Pixar movie I've seen up until this point; I think they were going for a much more serious and mysterious plot line instead of some of their earlier, "brighter" films like Cars or Toy Story. The DVD has some nice extras, including two short films and DVD Commentary. It could have used a bit more extras, but overall I am very happy to say I own this movie!
Being of Scottish heritage I had to watch this even though I am an adult!  It was a cute story, I would recommend it.

Brave is a 2012 American computer-animated adventure fantasy film produced by Pixar Animation Studios and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Tale focuses upon a girl named Merida coming of age and refusing to follow Scottish traditions of marrying into another noble house to keep the lands at peace. Of course, the tale is written for a 21st century audience because back in the day marrying into families was a way of survival and if you brooked tradition it could mean the death of many including your loved ones but Brave chooses to ignore that historical piece and instead turn this into a modern telling of following your bliss. It works well enough.

Brave is very much of a tale of a daughter and mother mending "the bond torn by pride". In fact, that is arguably the ongoing thematic element of this film and it works on different levels that adults and children can comprehend.

Notable voices by: Emma Thompson, Kevin McKidd, Julie Walters, Robbie Coltrane, Kelly MacDonald and Bill Connolly.

The budget for this film was $135M and it made over $535M at the Box Office. A video game and other spinoffs have resulted. The Golden Globes have nominated this piece for "Best Animated Feature Film". Should we expect a sequel?

ANIMATION: B plus; HUMOR: C plus to B minus; CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE/VOICE ACTING: B to B plus; STORY/PLOTTING/EDITING: B plus; CINEMATOGRAPHY: B plus to A minus; SOUND/MUSIC: A minus to A; WHEN WATCHED: mid December 2012; OVERALL GRADE: B to B plus.

Pixar has been on a slow downhill climb as of late, Brave unfortunately takes a drastic dip from previous outings.  First off , for those who don't know, in the middle of production the director was switched. This isn't that abnormal for Hollywood mind you, but considering Disney was pretty vocal about this being one of Pixar's first female directed movies with a strong female lead it does cause some issues. The switch of directors is very noticeable.

The movie doesn't seem to know what genre or mood it wants to set. One second it's dramatic, the next comedy/slapstick, then something mystic/supernatural, and then something like a poor imitation Ghibli movie. These constant switches are most likely due to the different visions both directors had. To make matters worse the story and characters suffer due to this.

First off the main lead. Merida doesn't change at all throughout the movie. She comes out at the beginning not wanting to follow family tradition, rather her own fate. Yet at the end she just caves in and gives into her fate as dictated by her parents. Yeah, she won't be forced to marry anyone right away, but in the future she will be. So her mother still controls her fate. Overall, Merida is a very passive character not the strong one the movie was advertised as having.

Next is the problem with the story. First off, the throw away characters. The main catalyst for the movie is Merida meeting the witch and getting the potion from her. Why does the witch do this? Is she evil? Good? The fact that the main catalyst is a two-dimensional throw away character shows a lot of the problems this movie went through during development. Basic screenwriting 101- cause and effect. You need a reason for things to happen. Not, I'll give you this potion so the movie can move along.

Next problem. What is this movie supposed to be about? Merida's engagement? Her mother issues? Some old prince who was cursed to become a bear? From these three points brought up in the movie, which one doesn't seem to belong? This movie has too many side stories going on. It's like they just took a bunch of ideas with some vague relation and stuck them together. A lot of the pacing issues could have been solved by removing the part about the cursed prince and filling that empty space with more plot from the other two points.

Another problem is the mother's transformation. She adapts to being a bear to easily. Within hours of being a bear she can already walk on both legs, navigate through narrow corridors, run through the woods, even use silverware with her claws. Disney's Brother Bear does this transformation much better, especially in terms of adaptability.

So, with a weak female lead, poor pacing, paper-thin plot, what does the movie get right? Well, it is beautiful. The animation is simply gorgeous with obvious care given to every detail on landscape and props.

In conclusion, as far as Pixar movies go, this is by far the weakest. Pixar has branded themselves as storytellers, being able to reach both young and old. This is what separates them from many other family movie producing companies. Unfortunately, Pixar seems to drop the ball here with their storytelling.

Imagine Disney/Pixar doing a movie where grown (animated) men are running around butt-naked (no frontal nudity, however), and where there is the scariest bear ever seen in an animated motion picture. Imagine a Disney move (animated or not) where there is no beautiful and vulnerable princess, no prince charming to save her, and no villain to be killed off or banished in the end.

Imagine a movie of any sort where the two strongest characters, whose conflict anchors the plot, are both strong and good women (well, one of them is a teen-ager). And imagine that in this unimaginable movie there are no male villains, just well-intentioned guys who can't see past the status quo when it comes to recognizing that women have brains as well as bodies.

Well, at least there is magic and will-o-the-wisps and a witch (but not a wicked one), and a valuable moral at the core.

My pre-adolescent granddaughters, if you combined them into one, would be the heroine of "Brave" - red hair and all. It was so gratifying to take them to this movie (the 3D adds a lot) not knowing just how fabulous the role modelling would be.

Fun to watch. Excellent animation... uncannily realistic. Good story. Like (almost) all fairy tales the message is right prevails and everything ends happily for the good guys... and the bad guys get their comeuppance. A good message, well delivered. Our grandson enjoyed the movie and understood the message; he was able to tell us what he had learned from it. (Personal comment:  It's tough to balance these kinds of messages with how life actually unfolds... but, maybe reality should be deferred as long as possible.)

It's mind blowing what the artists behind Pixar animation can accomplish with digital tools.  A few minutes into the film and you forget it's animated.  The color and detail are stunning and more importantly the story is good for both genders and all ages unless you're a particularly cold-hearted grumpy sort.  What I particularly liked is that this film is 100% female-positive and empowering without being preachy/feminist to the point of irritation.  It just flatly states that boys/girls should have equal opportunities in life to choose their dreams and their paths.  The story avoids the cliche father/son or boy/girl and instead focuses on mother/daughter in ways not usually seen in films.  Moving beyond the "marry who you have to and love will follow down the road" to an exploration of children needing to rethink their blind rebellion at all costs and parents move beyond blind adherence to legacy traditions that may be antediluvian.  And beyond all that, it's a reference quality HD movie to show off your HDTV/Blu-ray to those who still question the value of HD anything.

This movie is good.  I was pretty riveted by it.  It is a little scary for the smaller set but my kids seemed to not notice and they are 4 and 2.  I did find it perhaps predictable for Pixar.,.maybe could of been more inventive, but the theme of a strong princess who doesn't want the prince, and the focus of the mother daughter relationship was great!  I don't think Merida was portrayed as too bratty really..I mean, kids can be bratty and they do things without realizing the real consequences.  They can be short sited and only think of their wants and needs..I don't think that is bad to show as long as the resolution shows the growth of the character, and their realization to see beyond themselves and have compassion etc etc.  Merida does grow and so does her Mother for that matter.  They clearly love each other but their own preconceived notions and desires get in the way.  I have a very strong willed and feisty daughter and this movie touched me for sure.  It just reminds us that no matter what is going on in our relationship with our children, how furious we get, how furious they get, how many things that are done with haste..we still love each other fiercely and that is always there..sometimes things just get in the way and we must rise above and settle differences.  I think this is an important message to address, and maybe it's an ordinary topic but I'm glad Disney and Pixar addressed it.  It's not a perfect movie but the characters are loveable, esp. the Dad, Merida, the brothers, and the Mom; and the animation is top rate.  Merida's hair animation is reason enough on it's own to watch this movie!

Brave is another great leap forward in the American animation industry. From the setting to the costumes to the music to the quaint Scottish dialect, Brave is a masterful and mesmerizing tale of love told so beautifully in a message of timeless depth and power. From the opening scene, the viewer is swept away by the bold colors, the sympathetic characters, and the visual imagery that move across the screen and straight into your heart. After two sequels, I was very excited to hear that Pixar was producing a new original movie.  It had everything: and exotic culture, action, humor, and brilliant animation.  Sadly, it didn't pan out like I had hoped it would.  Maybe I've grown up too much, but I had always thought Pixar was brilliant at making movies that people of all ages could appreciate.  This movie felt like a waltz through a kindergartner's make-believe afternoon.  I never felt a real sense of urgency in the plot; it all seemed like the playful antics of a rebellious teen, and nobody was ever in any real danger.  By the time it ended, I was left thinking "That's all?"
Don't get me wrong, there are trademark Pixar aspects still in there.  The animation, the scenery, and the cinematography are beautiful throughout.  There are many characters to grow attached to, and the humor is tastefully written for everybody to enjoy.  But I expected this kind of story from Dreamworks; Pixar has a higher standard to live up to, and it fell short this time.

Disney appears to be doing everything right when it comes to civil rights. It has certainly been a long way. Their animated films reflect racial diversity without being patronizing or offensive, with good values. "Brave" is an exciting and delightful film that follows this pattern, addressing the at-times-neglected role of women in society, showing an empowered and determined young lady that defies good ol' boy traditions. And it does it in an intelligent and colorful way.

The story takes place in Scotland, where King Fergus rules the Clan DunBroch. The king gives Merida, his young daughter, a bow for her birthday. With time, Merida becomes an expert archer, a beautiful teenager, and lives a happy life with her three identical triplets. It is at this time that her mother, Queen Elinor, tells her that she is to be engaged for marriage to one of the sons of the leaders of his father's allied Clan kings. Merida, who has a strong and determined character - independent and opinionated -, hates the idea and does everything that she can to avoid this task, which means breaking a holy tradition. In doing so, she hurts her mother, by asking a witch to transform her into a bear. Merida, of course, feels sorry that she made that choice, and, against time, tries to reverse the spell. Add to this the curse of the legendary Mor'du, a huge, mean black bear, who is feared by all, and who was once a handsome prince. All these problems will make Merida reexamine her actions and behavior, and her future in the kingdom.

"Brave" has all the technical goodies of any Pixar films, and it is just great to watch. It is also funny, wicked and charming. And, as I said, it is about women's empowerment and bravery. The Blu-ray, Blu-ray 3D, DVD and Digital Copy edition is loaded with extras, such as extended scenes, Pixar shorts, alternate opening, art galleries, audio commentaries, and much more! (USA, 2012, color, 93 min plus additional materials). Reviewed on December 3, 2012 by Eric Gonzalez for Disney Blu-ray.

Ever since the first "Toy Story" film rolled into theaters, I have greatly enjoyed Pixar's contributions to Disney's animated films.  It seems that no matter what genre they decide to tackle, be it superhero movies (The Incredibles), dystopian science fiction (WALL-E), tearjerking Oscar contenders (Up), and even culinary movies (Ratatoullie), they come up with winners.  Even their critically panned "Cars" movies have been a step above a lot of modern animated movies, and I can't think of with a single Pixar film that I didn't just enjoy, but love.

"Brave" is no exception.  And after so many years of suffering through the pastel-colored, girly-girl world of the Disney Princesses, it's refreshing and wonderful to see a princess who can hold her own.  And the film looks gorgeous to boot.

"Brave" chronicles the story of Merida, princess of a Scottish kingdom who prefers horseback-riding and archery to etiquette and embroidery, much to the consternation of her proper and dignified mother.  When her mother announces that Merida must soon marry in order to prevent a clan feud from overtaking the kingdom, she runs away and decides to change her fate by consulting an eccentric witch in the forest.  The witch grants her wish... but it comes at an unexpected cost, and Merida must take responsibility and act quickly to save both her mother and the kingdom from the consequences of the spell.

This film looks absolutely stunning -- Pixar apparently had to rewrite its graphics software for this movie, and it shows in graphics that are top notch.  The Scottish highlands serve as a magnificent backdrop for this story, creating a world that looks almost real.  Hair and fur are well-rendered as well -- Merida's hair in particular is a wild tangle that must have been a nightmare to render but looks real enough to touch.

The story has come under criticism by some for being "average" and not showcasing Merida's talents enough.  I feel it's a wonderful fairy tale, however, and is a great coming-of-age story.  And the moral of the story is a timely one that I think all children and parents should learn -- that our choices have consequences, and we must take responsibility for our actions, for better or for worse.

I must also give special mention to the sounds of this movie -- the music and the voice cast.  The music, a combination of traditional orchestral score and bagpipe music, fits the story like a glove, with additional vocal songs woven in seamlessly.  And after seeing so many films that are supposed to take place in foreign countries but have a jarrinly American-sounding voice cast, it's refreshing to hear authentic British and Scottish voices in this film.  The voice cast does a wonderful job bringing the characters to life.

I personally consider this one of Pixar's best films yet, and one of the best Disney fairy tales and princess stories in a long time.  Merida is a worthy addition to the Disney Princess roster, and could probably run circles around Snow White and Cinderella (though I think she'd get along well with Mulan...).  Best suited for children 8 and up due to some scary moments.
Brave was an excellent movie and I am very pleased with it. The picture quality was great and the story line was awesome.
This movie was not nearly as good as the hype. I felt like it was very short and cheesy and lacked the adult disney humor in their older movies -- that let adults enjoy them as much as the kids do!
Great artwork, great message, great lil story.  It will be a hit at Christmas.  My daughter will enjoy receiving this.
i figured this would be a lot more funny than it was.  there were funny parts, but there were also very serious parts and those parts of the movie kind of felt like the movie was dragging on.
The quality overall is excellent. The movie is great and a real pleasure to be able to view it from my video library.

Had to watch it twice it was so great. Truth, wisdom and humor all put together in way for children to enjoy. The so called nudity scene, come on the short take of cartoon butt's is not something I would be afraid for my 2,4 or 6 yr old to see. This is a must see if you have a daughter, it is an inspiration to the strength of the so named fair sex. My daughter can do anything a man can do and I encourage her to follow her dreams where ever they may lead. Disney and Pixar really out did themselves with this one, I plan to buy this movie. It is one of those you share and watch over again and again, a new movie for my collection that few get to be a part of.
It's a movie that you can enjoy with the family. I must say now that I seen it will most likely get the DVD!

What a missed opportunity - Pixar could have done so much better.  It's like they went for the lowest common denominator.  Think of great movies like "How to Train Your Dragon" and "The Incredibles" --- innovative films that don't rely on rehashed ideas from other cliche-ridden movies.  Anything old, these movies reinvent and make new again.  That is what Brave should have been.  Instead we have a movie that should have been called "Brother Bear 3."

Yes, my kid enjoyed the movie and that is what counts.  But the truly great Pixar films have not been directed simply at kids; they are family films that can be enjoyable for anyone at any age.  I can watch "Finding Nemo" annually and enjoy it each time.  On the other hand, "Brave" is a movie I could have done without and will certainly never watch again.  This one just didn't have the Pixar magic we have all come to expect.

Warning this review may contain spoilers not intended to spoil the film but only to point out issues.
I really wanted to like this movie.  My girlfriend and I had a movie night and we wanted to watch this but the redbox nearby did not have it.  After renting two other movies I went back and found Brave at the 9pm return deadline :).  We came back and started watching it.  The Pixar film was made with amazing quality as usual.  The hair of the main character Merida was pretty neat to watch when she was a child it was stunning how the Pixar technology works.  The foundation and introduction of the characters was done in an adequate fashion.  Merida was portrayed as rebellious, smart, cunning, athletic, great riding abilities and a marksman with the bow.  It had one big Disney style production of riding through the forest shooting then climbing a mountain and singing in front of a waterfall (Cinematic Fluff).  After a finding out her parents were going to marry her off based on a competition with 3 other tribes.  She fights for herself to stay single.  That was it, that was the last point in the movie where I enjoyed it.  That was the only time the first introduction of the character actually came to fruition.  She stood up for herself and beat the oafs that were presented to her in an archery competition.  From this point forward it was like a new writer took over the films script.
Plot twist... Brave become Naive.  This was the last point in the film where Brave becomes an issue, factor, or relevance to the story.  Now she turns into this Naive little stupid girl who gets lost in the forest in a fit of self pity and rage.  A witch that tries to kill her she gives full trust into without considering any consequences gives her a spell.  This spell thus infecting her mother and brothers in such a way that the whole story dies.  It was pathetic.  It was so fantastic in premise that I could barely watch it anymore.  My girlfriend fell asleep during a Disney/Pixar film... really...
It wasn't her fault it just went from being a human movie to an animal film and not a very good one.  Long story short... The bears, the witch, the chasing and the bear hatred were all extremes that appears were the only way they could make this a movie.  All suffered from unoriginal thought, predictability, and the fact they made the Heroine so dumb showed the true colors of Disney.  The fact that the "Heroine" was strong and became such a pathetic child that showed no remorse for her actions, acted out of her own wishes and not considering the feelings of others even after destroying her families lives.  It was just disgusting.
I have no idea what the moral of the story was.  Was it the same as it has been with all Disney films of the past?.. Don't trust the witch or was it that you should try to get your way no matter who you hurt in your path and eventually everything will work out when you cause so much destruction in your path.  I don't expect everyone to agree with me on this and I don't really care I just wanted to voice my opinion on one movie what had great visual potential but lacked the moral integrity to even be considered as a Disney classic.  This should have been a straight to DVD film.  In so many ways this actually makes the woman Heroine look absolutely stupid and I think young girls should have a better example to learn by.
We rented this before I bought it, my Husband and I as well as all 4 of our kids just loved this movie!!
This film should appeal to all ages. I found it quite entertaining. This is a movie to watch over and over again.

I started seeing this movie poster a year ago and it looked like something really special that we haven't seen before, a style very ethereal, gothic, a work of art, but when I saw this movie, it was very lame, the story, the animation. I just don't see what audience they are targeting with this movie. I don't see little kids liking this movie and people who like fantasy, gothic style of art and movies, this is nothing like it looks in the poster. I really thought this movie was bad all the way around!

I absolutely love this movie. I saw it twice in theaters when it first came out and pre-ordered it way before it was actually released. It is one of those movies that, though it is intended for children, I can watch over and over again and still find hilarious and and heart wrenching every time.

I did have an issue with the shipping because it was lost in transit somewhere and never came in but one call to Amazon and they got it all fixed up quickly and painlessly and sent me another copy free of charge that came in the very next day. I am very happy with the product and the company in general.

Admission: I don't have kids, I just love Pixar movies.

With that out of the way, let me say that I did enjoy Brave, but it didn't capture my imagination like Pixar movies so often do. Where Pixar typically excels is in developing the characters so that despite the style of animation lacking realism, you connect and empathize with the characters. While Brave moves quickly, has a likable-enough protagonist, and ultimately does fine in terms of providing an hour and half of entertainment, it lacks the depth of character development that the more successful Pixar films had. In a similar fashion, I found the plot and message to be a bit flat and obvious as well.

Pixar usually makes movies that are ostensibly for kids, but that even adults can enjoy because of the many layers contained within. I'd happily plop a niece or nephew down in front of Brave, but I might not be fighting them for the popcorn like I normally would.
Visually amazing animation. The story is good, not great - not finding nemo. Be sure to check out the special features!

Her passion is riding her enormous clydesdale horse (Angus) and shooting arrows at stuff... similar to hunger games in that regard, also found it similar to disney's tangled. Worth a rental I guess, I wouldnt buy it... especially at disney's inflated prices. The animation is beautifully done though and it looks really good on BD

This is the best non musical Disney film to date.  I especially like the way it depicts Celtic culture; clearly Disney has finally learned something from its Pocahontas and Mulan cultural debacles!  Merida is the perfect heroine.  But more importantly, this film touches upon the most difficult relationship of all:  mothers and daughters!  It's a film so universal to our experiences as girls and women that it is an absolute must-see for mothers and daughters alike!

The soundtrack here is fabulous!  Please download the album.  it's absolutely beautiful music, especially "Noble Maiden Fair" which is sung by Emma Thompson in Gaelic and features haunting Irish harps!

I wish that it had been extended a bit longer, and I think the plot and the characters (all the members of the family are great!) could have easily supported it.

Few animated movies bring me to tears, but this one did!!! My ancestry is Ireland/Scotland and this movie really hit home with me!! It also reminded me of my granddaughter!!

at least I didn't waste too much money or gas.

i thought it was a good family movie i like these kind of movies i wish they would make more

I must say I am shocked at the negative reviews, but to each his own.  I loved this change of pace for Disney and Pixar.  The entire princess thing to me is played out.  Beautiful (perfect looking) girl seeks handsome husband and somehow they meet, fall in love instantly and live in a huge castle with everything they could imagine, etc (oh and they can all sing.)  While nice in a fantasy type world, it is not reality.  How many of our daughters still think this is reality.  They want that fantasy, and as they grow they realize that it is not how the real world is, and truth be told is not reality for many of us.  I loved how this played on the tough relationship between a daughter and her mother (this is real life).  The fact that as the daughter got older she came to understand she did not want the same thing her parents wanted is reality, many of us lived this.  The daughter tried to change this on her owm, makes a bad decision, but in the end they work things out as a family.  It is called growing up, coming to terms with your parents dreams to make you happy and your own.  The witch and magic aspect - if you don't approve of this in a movie for your kid, I can respect that.  It is just par for the course since Harry Potter, the Twilight movies, the list goes on and on.  If you feel that strongly - don't go to Disney World, it is filled with Magic inspire rides and shows.  My daughter loved it, she was Merida for Halloween - she loved the strong "Brave" aspect.  A girl who is able to be tough, hold her own among the "men" and still a pretty girl.
the kids and the adults all liked this one. story was a bit predictable but its based on a classic fairy tale.

This is not your typical damsel in distress movie where a prince comes and saves her. In this movie its all about female power. It doesn't even have a prince involved which is the best part because it sends a very important message about the female gender....we don't need a male to come and rescue us because we are fragile NO! WE CAN DO IT ALL ON OUR OWN. This movie is a defenite must see. Its empowering to women and little girls. Finally a movie from disney that actually empowers the princess to live hapily ever after without its night and shining armor!

I am a Disney/Pixar fanatic and over the years I have come to expect BIG things from Pixar. It pains me to say that this is the second movie they have put out in a row that left me feeling underwhelmed (Cars 2 was the first). It's not a bad movie by any means, let me get that out of the way. It's a mildly entertaining flick for kids, and it's almost a coming-of-age tale, mostly geared towards girls, which is fine, but it was not what I expected. I feel like I was watching a movie I've seen a hundred times, even though it was my first time watching it. The animation is spectacular, I'll give it that. The characters and story are largely forgettable. I can't even recall the main character's name. Or any of their names to be honest. Pixar can do better than this. I have my fingers crossed that Monsters Inc 2 will live up to the original. And to be fair, Cars 2 and Brave are the only 2 Pixar movies I found disappointing. The trouble is, I didn't expect big things from Cars 2. I expected big from Brave, and it did not deliver. Is it my fault for expecting too much then? Perhaps. At any rate, it blows Avatar out of the water. Then again so did Cars 2.

Hopefully unbiased (or at least low-biased) part of review:

Important Point: Know the content of this movie. The animation is spectacular...but some of that techno-pizzazz is used to show, to a high degree of realism, men's naked butts and women's cleavage. Granted, the scenes are short...but they are in there.

That being said, I enjoyed the movie...and the animation was incredible. I'm a computer scientist with many years of experience and advanced degrees and I was blown away by the technical prowess in animation that was demonstrated.

The story was, at least to me, entertaining. Did I love the story as much as I did for The Incredibles? No, but The Incredibles truly WAS incredible (to me). I found Brave to be an enjoyable movie so long as you understood and was comfortable with the content.

Now comes the biased part of the review and a rant...so feel free to skip this part...

I gave the movie only 2 stars for the following reasons:

1) Subtracted two stars for squeezing in "brief" nudity (men's butts and a too-often fixation with animating women's cleavage) in a movie clearly aimed at a demographic that includes young children.

2) Subtracted one star because Disney/Pixar officials knew EXACTLY what they were doing. Shame on you!

Yep, I'm an old fogie and a prude...but given that I still won't excuse Disney/Pixar for putting this content ("sneaking" it in sounds like a better characterization to me) into a movie clearly aimed at kids. Never again will I be able to buy a Disney/Pixar movie clearly aimed at kids and know that there is no question about whether or not the content is age appropriate. If it isn't rated-G, it is not automatically okay for kids. I cannot believe that Walt would be pleased with what they've done with his name.

Disney/Pixar will argue that I should have known this from the PG rating...but they know full well that most people don't know that PG allows for brief nudity. I suspect most adults, like myself, figured that an animated movie could get a PG rating from intense scenes ...but that the movie makers would NEVER be so foolish as to animate nudity into a kids movie (the Incredibles is an example of what is expected. It was rated PG due to some intense scenes...not because of nudity or anything like unto it).

Guess what? I was wrong. Whomever is in control at Disney/Pixar clearly believes that pushing to the very limit is the way to go. I wonder if they calculated into their projections the number of people they would lose as loyal customers due to feeling betrayed?

I was doubly ticked off because content aside, I *liked* the movie. I would have liked to have sat down with the nieces and nephews to watch this. Nope...not the younger ones to be sure. To borrow from one of Pixar's non-Brave characters, the movie was visually captivating and very entertaining...and then you had to just go and ruin the ride...

My rating is just that...*my* rating. However, if you feel such content is perfectly fine for your young children...then I think you'll enjoy the movie.

This is so not a kids movie!!!  I am so glad I was impatient and watched this before letting her watch it.  She had seen the commercials for this on tv and was asking for it more than once.  I bought it for her but thankfully watched it before she did (after he went to bed).  Take my advice watch this before letting your kids watch it.  Personally I think it is a bit scary for kids!

I enjoyed the characters and story line.  I think adults would appreciate

*Spoilers Ahead*

Well, Pixar has released it's first fantasy film, and despite some bumps along the way, it's a pretty good film. It also gives us Pixar's first princess to join the Disney line-up; Merida. But, let's break it down a little.

First, the most important thing, the story. The film is about a rebellious princess (cliche as that may sound) wanting to change her unwanted fate of getting married to someone she's never met. The lengths at which she goes to achieve this however, lead both her and her family down a dangerous path. Sounds simple enough on paper, but there was a lot of twists and turns in the film, that it was almost a little hard to follow at times. Still, the focus of the movie is set on Merida and her relationship with her mother, Queen Elinor, which is a nice touch for Pixar/Disney to finally focus on a mother/daughter relationship this heavily. I'll admit though, when Elinor is transformed into a bear, that just felt a little, random to me. I found myself echoing Merida's "Why a bear?" line when I saw it happen. This plot point does provide a nice climax at the end though, showing that the curse on Elinor is more dire than they thought at first, and what could happen if they don't find a cure.

Next, the characters. A little superficial nitpick, when I saw Merida's hair, I might have been a little happy that finally there was a princess with hair as crazy as mine. But, besides that, she's, well, a little annoying at times (at least to me). I mean, she doesn't want to get married, and acts selfish (which she even admits later on) about the whole situation, and doesn't handle it very well. But, she learns, and grows as a character. The same can be said for Elinor, who scarily reminds me of my mother. The two's relationship is very relateable. Plus, she's the around one of the only queens in Disney who is not evil. Fergus, Merida's father is probably one of my favorite characters, just because he's so crazy and fun. Plus, they got the casting just right for him. Next, is Merida's brothers, who are basically the comic relief, but do a pretty good job at it, having a sort of Tom and Jerry relationship with one of the maids. The lords from the different kingdoms, and their sons, I'd also put on my favorite character list, even though their roles are minor. Just the way their differing personalities cross is enjoyable to watch. The witch (does she have a name?) is OK I guess, but this films got enough quirky characters in it. But, she's only in it for about 10 minutes so, no real harm. And finally, the villain of the film; the demon bear Mor'du. This is the first Pixar or Disney villain for a while, with no real motivations (at least at first). He's akin to the bear in Fox and The Hound, except a tad more vicious. I wasn't really expecting him to be that Prince that was cursed, but I suppose they had to explain his savage nature somehow, and it was a really good payoff. In the end, he's not so much as a villain, just a victim of "Ambition is Evil". Plus, his design, both bear and Prince, is interesting.

Wow, now that the character section's done, let's move on to the design and music, because it's worth talking about. It's one of Pixar's finest special effects work, especially with portraying the landscape. The little details they add, while still pulling away and appreciating the larger scale, is awesome, and it was amazing to see it in 3-D at the cinemas. The music is also creative too, with a few songs by the cast that are both humorous and heartbreaking. There are a few songs by an artist, but, in my opinion, they fit in to the film okay.

Lastly, the special features. We watched the behind the scenes stuff, and it was worth checking out. I always love when they add stuff like explanations on how things in the film work. Also, there are a lot of deleted scenes, though their more prominent on the second disc. I have yet to watch the commentary, but I'm thankful it's there so we can get the director's input. Plus, there is the standard Pixar short, "La Luna" which is amazing, and, like the landscape in the movie was cool to watch in the cinemas, but can still be appreciated on the small screen.

So, I think I've ranted enough (actually I think this is my longest review). Overall, this is a decent add to the Pixar lineup, and Merida is a good addition to the Princess line-up. The story can get a little clunky at times, but everything else I think, is worth the price to add to your Disney/Pixar movie collection.

When I saw this movie in the theater, I left with mixed feelings.  It is NOT your typical Disney princess tale.  There is no falling in love and living happily ever after with the man of her dreams.  But I should not have expected typical with a Pixar production.  If you can leave your expectations at the door, you'll appreciate what this story has to offer: a tale of family love; a girl coming of age and her mother who make choices they both regret; and second chances to make things right.  My daughter loved this tale from the first, and I like Merida as a role model much better that the standard princess role models that are available.  I've seen Brave three times now, and I have to say I have moved from ambivalence to admiration in short order.  And no one can argue that the visual art is stunning.

There are over 800 reviews of this movie as I write this, so obviously this has been reviewed many times before.

Because it already has so many reviews, this is not a review of the movie itself, but specifically of the 3-D portion. Some 3-D movies are really incredible, with objects "flying" out at you and things "floating" in your living room. These 3-D movies, in my opinion, are absolutely worth the extra money. Others, however, simply give the movie another layer of depth, but are not really that different from the blu-ray version. This is the case for Brave. Great movie, but I was very disappointed with the 3-D effects. Save yourself the extra money and buy the blu-ray version instead. If you want a great Disney movie with fantastic 3-D effects, buy Tangled instead. The 3-D effects are unbelievable!

(I gave it 4 stars because it is a very good movie, but minus one because of the 3-D effects.)

The result is a satisfying experience for adults and a heroine that kids can relate to. I really wanted to give this film a full 5 stars and I'd say the only reason I didn't is because the film isn't especially memorable.

Brave is a great movie if you're looking for an hour and a half of fun entertainment for adults and kids. The pace is quick and keeps you interested and while the story could have been a touch deeper the movie doesn't get too serious like so many animated films today.  Some of the moments with "the bear" can actually be a bit scary! I'd say while not perfect (hence the 4 stars) this little known movie is probably one of the best animated films Disney and Pixar have done in a long time.  Worth the watch!

When a story is weak, it drags everything down with it. This is a story that goes round and round in circles overburdened with boring chase sequences that go on much too long. What a shame, considering the talent involved in creating it.  The humorous voices, the spectacular landscapes and gifted animation were, in the end, not enough to buoy up a plot line so leaden, it put a drag on everything. Even the heroine seemed a little selfish for not taking responsibility for her wish-gone-horribly wrong, until close to the end. What makes a story not gel? Lack of nuance maybe? A need for plenty of chases as filler for a thin narrative?  I wanted to like this movie about a spirited, pretty girl with flaming red hair, but bears took over and brought it to the dark side for most of the picture.  I'm fine with a more politically correct, less pink or frilly or classic princess meets prince plot, but exactly what was this?  Ok, this is also about a product. Would I buy this dvd?  Sure!  With the handy FF button I can watch the sequences I like and shoot past the ones I don't.  This film has enough that's satisfying on separate levels that one can overlook the weak plot.  Sometimes first impressions get overshadowed by what is working well in subsequent viewings.

I've been a fan of animated movies my whole life.  The visuals are usually stunning, and the stories are usually better than "regular" movies.  The visuals in this movie are nothing at all special.  We've seen it all many times.  The story is so weak, it almost doesn't exist.  The heroine's archery skill serves nothing, in fact I wondered why they included it in the movie. Surely she could have gotten in trouble a myriad of other ways?  The bear was too cartoon-ish. It felt like the makers couldn't quite figure out if this was sad or funny.  The horse, a buddy in the beginning, disappears when the going gets tough. I also found the dialog hard to follow at times because of the accent.  The best and most significant character in the whole movie is the red hair, and in fact it dominates the screen.  So why not have the hair be a significant part of the story?  (yes, Tangled has been done, and very well, but there must be other ways to use such a head of hair.)  I'm not sure how something this half-baked gets made.  Next time send the script out to someone who knows how to create a good story.
Its almost worth watching just to see how amazing the rendering of her red hair is.  Worth watching but not at the awesome level - maybe because it repeats a variety of earlier tropes.

Merida is not your typical princess.  She's more comfortable hunting with her bow and arrow, then she is wearing fancy dresses.  Merida is not keen when her parents decide to give her hand away in marriage, and an argument breaks out between her and her mother.  I don't want to give away any more of the plot, but I highly recommend Brave.  It was a very touching story of a girl who wants to be independent and trying to get her parents to accept that independence, especially her mother.  There were a lot of things said between mother and daughter and it reminded me of my own mother-daughter situation.  Go along for the ride with Merida, you won't be sorry.

So many people have complained about this film working on a tired formula. To an extent, that's true. However, it does something very different - and important - with its characters. In addition to the usual rebellious princess (Merida) who enjoys activities such as horseback riding and archery, another central character in the film is her mother, Queen Elinor. Elinor is trying to train her daughter to be a princess, and later, queen herself. However, Merida resists this education, viewing it as too restrictive.

The exploration of the mother/daughter relationship is the most interesting part of the movie, as it does not paint either of them as completely wrong: far too often movies like this have the strict authority figure featured as nothing more than a challenge for the character. Brave, however, makes it clear that Elinor has valid reasons for her actions. Also, it shows that Elinor herself is every bit as strong as Merida, even if she is a much more reserved, elegant figure. She shows and uses her strength in different ways.

Merida is able to learn something from her mother, and we see a wonderful case of conflict resolution (there's some fighting later, for those who want it, but I thought that wasn't as interesting), in which Merida has to think and speak, bringing what she learned from her mother to use while applying her own views. She didn't have to give up any agency, she just gained a new way to use it.

I guess the short version: I'm so glad to see a movie that doesn't treat feminine things as weaker than masculine ones. This movie shows the strength in both traditionally feminine and traditionally masculine activities.

Most of the humor is rather "meh" in the second half, and one major plot twist isn't adequately explained.

But it's a very good movie overall, and not to be missed!

In the summer of 2012, Pixar Animation Studios released their latest computer-animated film titled "Brave".

The summer blockbuster was written by award-winning writer Brenda Chapman ("Chicken Run", "Who Framed Roger Rabbit", "The Real Ghostbusters"), Mark Andrews ("John Carter", "Spider-Man"), Steve Purcell (creator of the adventure game series "Sam & Max") and Irene Mecchi ("The Lion King", "Hercules", "The Hunchback of Notre Dame") and co-directed by Mark Andrews, Brenda Chapman and Steve Purcell.

The film would become Pixar's first fairy tale film and also feature a darker tone compared to previous Pixar animated films.  And as one would expected from a Pixar film, "Brave" which was budgeted around $185 million, went on to earn over $532 million in the box office.

VIDEO:

"Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" is probably one of the most significant Disney/Pixar animated releases I have seen in terms of overall presentation and gorgeous picture quality.  The film is presented in 1080p High Definition (2:39:1) aspect ratio and as far as picture quality is concerned, everything about this film looks incredibly well-detailed.

First, let's take a look at the Blu-ray 3D version.  For those who have the hardware to display 3D, this is one film that was created with 3D in mind.  From the way the animation utilizes depth for 3D is wonderful to see.  You actually can see the scale of the castle through 3D as it gives an impression the location is quite vast.  While there are scenes with the Elinor as the bear or Mor'du the demon bear cowering over a character with great monstrosity, you can see the scale of the bears.

But for the most part, the 3D for this film is improved compared to past Disney 3D films.  Overall, depth gives us a sense of scale much more effective for the film on Blu-ray 3D.

As for the Blu-ray release, the Blu-ray of "Brave" is fantastic.

From the food that King Fergus is eating to the emphasis on hair, from the strands of hair, unkept hair, beard hair, ear hair, you name it, there is a lot of detail when it comes to hair and hair physics in this film.  Also, the clothing are well=-detailed, the background scenery looks magnificent outdoors especially indoors.  The overall color is sharp, vibrant and black levels are nice and deep.

There are so many things about this film that looks realistic and detailed, I was really impressed.  The overall picture quality is one of the best I have seen on Blu-ray and the film on Blu-ray looks amazing!

As for the DVD, the DVD version is presented in 2:39:1, enhanced for 169 televisions.

AUDIO & SUBTITLES:

If you thought that "Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" was great for videophiles, audiophiles will also find a lot of satisfaction with the Blu-ray release.  Presented in Dolby TrueHD 7.1, this is one of the most immersive Disney Blu-ray releases I have heard for an animated film.  From the environmental ambiance of hearing the forest, the wind, the trees, the grass being fully integrated to the film and giving you the sense that Merida and family are out in the country, there is also great utilization of sound when Mor'Du approaches or when Ilinor growls in bear form.  There is also great utilization of sound when Merida is shooting her bow and arrow or when the men are fighting against the demon bear.

The immersive soundtrack utilizes the surround channels may it be with sound effects or its beautiful musical soundtrack but also a good amount of LFE to make you feel those action scenes.  But the positive factor of this film is its immersiveness and making you feel that sound outdoors are coming from all over your soundscape.  "Brave" sounds absolutely fantastic in Blu-ray!

As for subtitles, subtitles are presented in English SDH, English Commentary 2.0 Dolby Digital, Spanish

SPECIAL FEATURES

"Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" comes with the following special features:

  La Luna - (6:57) A theatrical short about a young boy working with his father and grandfather.
  The Legend of Mor'Du - (6:51) What is the history about the demon bear known as Mor'Du.
  Behind the Scenes - (12:35) Featuring seven scenes in which the crew traveled to Scotland and embraced the scenery which was important for creating the look and feel of "Brave".
  Once Upon a Time - (7:47) Each scene may have had different perspectives and storytelling that had to be cut out.  This segment features the different ideas for a certain scene.
  Extended Scenes  - Featuring four separate extended scenes with extra scenes that were cut out of the final cut.
  Director's Commentary - Featuring audio commentary by director Mark Andrews, co-director Steve Purcell, story supervisor Brian Larsen and editor Nick Smith.
  Fergus & Mor'Du: An Alternate Opening - (2:40) Featuring a scene that original focused on King Fergus.
  Fallen Warriors - (2:08) Shots that were cut out of the final version of the film and honored in this Blu-ray.
  Dirty Hairy People - (3:33) The animators talk about how the characters have a lot of hair in this animated film.  As well as trying to capture the authenticity of Scottish people of that time period, including bad teeth.
  It is English... Sort of - (3:50) The Scottish talent and crew discuss the various Scottish dialects utilized in the film and with various characters.
  Angus - (3:25) A feature about the research of horses and capturing the look and feel of the horse and also creating the relationship between Merida and her horse Angus.
  The Tapestry - (3:56) Creating the visual element of the tapestry and its importance int he film.
  Art Galleries - With your remote, you can view art revolving around the characters, color keys, development art, environments and graphics.

EXTRAS:

"Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" comes with a cardboard sleeve case with a renticular front featuring Merida.  The Ultimate Collector's Edition comes with the Blu-ray 3D, Blu-ray, DVD and Digital Copy.

JUDGMENT CALL:

"Brave" was a pleasant surprise to come from Pixar.

Not only was the storyline a bit dark, but rarely do you find a story that is concentrated on a mother and daughter relationship.  But obviously it was a film that was used to test waters of what Pixar can accomplish outside of animated films that featured non-human characters, especially characters who were not young children and it was also a film that featured Pixar Animation Studios first female director.

While a film like "Up" was a film about an elderly man's life who is changed thanks to a child, "Brave" is a film that was driven by co-director and co-writer Brenda Chapman and capturing the relationship between mother and daughter.  From Chapman's experience of traveling to Scotland and wanting to create a fairy tale in the tradition of Hans Christian Andersen and the Brothers Grimm.

I'm always open for something unique and different and what I enjoyed about this film is it's overall feel and how the film incorporated Scottish dialects and utilizing the right talent that fit the film.  Originally, Reese Witherspoon was to voice the character of Merida, but it worked to Pixar's benefit to have actress Kelly Macdonald play the lead character.  From the spoken dialogue to seeing a female character that is athletic, dominant but also free-spirited, you just don't see this kind of character in a Disney animated film.

And speaking of acting, along with actress Kelly Macdonald, "Brave" also features wonderful voice acting from Bill Connolly, Emma Thompson, Julie Walters, Robbie Coltrane, Kevin McKidd and Craig Ferguson.  The voice acting really made a big difference in the believability of this film.

And it's important to mention that "Brave" is not a film that loses its cuteness in sake of creating something realistic.  While the film does focus on mother and daughter relationships, children will no doubt love the adorable and mischievous nature of Merida's triplet young brothers.  And also, for action purposes, you have Merida's father ready to jump into any fray to defend his family and people.

The characters are fun, the scenery looks absolutely beautiful and overall animation is fantastic.  But will it work for children?  I think children will love it for its action.  I also feel that families will enjoy it for that family bonding storyline but also the nature of the story and the aspect of family.

And for those who have wanted an animated film with a brave heroine, "Brave" is that kind of movie.

As for the Blu-ray release, "Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" is wonderful!  Not only is this the best 3D animated film to come from Disney thus far, it's also a film that looks and sounds incredible on Blu-ray.  There is so much detail in the characters (especially the hair!) , clothing, backgrounds and scenery, I was impressed by seeing how fantastic "Brave" looks on Blu-ray.  It really was breathtaking just to watch this film and see how Pixar continues to improve after one hit film after the other.  As for special features, you get a lot of them included with this release that shows us how much work and research went into capturing Scottish culture and integrating it through the entire film.

And with the holiday season coming up, "Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" is also fantastic as you get the Blu-ray 3D, Blu-ray, DVD and digital copy.

A first for Pixar....first female director, the first fairy tale film and a film that focuses on a mother and daughter relationship.  But "Brave" is much more than that!  It's a film that is strong on storytelling, featuring wonderful acting but also, "Brave" is one of the most impressive Blu-ray releases I have ever seen and heard in my years of reviewing Blu-ray releases.

"Brave: Ultimate Collector's Edition" is a must-own, must-buy Blu-ray release!  And is highly recommended and deserving of five stars!

Pixar's 2012 animated feature Brave stands apart from the wealth of princess-based movies which came before it. Where most princesses sit around gazing moonily at a bird and hoping for a prince to rescue them, Merida picks up her own sword, takes charge of her own life, and at the end of the film, is still proudly carving her own path - putting off thoughts of marriage until later.

It is quite clear from the very beginning that the team at Pixar knew what they were doing in the archery and sword-fighting scenes. I've taken medieval swordfighting classes for several years and have spent far more years attending reenactments and watching swordplay. The movements in Brave are nearly perfect; in many cases they were exactly what I was taught to do. I remember thinking, in a pivotal scene where Merida holds off an assailant with her sword, "hey, I know that pose!"

In the commentary we learn that the team did know how to sword-fight and mapped out all the combat sequences in real life before transferring them to the screen. So these aren't just fantasy versions of sword fights. They are realistic, authentic looks as to how these swords were handled.

The same is true for the archery. They show the details about how the arrow bends as it flies, the way the bow is held, and so on.

It's true that Merida's mom is not thrilled about Merida's sword-and-bow interests, but that conflict between mother and daughter is the whole heart of the film. Merida's mom has one, specific track in mind her for daughter - become part of a clan merger. And, to be fair, this was often the way marriage was in medieval times. Nobles had to ensure their land was protected and their borders secure. It was a quite practical situation. So the mother's stance is understandable. So is the daughter's.

I give the story great praise. Sure, it's a bit predictable. We could almost recite some of the lines along with the characters, knowing what they were likely to say. Still, the underlying message is wonderful and miles apart from the 1937 Snow White. Snow White sat around waiting for her prince to come, with no thought of doing anything for herself. Merida has plenty she wants to do with her life, and has little interest in a prince coming to take control.

Well recommended.

i absolutely love this film. there's not much else to say except its medieval scotland with the voices of billy connelly and emma thompson as lord and lady. kelly macdonald does a fantastic job emoting not only as a child but as a woman coming of age in a difficult situation. one of the only of these films that i can think of where the parents are still together and have a strong relationship with the children. children and adults alike will love this movie not only for the humor and music (which has become one of my all-time favorite disney soundtracks) but the artwork. it looks all the more breathtaking on bluray in the highest picture settings possible. do yourself a favor and buy this whether you've seen it already or not. you will not be disappointed. btw, there is also a boatload of extra behind the scenes featurettes on just about every aspect of making this movie for all you cinephiles (or disneyphiles as it were) out there.

Another wonderful princess movie by Disney.i wish the father was more involved since this family is actually all still together. It focuses on the mother/daughter relationship, and Merida and her mother both learn important lessons in the end.
My 3 yr old likes it but found the parts with the bear to be slightly scary. I could see those parts giving little ones nightmares.

I can't say enough about this brilliant movie. Disney has done it again! As a middle age woman, I couldn't help but think  about my own coming of age and the differences between myself and my Mom during that time in my life. It's a touching story and it's nice to see that Disney is willing to change with the times as Brave's princess had no need to be rescued by a man. This is my second favorite movie now right behind Tangled. I'm thinking about getting both for my 80 year old Mom (who still loves Disney) for Christmas this year. :)

There were dangling threads of characters which were never resolved or resolved poorly. The animation was great. I enjoy animated movies for the entertainment value but this one seems to be a bit shallow.

I do a lot of shopping with amazon and have always been happy with service. They have even gone above and beyond to get a shipment to me in a timely manner before I was even a Prime member. I do have the digital copy version of the movie and it does not work with my kindle. I notice that they now have ultraviolet copies of certain movies that will work. Wish they would make those available as an upgrade to customers who bought movies through amazon prior to the release of ultraviolet, expecting digital copies to work on kindles.

Only have purchase a few 3D blueray movies. This one is a good one, and has all the versions/formats in one box! Buy it!

Rented this movie for thanks giving weekend.. Kids enjoyed it. I don't think its really come in disney's collection category
I watched this movie and I recommend to everyone and anyone that is looking for encouragement to watch this. Great Watch!

The technology behind the animation was two thumbs up!
The story line was easy to follow and kept you interested.
On a whole a must see.
I would recommend to parents to watch the movie with their children the first time. My daughter (3) got kind of scared when the Mom had turned into a bear.

I got this gift for my child she loves anything that has to do with the Brave. This movie was a great price for what i got. I would tell any Parent that is looking for a gift this is the way to go. kids love movies and its easy on you wallet.

'Brave' is entertaining. It is visually pretty, has some touching parts (not as many as the directors were aiming for, I'm guessing), has some funny part, and has some exciting parts. The story is ok. But when all is said and done, the movie is not memorable.
Even though I do not have young children, I decided to rent this movie.  I loved it.  A good lesson to learn...  LOVE and RESPECT YOUR MOTHER!

I was a little weary about buying this movie. I had no idea what it was about and it was marketed to the young female audience. I started this movie and the picture was amazing. The forest was drawn like a work of art. I was amazed at how much detail the Blu Ray contained. At first the events of the movie shocked me a little. I had no clue what was going to happen. There really wasn't a bad guy like most Disney movies; however, it didn't take away from the story. There was a lot of humor to the movie that propelled the story and kept you interested. The best part out of all this movie has to offer is how well the side characters were implemented into the show. The voice acting fit very well with each character and gave the movie a lot of depth. I would recommend this movie to anyone that enjoys a good Disney Pixar animated film.
Disney does it again with another movie that will be passed down generation to generation. Family friendly and overall a great movie.

I PLACE ANOTHER 3D-DVD TO VERIFY THAT THE PROBLEM WAS NOT MY 3D DVD PLAYER AND I WAS RIGHT, MY DVD PLAYER IS GOOD THE PROBLEM WAS THE DISC. I REALLY HOPE AMAZON WILL SEND ME A REPLACEMENT OR MY MONEY BACK SO I CAN BUY IN ANOTHER STORE. I BUY EVERYTHING IN AMAZON IN THIS IS THE FIRST TIME I HAVE A PROBLEM.

Outline of the story was too pointed out for tweens or teenagers, predictable and hardly any funny elements in it. When you sit down to watch a cartoon, you expect to enjoy yourself. This was too boring.

Good message and well done for the most part. Kelly MacDonald was my favorite and overall it was very family friendly although my 4 year old granddaughter was frightened during the scenes with the bear at the end.
The animation for this movie is gorgeous. And the storyline is utterly charming and touching. Great family movie, I highly recommend it! Pixar just keeps getting better and better.

My children love this movie and so do I.  Great message about it is okay to be yourself and to be careful what you wish for!  I love that we can watch in on our Kindle, the Play Station or our Roku since it is in our cloud storage.

I was just saying how there's so many movies about son/father (finding nemo, bambi), or father and daughter (the little mermaid, ice age continental drift), but none about mother/daughter relationships. Now there is one. Very cute movie.
I would recommend this for all ages.  Well constructed tale with both humor and drama about breaking and healing relationships.

The real essence of the movie comes as a real surprise. It is a family booster, something that is hard to find today. Be there when your kids watch it. It's for the family, a complete binding experience. Beautiful.

Possible spoilers ahead.

I'm going to begin by saying I am a 21 year old who absolutely loves animated movies.  For a long time, I would have considered Finding Nemo to be my favorite Disney/Pixar, but Brave effortlessly replaced it with its Celtic charm and lovable characters.

This movie was excellent.  The animation is stunning, the characters are quirky and interesting, and although the plot is short it really covers everything they could have done with this plot.  It was nice to see a princess who finally didn't end up with the man and openly admitted that she may never be interested in getting married, ever.  It's much more common to see the princess fall in love and leave happily ever after, especially with Disney, so it was definitely refreshing to see the princess taking the front seat and controlling her own life rather than letting the men in her life control her.  Feminist thoughts aside, the characters in the movie were enjoyable (adore the little brothers... "wee devils, more like!") and the visual representation of Scotland is breathtaking, as most Pixar animation tends to be.

Those who are complaining about the nudity and humor ("feast yer eyes!"...it's funny because traditionally, men wear nothing beneath their kilt) have clearly never seen what else their kids are watching on television (seriously, if your kid is watching Spongebob, Adventure Time, The Fairly Oddparents, etc., they've seen almost literally the same thing).  Seriously, Merida is a great influence for the little girls of this generation:  Merida can teach them that they are able to make their own choices and they do not always have to follow tradition.

While the movie was short and I do believe they could have made it a little bit longer and a little more suspenseful, but if you didn't tear up a wee bit during the climax, you may have missed the point of it, and that is a shame.
The whole family enjoyed this film.  My 6 year old watched it 5 times in two days.  Great story, superb animation.  Highly recommend.
Wonderfully heartwarming movie that teaches a valuable lesson on the dangers of pride. The special effects are really really good as are all of Pixars movies.

This was a good movie for the kids.  The movie has a message and this message will teach kids to be grateful for what they have and appreciate the love of a mother. Also send a message to parents to let their children choose for themselves. It was nice to have all this in a movie. It was entertainment for the whole family.

this was a great movie to watch with the family.  I will definetly watch this with my family again on movie night.

Nice plot for a Mother/Daughter resolution play.  It would have been better if there had been at least one or two admirable male characters.  Perhaps if the father figure hadn't been so dumbed down.  As it is, this movie doesn't have a single significant adult male character which isn't the cartoon representations of some form of stupid, evil, or awkward.  Only the mother and daughter come close to being normal in both their cartoon physical form and character representation.  Maybe this is a good movie for a single Mom to share with her daughter?

Beware! It's not a Disney movie!
It's not a Pixar movie!
After the first 15 mn I really felt uncomfortable and God knows
how much I usually love Pixar and Disney.
Finally I hated it.
